PROCTEXT.PARA: The DEPUTY PRESIDENT (Senator Colston) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: AIDEX Exhibition
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:

We the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully call on the Government to withdraw its endorsement from the arms bazaar, AIDEX `91, scheduled to be held in Canberra, 26-28 November, 1991, and to ensure that no government department or company takes part in the aforementioned event.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senator Jones (from 40 citizens), and Senator Vallentine (from 148 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: AIDEX Exhibition
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable Speaker and members of the House of Representatives assembled:

The petition of the undersigned shows the very deep concern of people in the community against the proposed AIDEX exhibition of weapons of war in our country. We firmly believe that it is not in Australia's interest to become dealers in death and destruction. Particularly at this time when our planet's environment is in a parlous condition and demands statesman-like leadership to the world on its rehabilitation. We therefore ask that:

The Exhibition to take place be one which shows instead the ways in which we aim to overcome the dangers to our world from poisoned soil, air and water by high-lighting the need for tree-planting, solar-powered homes, electric cars, etc. as a means of attacking the global warming and other hazards to our fragile environment.
And we, your humble petitioners will as in duty bound, ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Tobacco Advertising
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: the humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That we the undersigned call for urgent action by our Federal Parliament and all government agencies concerned with Health and Sport to impose an immediate ban on the incidental advertising of tobacco products on television and provide for alternative funding to replace tobacco sponsorship. That tobacco sponsorship of sporting events and participants openly flouts the 1976 Federal law prohibiting tobacco advertising on TV and radio. That our Parliament immediately end this association between healthy sports and the deaths of 18,300 people in Australia each year from tobacco-related diseases.
And your petitioners in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Political Advertising
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled; the petition of the undersigned citizens of Western Australia respectfully showeth:

That we call upon the Honourable Senators to reject legislation denying Australians the right to advertise electoral material on radio and television, believing such bans amount to a denial of free speech, an unfair advantage to an incumbent government, and a denial of information to print-handicapped Australians.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Consumption Tax
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President of the Senator in Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned,
i) are alarmed by talk of a consumption (goods and services) tax which we feel would have a devastating effect on the lives of the people on low to middle incomes.
ii) call on the Senate to express its total opposition to the introduction of a consumption (goods and services) tax.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom: 0055 Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
(1) Telecom is selling 0055 telephone networks to private contractors who provide offensive and sexually explicit recorded messages to the public.

(2) The providers of these services are advertising in the pages of Australian newspapers in a manner which is designed to titillate and attract calls from the whole community and thus play on the curiosity of children.
(3) These services degrade and humiliate women and portray them as sex objects, and they destroy the innocence of children.

Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, immediately call on Telecom to so regulate the conditions under which these services are made available, that women are no longer portrayed as sex objects, degraded or humiliated and that the innocence of children is protected.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Arms Trade
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled:
We the undersigned petitioners draw to the attention of the Senate the central role played by the arms trade in creating an environment in which armed conflict such as the Gulf War can occur.
Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should demand that the Australian Government:
(a) outlaw sales of armaments and arms-related technology to overseas organisations: government and private.
(b) lobby internationally, including at the United Nations, for the banning of sales of armaments and arms-related technology.
(c) cancel the AIDEX 91 arms bazaar.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT (VALUELESS SHARES) AMENDMENT BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Watson) agreed to:
That the following Bill be introduced: A Bill for an Act to amend the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 to provide for deemed disposal of valueless shares.
Motion (by Senator Watson) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: — I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows--

The purpose of this Bill is to allow losses on valueless shares to be claimed as a capital loss and thus be available for netting off against any capital gains accruing in the current or future years, in circumstances where the company, the subject of the investment, is in liquidation.

The current capital gains provisions do not allow for capital losses arising from investments in shares in circumstances where the corporation is in liquidation and where a valid and effective transfer of ownership cannot be effected.
Further, the liquidator rarely directs funds for maintaining a share register.

Timing problems arising from the present capital losses provisions reflect yet another example of taxpayers' restricted rights under taxation law in Australia. Other jurisdictions with capital gains assessing provisions provide a recognition of loss in such circumstances.
This Bill will thus allow capital losses to be available to offset capital gains in the current or future years.
The Government has acknowledged the problem, since Income Tax Ruling 2643 suggests that a loss can be crystallised by transferring relevant shares to an associate party for a nominal consideration.

However, the ruling may founder through certain provisions of the Corporations Law as absolute control and ownership of the shares may not be validly and effectively transferred in such circumstances.
The purpose of this Bill is to determine the mechanism or technique to crystallise the loss.

Although the ATO in Income Tax Ruling 2643 has stated that under certain stated conditions Part IV A would not typically apply to "wash sales", there is still a probability that the share sale arrangements between related parties, including family members, could be caught by the anti-avoidance Part IV A mechanisms as the facts of each case need to be determined.
"It is not possible to give an assurance that Part IV A would not apply to wash sales generally"--ATO Ruling 2643.

Most significantly, I believe the ruling to be wrong in law. One accounting firm has stated that, "The ruling appears to substitute some form of arm's length test for the true test contained in Part IV A.

The Bill defines the valueless shares as having negligible or nil value. A similar situation exists within the UK tax legislation. The "negligible value" is not quantified in the UK legislation, though the UK inland Revenue considers negligible to be less than or equal to five per cent of the par value of the share.
Such a determination could be assisted by an appropriate income tax ruling.

To complement the legislation, the ATO would publish from time to time, details of lists of shares where such claims would be accepted. The circulation would be via organisations including the Taxation Institute of Australia, Butterworths and CCH tax services, the Australian Taxpayers Association, Australian Securities Commission and the Australian Stock Exchange.
The concept of a deemed disposal and re-acquisition is a familiar one within the context of Part III A.

Subsection 160WA(2) will require the taxpayer to make an election by notice in writing given to the Commissioner on or before the date of lodgement of the income tax return for the year in which the disposal of the share is deemed to have taken place or within such further time as the Commissioner allows.
This technique provides a degree of flexibility and a mechanism for current period or future eventualities.

In Taxation Ruling No. IT2624, the Commissioner exempts companies, superannuation funds, approved deposit funds and pooled superannuation funds from the necessity to lodge such election notices. The ruling, however, does not apply to individuals or trusts.

However, once the full self-assessment system, as outlined in the Federal Treasurer's 1991 August Budget, is fully implemented, individual and trusts will no longer be required to lodge such election notices but simply retain them as part of the taxation records.

The principal beneficiaries from this Bill will be private investors who invest in their own names and who have to dispose of shares before being able to claim the losses but cannot because of provisions in the Corporations Law.

The Bill may have been drafted more widely to cover persons who hold units in a unit trust where the value of the units may have been lost, i.e. units in Estate Mortgage or provided for situations where shares in a company are valueless, but no formal winding up has been entered into in order to liquidate the company. Such extensions would have required a more complex Bill.
The cost to revenue would not be significant.
I commend this Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Foreman) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator McMullan) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows--
The Social Security Legislation Amendment Bill (No 3) 1991 gives effect to a number of measures most of which were announced in the 1991 Budget.

In his Budget Speech the Treasurer recalled that in 1987 the Government introduced the Family Allowance Supplement to provide a basis for targeting income support to families and that during 1991-92 the Government would be building on that work. The Treasurer announced that a major families package would be introduced to provide additional assistance to low and medium income families with children and target Family Allowance more effectively. This Bill provides for the first stage of that package.

From 1 January 1992, the existing parental assets test of $347,500 (indexed each 1 January) for family allowance supplement (FAS) will be replaced by a family assets test. The existing assets test for FAS is based on parental assets only. This can be avoided by rearranging assets among family members to ensure parental assets fall below the test threshold. As a result of the changes this possible avenue of avoidance will be closed.

Family Allowance is the only major social security payment not subject to an assets test. This Bill provides for the introduction from 1 January 1992 of a family assets test of $600,000 of net assets excluding the family home.

Currently, the parental assets test on FAS removes entitlement when the value of net assets (excluding the family home) exceeds $347,500. In the prevailing economic circumstances, especially the effects of the rural downturn, the Government is concerned about the welfare of children in families with assets above the test threshold but where those assets are returning very low incomes.

The Bill proposes to introduce a special financial hardship test to operate for the next two years from 1 January 1992. This change will protect these families by allowing them to continue to receive FAS if the value of their net assets does not exceed $600,000. If the value of their net assets exceeds $600,000, they may continue to receive FA only.

From 1 April 1992, the income threshold at which full rate FAS is payable (currently $18,000 a year) will be increased and aligned with the AUSTUDY income threshold. (This is currently $19,300. From January 1992 this will increase to $20,700 a year, indexed each January.) This increase in the FAS income threshold will increase both the number of families eligible for FAS and the entitlements of families receiving less than the maximum rate of FAS. It will also achieve greater consistency between the AUSTUDY and FAS income tests.

Under current arrangements, all FAS recipients, irrespective of whether a full or part rate is payable, are entitled to a health care card. In order to bring entitlement to health care cards more into line with the income test arrangements for eligibility for health care cards for low income earners, from 1 January 1992 health care card entitlement will be limited to existing FAS recipients (full or part rate) and new recipients of full rate FAS.

Provisions to give effect to the second stage of the package, namely, integration of Family Allowance, FAS and Additional Pension and Benefit and the continuation of payment of FA until the end of a young person's secondary studies or to the end of the year in which the young person turns 18, whichever is the earlier, will be introduced in the Autumn Sittings next year.
From 1 January 1992, a person's FAS will be recalculated where the person's income increases to 125% of his or her base tax year income even though the increase was not related to a notifiable event.
The Bill will also effect a number of minor changes, from 1 January 1992, in the area of families administration.

Other measures contained in this Bill will also benefit families. First, on 1 January 1992 there will be an increase in the rate of Child Disability Allowance by $2.15 a week (after the annual 1 January indexation has occurred) to help restore Child Disability Allowance to the same value it had in real terms when introduced in 1987. The Youth Disability Supplement will be increased by the same amount. Second, family payments will be back-paid to the child's date of birth if a claim is lodged within 13 weeks of the date of birth where the child is born on or after 1 January 1992. At present back payments apply only if a claim is lodged within 4 weeks of the date of birth.

Sole parent pensioners face substantial up-front costs when undertaking education. Although those undertaking vocational training have course fees, books and equipment paid for, no similar assistance is available to those undertaking general education. Accordingly, this Bill provides for a $200 up-front payment to be made each year to sole parent pensioners who are starting or continuing full-time or part-time education courses and who are eligible for the AUSTUDY supplement. This will apply from 1 January 1992.

There can be no doubt that young persons who have to live away from home or who leave secondary studies at an early age face considerable social and economic disadvantages. With this in mind, this Bill provides for initiatives directed at young persons under 18 years of age.
The current Job Search Allowance and Sickness Allowance provisions relating to young persons aged 16 to 17 years have helped to improve the circumstances of many young people.

However, many face hardship because, although they have lived away from home for a substantial period, they are precluded from Job Search Allowance or Sickness Allowance as they do not meet the employment requirement set down in this definition. This Bill provides that, from 1 January 1992, for an "independent young person", 13 weeks registration with the CES will be accepted. At present the definition requires that the young person must actually have been employed.

At present, a 16 to 17 year old person in substitute care for whom no substitute care or similar allowance is being paid receives the basic rate of Job Search Allowance or Sickness Allowance unless he or she qualifies for the independent rate under other criteria. From 1 January 1992, this Bill provides for social security arrangements to be brought into line with AUSTUDY entitlements for 16 to 17 year old persons in substitute care.

There are currently unemployed and sick 15 year olds who receive special benefit on the ground that they would, apart from age, qualify for Job Search Allowance or Sickness Allowance respectively. These special beneficiaries are required to comply with all the usual Job Search Allowance or Sickness Allowance qualification and payability conditions but are subject to more rigorous income testing, ie, dollar for dollar reduction in benefit for each dollar of income earned. Persons in this category are not eligible for transition-to-work incentives such as the Employment Entry Payment and are not generally eligible, under Department of Employment, Education and Training guidelines, for the labour market assistance available for 16 and 17 year old Job Search Allowance recipients. This places 15 year olds who are essentially in the same position as their 16 and 17 year old Job Search Allowance counterparts at a distinct disadvantage. This Bill extends qualification for Job Search Allowance to 15 year olds who meet the requirements for Job Search Allowance apart from age, who are above the minimum school leaving age or have a formal exemption from attending school, who have an employment history and who are not living with or being supported by a parent.

There is a need to ensure that any anomalies in social security legislation or administration are removed. To that end, from the day of Royal Assent, neither Job Search Allowance nor Newstart Allowance will be payable to persons receiving income that is paid by a community or group from funds provided under a Commonwealth funded employment program. If the person's partner is receiving such income, the person will not be entitled to an additional payment in respect of the partner.

There can be no person in Australia today who is not aware of the special difficulties being faced by the rural community. Although many primary producers are `asset rich' they are often `income poor'. As a result, they may receive reduced social security payments or none at all as a result of the application of the assets test. This may be the case even though they have considerable liabilities. At present, the assets test works by compartmentalising debts so that they can be offset against only the particular asset which provides primary security for the debt and then only if the owner of the asset and the primary debtor are the same person. An example of the problems this causes is where the value of a person's farm is included in the person's assets thus precluding payments. Assume there is also farm machinery valued at $100,000 but it is subject to a bank lien of $150,000. Effectively the machinery has a negative value of $50,000. At present the liability of $50,000 cannot be offset against the value of the farm to allow the person to qualify for payments.

This Bill modifies the assets test from 1 January 1992 to allow primary producers to deduct all liabilities which relate to carrying on of primary production from the value of all assets used in that production.

The Bill will also ensure that, with effect from the day of Royal Assent, the value of a person's asset will be taken to be reduced by the value of a charge or encumbrance on the asset only if the person or the person's partner gets the direct benefit of a loan secured by the charge or encumbrance. This amendment will close a loophole highlighted by the recent Federal Court case of Clayton whereby mortgages taken out for the benefit of others were held to be allowable deductions.

From the day of Royal Assent, the rules for assessing notional ordinary income within the hardship rules will be modified so that owners of residential premises that are occupied by family members in certain situations will not be penalised because the premises are not attracting commercial rates of rent.

This Bill provides for the implementation of two initiatives relating to rent assistance. First, the rent assistance waiting period for recipients of Job Search Allowance, Newstart Allowance, Sickness Allowance or Special Benefit who have no children and who are aged between 18 and 60 years will be reduced from 26 weeks to 18 weeks. This will apply also for disability support pensioners aged between 18 to 20 years. This will start on 20 March 1992. Also from 20 March 1992, eligibility for rent assistance will be extended to under 18 year olds who receive the homeless/independent rate of Job Search Allowance, Sickness Allowance, Disability Support Pension or Special Benefit and who have been receiving social security income support for at least 18 weeks. A further initiative relating to rent assistance will be included in a bill to be introduced later in the current Sittings.

The Bill also provides for the extension, from 1 July 1992, of bereavement payments to certain long term social security recipients and their partners. The bereavement provisions generally work by allowing the survivor of a pensioner couple to get paid more for a period of 14 weeks. In some cases a lump sum may be payable. However, at present, the bereavement provisions do not extend to beneficiary couples. The Bill also extends from 12 to 14 weeks the period in which a person receiving a widowed person allowance will be entitled to a bereavement payment. This measure will apply from 26 March 1992.

The aftermath of the recent deaths of people at Strathfield highlighted an unfortunate aspect of current social security legislation whereby child bereavement payments were not available to some families. I gave an undertaking to correct this deficiency at the first opportunity. This Bill gives effect to that commitment and provides that, on the death of a child, a parent may be eligible for payment for 4 weeks of Family Allowance, Child Disability Allowance or Double Orphan Pension as is applicable in the particular circumstances. This measure is to be taken to have commenced on 17 August 1991.

The Bill also makes some minor consequential amendments to various Acts mainly as a result of initiatives effected by this Bill and the introduction from 12 November 1991 of the disability reform package.
I commend the Bill to the Senate and present the Explanatory Memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Committee will consider certain items reserved by Senator Baume which relate to the expenditure of the Department of the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I thank the Minister for Social Security (Senator Richardson) for his courtesy in allowing this procedure to take place. I am most grateful and I will try not to hold up the Senate or the Minister's group of advisers too long. Firstly, I will deal with the reservations that I made concerning the Australia Council. The peg is a question I asked about calculating the funding for the Australian Opera. I notice that in that funding there is no indication that the impact of the major award changes that took place last year has been met, apparently in any way, by the Government through the Performing Arts Board. Of course, this creates major problems because the orchestras for the opera and the ballet have, for the past 20 years, been fully funded.

SPEECH.PARA: As I understand it, there is an extra half a million dollars per orchestra--Sydney and Melbourne--involved in costs as a result of that work value case. The consequences of that huge additional cost are very severe indeed for the users of those orchestras. In fact, the Minister will no doubt be aware of a letter sent by the chairmen of the organisations that are mainly affected by this: Mr Redlich, the chairman of the Victorian Arts Centre; Mr Wiederberg, the Australian Opera and Ballet Orchestra; Mr Fred Millar, the Australian Ballet Foundation; Mr David Clarke, chairman of the Australian Opera; and Sir Rupert Hamer, chairman of the Victorian State Opera Company. I understand that letter went to the Prime Minister and to Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories (Mr Simmons) and to the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly).

I stress that, even today, as I understand it, there has been only a very moderate increase from the Performing Arts Board--something like 2.5 per cent--in the funds available for the orchestras' users, which would go nowhere near meeting this massive additional cost. The consequences are that either the opera and ballet orchestras will play with a smaller number than the required 69 or the users will have to pay for the extra players. For the first time in 20 years, these orchestras will not be fully funded. I hope the Minister will be able to indicate to me, firstly, what sort of response the Government has been able to give to this very concerned letter from these organisations and, secondly, what is going to happen.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The position is that the Performing Arts Board of the Australia Council was considering this matter last Friday, I am advised, although I am not certain of the result. The position of the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories (Mrs Kelly) is that the Performing Arts Board can, if it chooses to do so, allocate funds to cover this increase. The Minister has so far declined to provide extra funds to the Australia Council to cover the costs of increases in the award for musicians.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My concern is that, if the Government has declined to fund this, it means that the Government has decided that it will not meet the additional cost of award decisions handed down by a tribunal. As I understand it, that is the first time this has happened in this area. I do not know of a situation where the Government has refused to meet, in a fully funded organisation, the determinations of a wage tribunal. Maybe there are circumstances when that has happened but I am unaware of them.

SPEECH.PARA: What I do know is that if this situation persists--and the Minister has outlined that the Government has declined to do this--according to these people there will be a crisis in the orchestral end of the opera and ballet. I understand that the Australian Opera has already written to the State Orchestra of Victoria advising that it cannot meet the additional costs because it does not have the income either from government grants or its ticket sales. As Mr Donald McDonald said in a letter to the Victorian Arts Centre Trust:

I hope that you agree with us that to merely transfer part of the funding obligation for that orchestra from Government to user companies which are themselves Government funded, is a worrying and potentially dangerous step, which would act only to transfer the problem, not solve it. For over 20 years, Government has fulfilled the responsibility of funding the two orchestras; it is not reasonable for that responsibility to be diluted when the extra funding is required entirely to meet costs resulting from proper industrial process.

I wonder whether the Minister could give any indication as to what the Government believes to be the correct way to resolve this problem. Is it suggesting to the user companies that they cut their expenditure elsewhere--for example, reduce the number of singers or dancers employed? It would have to be a very substantial cut because in 1992 there will be a total shortfall of $883,519 in funds to pay the salaries of the two orchestras in the event of this situation remaining unresolved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I think there would be a number of ways that the orchestras or, indeed, the Opera and the Ballet could meet these costs. It would not simply relate to saying that the Opera would have fewer singers next year. I imagine that there would be a range of measures, including an increase in ticket prices, that could be used. I think what is occurring at moment is a proper examination of not only the financial situation, but also the administration of the orchestras to see which is the best way to go. As I said in answer to Senator Baume's first question, the Performing Arts Board is still considering whether to fund this. Once the Minister has seen a report from the Performing Arts Board, he might be in a position to take the matter further. I do not think this is the first time that the Commonwealth has not fully funded an award increase. I think the usual procedure has been that the Commonwealth and the States together fund such increases, although I will have that checked for Senator Baume.

SPEECH.PARA: In so far as the Opera is concerned, we have made some one-off grants over recent years. Each time we make one, we are told that it is the only one it needs, but we have made a few more after each one. So I think the Government's support for the Australian Opera is graphically demonstrated by the number of times we have come in with extra funding. I hope that, whatever happens now, the Opera is not forced to cut the number of its performers. That does not mean there are not efficiencies to be gained in the Opera, the Ballet and the orchestras.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I thank the Minister. In view of the courtesy he has extended to me in allowing me to raise this, I will not raise some of the other matters that I had wished to on the Australia Council. I will proceed to some other matters. I did have some difficulty with one of the replies to a question on notice. I asked how many of the 1,653 grants made to arts organisations were duplicated or jointly funded by State or local governments. In the previous year when I asked that question, I got a figure of around about half. I notice that the response this time equivocates and says in specific terms:

SPEECH.PARA: The Performing Arts Board allocates the majority of the Council's general grant funds. In 1990-91 of the 76 companies receiving general grants, 68 were jointly funded by a State or Territory.
I am grateful for that information because it does underline a fairly substantial level of duplication, but I am wondering why the reply says:
The Council does not give a consolidated tally of this joint funding project by project across all art forms.
I wondered how the previous year's figure was indicated to me and whether, in fact, a ballpark of around about half, which was indicated last time, is accurate.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I think we would have to get officials to go back to find out why there is a difference. I imagine that it would be a fairly big task to go through 1,600--or whatever it was--grants to find out which ones are funded by other tiers of government. I do not like the term `duplication', because I do not really think we are talking about duplication. There is an inference of inefficiency in the word `duplication'. Of course, many companies can exist only because they receive funds from two or three tiers of government. So I would prefer to use words like `supplementing' rather than words like `duplicating'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I proceed to the question of film. In particular, I would like to deal with a couple of matters that were raised in response to a question that I asked on Film Australia. It was about the extent to which there may have been a diminution of use by departments of Film Australia's facilities as a result of the change in the arrangements last year under which departments were no longer obliged to use Film Australia for their work. The reply to my question about whether the departments have been building up their own facilities was:

SPEECH.PARA: Film Australia is aware that several departments do have installations which replicate what is already available in the private sector.

This includes Film Australia. It is not aware of any such developments since July. What is the Government doing to ensure that the change in the arrangements does not lead to a wasteful duplication--in this case it would be a duplication, not a supplementation--of facilities and activities within the Department rather than using either the private sector or Film Australia?

TALK.START.PARA: —-There has been a fundamental change in the way the Commonwealth conducts its business in this respect. It is up to managers in each department to make their own decisions rather than there being some compulsion about using Film Australia. From early indications, in any event, this is working to the advantage of the Department and of Film Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I will not pursue that matter any further. I have a question regarding the general revenues of Film Australia. I presume that when the annual report comes out we will see a full list of its revenues, activities and so on.
—-Yes.

—-I now switch to the Film Finance Corporation. According to a report that came out after the meeting of the Senate Estimates Committee, the Australian Film Commission noted that there had been a significant decline in feature film production in the latest year, which it said was due to a levelling out of feature film investment by the Australian Film Finance Corporation, as well as a decline in the number of films funded principally by private investors, particularly foreign investors.

SPEECH.PARA: When I looked at the Film Finance Corporation's previous balance sheet, it seemed to me that there had been a substantial increase in the volume of Film Finance funding in 1989-90. Was the decline in activity in 1990-91 related to the change in the Government's funding arrangements which, as I understand it, involved a slight diminution in terms of grants--I think $5m--but an attempt to raise more money through private sector prospectuses? I had been under the impression that these prospectuses had been successful; in fact, that was the answer given to me during Senate Estimates. But if they had been successful and the Government's funding was reduced by only $5m, how come there has been this substantial reduction in the funding of films by the Film Finance Corporation, such that the Australian Film Commission says that it is the major reason for this decline in feature film production from $204m in 1989-90 to only $137m in 1990-91.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-This is best explained by pointing out that, while the Film Finance Corporation can have an allocation of $70m in one year, it does not necessarily spend it all in that year; there can be a carry-over into the following year. As I understand it, that is what occurred here.

SPEECH.PARA: As I understand it, the Film Finance Corporation has been quite successful in the private sector; its film funding is fully subscribed. Having said that I, like many senators yesterday, received a delegation from Actors Equity expressing concern that, if projected cuts in years ahead were to go ahead, we might find a substantial drop in the number of films being produced. I intend to seek the Minister's thoughts as to whether that is likely to occur. Obviously, in the aftermath of the end of 10BA, there were always going to be some difficulties. I think they have been substantially overcome in the last few years; I am not necessarily certain of the future. That is why, as a result of yesterday's meeting, I will be seeking some assurances from the Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —-These concerns were also raised with me yesterday by the arts people, particularly in view of the uncertainty that is apparently hanging over the industry because the decision about renewing the FFC funding does not take place, I understand, until next March. Can the Government indicate whether it intends to maintain its direct funding or whether it will persist with the trend back towards tax benefit funding; in other words, through investment in FFC prospectuses.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-From my experience in the portfolio, I would be shocked and appalled if we were to go back to using tax expenditures. I think that was an unfortunate episode in the history of Australian arts. I had so many examples brought to me of rorts under 10BA that I think it is dead and buried and no-one should exhume the cadaver.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of the future, a review is being conducted. I think that should be available to the Minister by the early months of the new year. The Minister then has to make a decision on the level of funding for the Film Finance Corporation. I do not think we can necessarily predict the outcomes of the review; certainly, there are those among us who will be watching it very carefully. What the Government does with the level of funding will be critical to the industry over the next few years.
The success of Proof is outstanding. It was not funded by the Film Finance Corporation, and it had a budget of just over $1m. There is obviously no set formula for success.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I thank the Minister. In particular, I am glad he mentioned the success of Proof--I would not have raised it. The thing that is striking about Proof is that it was, of course, a low budget film. As I recall, the Australian Film Commission was involved in its funding, rather than the Film Finance Corporation. What concerns me is that the Australian Film Commission's report on lower production levels dramatises that considerably fewer low budget films were made in the latest financial year. It says that 11 films--around half the number of 1989-90--were budgeted at under $3m. Does the Government have a policy view on this? Should we be looking more at big budget items? Is it purely the Film Finance Corporation taking a big budget view? That is why I am grateful for the Minister's comment that it was interesting to note that Proof was so successful. Is there a Government policy that the Film Finance Corporation should be getting into the big bickies items and diminishing its role in low budget films?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I hope I am not corrected but, certainly, there was an onus placed upon the Film Finance Corporation for commercial success to enable it to attract significant private sector investment. There is always going to be a problem when one does that because of accusations of the sacrifice of culture in the pursuit of monetary gain.

SPEECH.PARA: The Film Finance Corporation, therefore, is looking at some, mostly in any event, pre-sale interest in a prospective production. Very often that means the Corporation is looking at some likely overseas distribution. Very often that is more likely to occur with a film that has a larger budget. So there may well have been a tendency in that direction. Again, referring to the representations that industry workers are making, the problem with that is this alleged cultural sacrifice in the sense that often overseas actors are put in these films to attract that pre-sale interest. There is considerable criticism; there is no point in kidding ourselves on that, and that is another matter I intend to take up with the Minister.

It is not the Government's job to direct the arts. That is always a fine line which governments should never cross. But I am equally concerned to see that the range of films produced in Australia is as wide as possible and does not become too stereotyped--does not rely too much upon a formula. There are certainly many people in the industry who feel that it is heading in that direction. So that is another matter that I will take up with the Minister, and I will inform Senator Baume of the Minister's views.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I thank the Minister very much for that--all the issues he raised are obviously of major concern, particularly when one is distributing a very limited amount of money. However, I would make the point in passing that film overall takes something like twice the amount of government revenue that is available to the total of all the other arts put together. So there are some problems with other arts groups which come seeking funds, particularly when one takes into account the tax expenditures involved in film making, which would probably have cost the taxpayer something like $20m in the latest year, according to the figures for private sector contributions.

SPEECH.PARA: The next matter I want to raise relates to the roof of the Australian National Gallery. When I first asked about this disaster in Senate Estimates, I was told the cost was going to be something like $3m. This time we found that the cost is going to be well over $5m--it is $5.6m. Quite frankly, I find that totally unsatisfactory. I am not suggesting motive, but the response initially was clearly misleading because it did not include a whole range of other expenditures.

When one asks for the cost of fixing something, one wants the cost, not what an individual contractor is going to get paid for it. In an answer at the Senate Estimates Committee hearing on 18 September 1990 an amount of $3.43m was referred to in connection with the roof repairs. In fact, this amount referred to the contract price for the roof repairs but, in addition to the contract sum, fees are payable to the Australian Construction Service in the sum of $727,000 for administration supervision. A further $600,000 was spent on design and preparatory costs. The contract allows for a rise or fall in costs, and it is expected that additional costs associated with this will be approximately $300,000.

In other words, when one asks a question about how much it will cost to fix the roof one is told $3m which really, when it is translated into real language, means $5.6m. All I would ask is whether it is possible for someone to take on board that when a senator asks a question about the cost of something we should be told the cost, not a segment, a portion, a smorgasbord or a part of that cost.

The reason why this is of such major concern is evident later on when one sees what the cost of this roof disaster has really been to the Australian National Gallery. It is not simply a cost of $5.6m to fix it; it is the consequential cost of the Gallery's activities being severely inhibited during the years of that fixing. I asked how much the net surplus was for the year 1989-90--the year before the fixing of the roof started--so that I could get a feeling of just what the consequences of this roof mess have been.

In fact, the whole thing has probably cost the National Gallery close to $10m both in expenditure to fix the roof and in revenue lost. In 1989-90 the net surplus of non-government revenue, excluding donations and sponsorship from specific subsidies and grants for the Australian National Gallery, totalled $2 1/2m. This included revenue from the British Museum exhibition and the art of photography exhibition. In 1990-91 that $2 1/2m collapsed to $150,000. For this year it is expected to be $380,000. That means a shortfall over those two years of $4m, perhaps more. That is $4m in receipts that the Australian National Gallery may well have earned had it been able to have blockbuster exhibitions which, we were told at the time, it could not have because of the roof repairs. Close to 10 million bucks lost from the Gallery's revenue of something like $20m a year is, clearly, very significant and very damaging to the Gallery.

As I understand it, there is no way of seeking recovery against the people or persons--the designer, builder or whoever it was--responsible for the disaster of that roof. I simply hope, in view of the enormous cost, that the Government, the Gallery or whoever else may be involved in building anything in Canberra and looking at future contracts, will take a fairly severe view of the competence of people who cannot build a roof properly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I apologise to Senator Michael Baume if he has gained the impression that a misleading answer was given. I think someone has simply seen that a contract was let for roof repairs for $3.4m or whatever it was, and has given Senator Baume that answer. Clearly there are other costs involved. The sum of $5.8m has been appropriated for it, but I think the total costs are likely to come in at around $5m, because the estimate was made prior to tenders having been received. It appears that the figure will come in closer to $5m than $5.8m.

SPEECH.PARA: I will certainly ensure that Senator Baume receives an answer as to what may have been forgone as a result of the roof repairs. To some extent it is in the area of conjecture but, given the number of exhibitions that do come to the Gallery, it would not be unfair to assume that, had this problem with the roof not occurred, there would have been more. I will make sure that the Department gives Senator Baume an estimate of that cost as soon as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —-On the subject of the Australian National Gallery, I discovered in the Estimates Committee hearing that the Gallery had rejected sponsorship from the Rothmans Foundation for an unstated amount of which I am not aware. It struck me as strange that, at a time when the Gallery is clearly pressed for funds, when it has enormous expenses, when it is close to $10m down the gurgler in regard to its roof, it has the capacity to knock back sponsorship from the Rothmans Foundation. By the way, a few years ago it was quite prepared to take money from Philip Morris by way of sponsorship.

SPEECH.PARA: I am concerned about this because, as I understand it, the product is legal; the Rothmans Foundation is separate from the company; support from the Rothmans Foundation is not in any way associated with tobacco advertising as such; and Rothmans is not a major brand name of the Rothmans company. The Rothmans Foundation has as its trustees Sir Roden Cutler, Sir James Hardy, Sir Rupert Myers and John Utz. This is a group of citizens who could hardly be accused of seeking to do anything other than bring benefits to the recipients of Rothmans Foundation funding. I find it extraordinary, at a time when the Gallery is under such pressure, that that decision not to accept the money was taken.

I have a letter from Mr Alan Davidson, another distinguished Australian, who is the Executive Director of the Rothmans Foundation, expressing his concern at the response given in Estimates Committee C. The letter states:
At no point was it clarified that the sponsorship was submitted to this Foundation and that acknowledgments would have been solely to Rothmans Foundation and not any product.
We should perhaps explain in broad terms the objectives of the Foundation's different Divisions. . . These are:
Cultural
To advance artistic and cultural standards generally by the promotion of the fine arts of music, painting, sculpture and drama, to be achieved by the provision of public performances and exhibitions.

The most fundamental point we should make is in relation to the Trustees and executives of the Foundation. The activities of the Foundation are solely directed by the Trustees whose decisions are carried out by the writer and our executive officers. The Trustees carry out their obligations strictly in accordance with the laws in relation to the conduct of trusts and in particular under the Trustee Act of New South Wales.

Neither the founder of the Trust, Rothmans Holdings Limited, or any of its executives interfere with these decisions and there is therefore no opportunity for the executive of Rothmans of Pall Mall (Australia) Limited (their tobacco subsidiary) to in any way direct the Foundation's activities towards the marketing of tobacco products.
We trust this explanation clearly delineates the difference between our community based objectives and those of tobacco sponsorships.

I find this an extraordinary decision which will require strong defence. It is intolerable, particularly as I note that other organisations are prepared to accept Rothmans Foundation sponsorship. The Australian Chamber Orchestra on an invitation I received this week for 27 October says:
The afternoon's performance of the Australian Chamber Orchestra is proudly sponsored by the Rothmans Foundation.

This organisation of high repute is made up of people of integrity, but apparently they are not good enough for the Australian National Gallery, which is about $10m behind the eight ball as a result of its roof disaster. It seems to me that perhaps a touch of reality might be appropriate at the Gallery.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I am a little concerned because I find myself agreeing with Senator Baume too often this morning, and it is a worry. I share his view on this matter. Having said that, I would make the point that it is also true that the Council of the Australian National Gallery is made up of some outstanding Australians. They have made an independent choice. There was no instruction from the Minister. There is no policy that they have been given which tells them to reject sponsorship from tobacco companies or trusts of this kind that bear the name. This is a very big argument in the community.
—-You're not going to appoint Mr Hill to the board, are you?

—-I do not think we need to. From his point of view obviously this a good decision. I am not one of those who would reject sponsorship from that source. There are quite a number of people in my Party who would support this decision; there are probably some in Senator Baume's who would. However, I think that it is not the way to go.

SPEECH.PARA: Having said that, I do not think it would be appropriate for the Minister to instruct the Gallery. I think the Gallery has to make its own decisions. There may be marketing reasons for taking the decision. It may be felt that there is some effect down the road. The Phillip Morris sponsorship did not do it much harm, and I do not think that this will either.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I move on to the sports element of the Department. In particular to 5.2, relating to community sports facilities program, which was renewed in the latest Budget. I also found in response to questions asked about where the grants were made last year that an interesting pattern seems to be developing. In the community sports facilities program grants for New South Wales, for example, a remarkable proportion of such grants seems to go to Labor-held marginal seats.

SPEECH.PARA: It may well be--and no doubt the Minister will claim this--that Labor-held marginal seats are those in the greatest need because they are the most depressed. I suppose that when one looks at the unemployment figures under this Government's induced recession, there may be a case--I have not seen a case made out--for the fact that they are the most needy parts of Australia. In New South Wales, for example, where there are 51 seats, almost a third of the community sporting facilities program money went to just four marginal Labor seats. The largest amount, $250,000, or about 14 per cent, went to just one seat, which magically happens to be Calare, the seat of the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories (Mr Simmons) and a very borderline seat indeed.

In Western Australia 75 per cent of last year's grants went to Labor-held electorates which only totalled 57 per cent of the electorates, with Canning getting $162,000 or 35 per cent of the State's total allocation. Another received 22 per cent.

In Queensland seven marginal seats got 75 per cent of the grants and five of those seven marginal seats were Labor-held. At the time the other two were held by the National Party, but I understand that in Kennedy in particular, which received a fair amount of attention, it was trumpeted around that this was the Labor Government that had brought these goodies. I do not know, but it may well have been a factor in the National Party's losing that seat. The remaining one, Dawson, is held by an outstanding member, Mr Braithwaite. Adding the five marginal Labor seats and the two coalition marginals together, in Queensland 75 per cent of the grants went to just seven seats.

I am grateful to the Government for giving me the breakdown of this programs expenditure. I seek an undertaking that perhaps a more equitable approach could take place in future. I would have thought that perhaps areas of greatest need would probably be very safe Labor seats rather than marginal ones. I wonder why it is only the marginal seats that appear to be in such desperate need of the community sporting facilities program.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I cannot look to my left for assistance on this matter because the Department did not handle the distribution of these grants; I did. It was done from my office. I understand that the new program will be done from the Prime Minister's office as well. Therefore, it is misleading to talk about the percentage that may have gone to one electorate or to two or three electorates. Sometimes it may well be a big project.

SPEECH.PARA: We set a rough guide that the maximum grant that could be received was $250,000. In fact, there were very few over $200,000, because the idea was to try to spread the money. If one happens to be in the electorate that got the $200,000, that can distort the figures. I do not think that the percentages mean that much. Much of the money did go to some safe Labor areas. There were very big grants to areas like Penrith, which is part of Ross Free's seat. There were plenty of examples of large grants going to western suburbs seats, and also to a great many rural electorates where there was significant disadvantage.

As for Senator Baume's claim that Labor may have won Kennedy because, in his words, we trumpeted the fact that it was the Labor Government that brought the grants to them, I would point out that, if Government policies are popular and we win seats on them, that is an example of good government that is accepted by the people. In fact, the sports facilities program was a phenomenal success. The number of applications for the number of grants was extraordinary indeed. We were literally getting more than a thousand applications for what were only ever going to be the small amounts--small in the context of the whole Budget--that were available.

I am sure that, because of the success of that program, there will be tremendous demand for the next one. I am certain Mrs Kelly would make sure, in the same way I did, that the only rule that is applied is that of need. If that is applied, one would imagine that the more deprived areas will get the bulk of the funds. I live in the electorate of Bradfield, which is represented by Mr Connolly. I doubt very much that the Minister would be looking towards giving my electorate any funding, and she should not.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Perhaps the Minister's electorate covering the whole State could receive some attention. I commend the Minister for his recognition that the program has been a phenomenal success. If people are offered money, they tend to ask for it. They tend to put out their hands if $10m is waved in front of them. I do not know that I would necessarily regard it as astounding that there has been enormous demand. One would find it astounding if there were not.

SPEECH.PARA: I stress that the Minister's response has underlined the political nature of this program, which has very little to do with perceived need by the sporting organisations in terms of what is the best location for the facility. The decisions are not made in the organisations best capable of determining the ideal location for facilities around Australia but rather by the Department or the Sports Commission. Information of that nature is readily available in the sporting organisations, which get together in many instances to establish what is the best locale in terms of the sporting communities and not the specific political interests of politicians. That is where these kinds of decisions should be made.

The fact that the Minister has said that the decisions are made in the Minister's office underlines the political stunt involved in this program, a stunt that is once again using sport for political purposes. I recognise that the Minister for Social Security is highly regarded in the sporting communities for many of his initiatives in his previous portfolio; I do not detract from that. What I will say to him is that many sporting organisations are resentful about the manner in which this large amount of money is being distributed on a basis that is, if you like, related not to what they see as the best interests of the sports involved but to other criteria. It is inappropriate and wrong that this kind of decision should be taken in a Minister's office.

TALK.START.PARA: —-What is the reason for having it in the Minister's office?

—-My colleague and friend from Victoria interjects: what is the reason for doing it this way? Did some additional staff have to be put on in the Minister's office anyway? Why is the Sports Commission so incapable of doing a good job in this area that the decision has been taken out of its hands and political decisions made instead?

SPEECH.PARA: I believe that there is a very sound case for reviewing the program on this basis. I notice that it is being renewed. The program has been so politically successful at $6m a year that funding has been increased to $10m. That largess in borderline seat terms is coming not out of an arm's length independent organisation such as the Australian Sports Commission but out of a political office, so it is natural that the outcomes are political.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I absolutely reject those assertions. All that the decision to increase funding from $6m to $10m a year reflects is the demand of which I spoke earlier. It is not the case that that is in some way politically handled. Many of the grants given were very small. For example, they went to putting lights on some very small ovals so that people could train at night; they went to providing gear for junior sports in a whole range of areas. The truth is that there is phenomenal demand. I am still getting letters of thanks from organisations all over Australia--I might say, organisations that I do not know. The funds are not given to friends; they are simply given on the basis of need.

SPEECH.PARA: The truth is that we could not go anywhere near satisfying the demand, and $10m a year will not satisfy it either. In that circumstance, it is far better to protect officers of the Public Service from the kind of criticism they inevitably get. I would much rather that the criticism be directed at myself. If I am responsible for the decision, I have to live with it.

Out in voterland, there is so much demand for the funds that whatever decisions the Minister makes next time will also undoubtedly attract criticism because she will not satisfy the demand. I know she will do her very best to ensure that there is no political bias in the decisions. Certainly, given the rural recession, I have absolutely no doubt that a greater percentage of funds will be directed to rural areas this time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister in his innocent mode has a certain charm. I must say that this charm has softened my hard heart, but not to the extent that I do not regard what he just said as absolute nonsense. The criteria on which all decisions about funding are made would be such, according to the Minister's definition, as to have them all transferred from the Sports Commission or any other commission to the Minister's office.

SPEECH.PARA: A limited amount of money is available for all sports in Australia. For example, there is continual disagreement about the `elite' athletes programs as against the `non-elite' programs. The Minister has never at any stage shown a massive determination to protect the bureaucracy from the slings and arrows of outraged recipients. How incredible it is that in this program, which happens to have massive political overtones, the Minister is, out of the kindness of his heart, protecting the bureaucrats from offended non-recipients of such grants. Quite frankly, this kind of double standard sounds terribly exciting and attractive and lovable, but it just does not wash. Will the Minister now give us the real reason why these grants are being made out of his office instead of out of either the Commission or the Department?

TALK.START.PARA: —-While Senator Michael Baume has been speaking, I have been looking at a list of the grants made in 1988-89 and 1989-90. Having quickly perused the list, it bears out what I said rather than giving the lie to it. Accusations of political bias are easy to make. When one looks at the sorts of places that have received the money, one sees that those accusations are much harder to sustain. I could not tell the Committee what electorates these places on the list are in; I have no idea. If it is at Penrith or Cessnock I know; I do not know where the Shire of Banana is.
—-It's in Queensland.

—-I thought it might have been; it would seem logical. Obviously, a lot of rural places received help. I would not know what electorates they are in. I do not think that was ever the consideration. I am not suggesting that the decision should be made by a Minister for any reason other than the extraordinary nature of the attention that is given to these kinds of grants. I am not trying to apply this across the board, but I think it is much better that the Minister himself or herself answer criticisms for these kinds of decisions rather than officials.

—-I thank the Minister for his quick skip through the list. I encourage him to do a more detailed examination, where he will find that just two Labor marginal seats--Calare and Hunter--received something like $400,000 out of the $1m that was spent on Labor-held seats in New South Wales.
—-That's meaningless.

—-The list dramatises it. We can see where the money is concentrated, and it is a remarkable coincidence that the concentration just happens to be in Labor-held marginal seats. I invited the Minister to explain the real reason for having these decisions made in a Minister's office rather than within the normal structure created for the distribution of taxpayers' money. His initial explanation--that he was trying to protect the bureaucracy from the outraged people who failed to receive the grants and how difficult it was to make these sorts of grants--simply does not wash and bears no relation to reality and is equally applicable to all the grants that the Sports Commission makes. The Minister is quite happy to see the Australia Council dividing up very limited amounts of money without protecting the Council in this way. I draw it to the Senate's attention that the Minister has been repeatedly asked to explain why these grants are handed out this way and that he has continually chosen not to do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I am disappointed that Senator Baume will not accept my explanation although, in referring to the Australia Council, again he points out the truth of what I am saying. My understanding is that in the new program to be announced cultural facilities will be included in the list. That is being done because, when we were looking at applications for the recreation and sporting facilities program, there were many cultural organisations which also needed assistance. There can often be a borderline between activities that are recreational and activities that are cultural. We will attempt to step over that line and allocate money to the cultural bodies as well as to the recreational and sporting bodies.

SPEECH.PARA: Just as the situation was when I was making these grants, there was consultation at times with the Department; quite a bit. State Ministers from all around Australia were approaching me about it, so there was certainly consultation with the States. Sporting organisations never stopped coming to see me about it, so there was consultation with God knows how many of them. Obviously, it is not simply a matter of the Minister sitting in splendid isolation making decisions. There was widespread consultation and there will continue to be. I am sorry that that explanation does not satisfy Senator Baume, but both of us will have to live with it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I thank the Minister. I believe that his answer outlines quite clearly that there is no coherent reason why these grants should be made in the Minister's office. There is nothing that distinguishes these grants from any other grants. The Government's decision to have these grants made out of the ministerial office underlines and dramatises their political nature.

SPEECH.PARA: In concluding my remarks on those grants, I was interested to note the response to my request for information about the success of previous grants. Of course, this has some bearing on the criteria for the making of these grants now. The Minister might, at some stage--not necessarily now--outline to us what criteria are used by the Minister in determining magically that Calare and Hunter, for example, have a greater need than apparently any other seats in New South Wales.

I note that, in determining whether the grants had been successful so far under the previous regime of, I think, $6m a year, in reply to my question about the failure rate the departmental brief said that almost every project was able to show an increase in recreation and sporting opportunities in the local community. I frankly wondered what `almost every' meant. Why would there be failures? I find that the answer shows that 14 per cent of projects reported no change in participation rate. I assume from that that participation rates in terms of facility are the Government's measure of success.

If 14 per cent of projects reported no change in participation rate, I suppose one can assume that there was no evident demand--at least yet shown--for the better facility. The funding did not increase the opportunities of the local community to use the facilities, at least in a meaningful way or, if there was an increased opportunity, there was no evident need for the improved facility. There may be other criteria but, if participation rate is the Government's criterion, it seems to me that a 14 per cent failure rate is pretty high when money like that is handed out.

I notice that in only one per cent of cases--that is two projects--there was a decrease in participation. I suppose the Government could say that it was 99 per cent successful because there was a fall in usage in only one case. It seems to me that the Government is required to explain to us whether participation rate is the measure of success, and what criteria are being used to hand out this money.

TALK.START.PARA: —-It might be appropriate at this point if I were to table the guidelines for the community cultural, recreation and sporting facilities program 1991-92, which I am more than happy to do. These guidelines are, of necessity, broad. There are many factors which have to be taken into account. I am quite happy for Senator Baume to have a look at those guidelines, together with the application form which accompanies the guidelines when they are sent out to those people who request that they receive a grant. When Senator Baume looks at that, he will see that there are quite a lot of criteria used in determining which bodies receive a grant. In fact, the figures which Senator Baume just gave me would tend to bear out the success of the program. If 86 per cent of facilities have reported an increase in participation, that is good. But it would not prevent us, in looking at grants, from increasing the pleasure, the health and the well-being of those who are already using these programs. If in 14 per cent of those cases we managed to do that, then I think we would be judged as successful.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I now move to the Australian Sports Commission. One of the matters I wanted to raise by way of reservation was funding for the Australian Olympic team for the 1992 Barcelona Games and the Adelaide bid for the 1998 Commonwealth Games. I will start with the funding for the Adelaide bid. We were told at the Senate Estimates hearings that no decision had yet been made, nor was one needed before February or March of next year. We were told that the fact that no announcement had been made in the Budget was of no consequence because it would not be a 1991-92 Budget appropriation; it would be a 1992-93 appropriation, if an appropriation were to be made.

SPEECH.PARA: I also noted in the reply that Brisbane had received no assistance in its successful bid some years ago for the Commonwealth Games but did receive a fair level of support in other ways. I find this reply remarkable because I have here a copy of a letter from Mr Hawke to Mr John Bannon dated 13 May 1991 in which he says, among other things:
I wrote to you separately to provide my Government's support for the bid which I trust proved helpful at the meeting of the General Assembly of the Commonwealth Games Federation in Malta on 12 April.
He goes on:

Regarding funding issues, you will appreciate that Commonwealth funding along the lines sought in your letter is still a matter which will need to be considered initially in the 1991-92 Budget round of discussions which will commence shortly.

Either it was to be discussed in the 1991-92 Budget context or it was not. Mr Hawke says it was; the departmental response says that in the end it was not. Does the fact that Mr Hawke says it was going to be discussed mean that it did come up and it was decided at that stage not to commit the Government? The letter indicates that the Government took a decision that it would not give an undertaking at this stage to support the Adelaide bid. If that is the inference to be drawn from the letter, is it a fact that in the 1991-92 Budget round of discussions Mr Hawke's apparent request that it be considered was not acceded to? Was the decision made to defer it? Was the decision made not to provide money? What decision was made?

TALK.START.PARA: —-In fact, both the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Department are correct. The matter was discussed and it was generally agreed--with South Australia as well--that there was no need for a 1991-92 allocation. The Commonwealth is not contributing funds to the actual bid to get the Games. I am certain that it would, as it has on every other occasion, assist an Australian city if it were to succeed. It has been agreed that we do not need to commit funds until we see whether that bid is successful. The matter will certainly be raised in the Budget discussions next year. But if Adelaide is successful in getting the bid in the interim, then certainly we will be contributing funds. So both were correct.

—-I would now like to go to the question of the Australian Olympic team's funding and the widespread reports, which emerged from answers at Senate Estimates, that the Government had cut back the money about which there was an understanding it would be providing for the Barcelona Olympic team by $1.5m. I understand that the Sports Commission had a meeting this week. Can the Minister outline whether the Sports Commission has made a decision to meet that $1.5m and, if so, where it came from? Did it come from other sports allocations or did it come from the huge item shown in the books as administration expenses of something like $20m, which covers not simply the normal concept of administration but a whole range of activities carried out by the Commission on behalf of other sports? If, in fact, it has come out of that administration vote, can we be assured that it does not cut services available to other sports?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-First, I should add to my previous answer on the Adelaide Commonwealth Games bid by saying that we have now received a request from the South Australian Government that at least an intention to support the bid be included in the documents that it will be sending off in an attempt to gain success. I do not think that will necessarily be specific in terms of money; just a clear statement of Commonwealth intention. On that basis, Minister Kelly will be approaching the Cabinet, perhaps at its next meeting or the one after. I will certainly make sure that Senator Baume is informed of the result, although I would be very surprised if the Cabinet were to decline.

SPEECH.PARA: As for the $1.5m from the Sports Commission, the answer is yes, the money has been provided. It has not been taken from any sport; rather, it has come from part of the surplus from last year, it has come from a transport credit and it has come from interest. It is money that could have been allocated later on to other sports, but no sport will have its program cut due to the fact that this grant has been made.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I acknowledged when I was asking the question that it was likely that the $1.5m would be found out of the administration vote, of something like $20m, which covers many things apart from administration, such as services provided to sporting people and sporting organisations. So to that extent the Minister's assurance that it came out of administration does not necessarily diminish the point, as he conceded later, that it may well have been available otherwise for other sports.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister may be aware that Minister Kelly had said on Sydney radio when debating the matter with me that this money had always been available, that there was no suggestion that it was not available and that I was running some kind of scare campaign or misleading people by saying that the money was not being provided. As the decision taken clearly indicates that the money was not being provided until this decision was made, what was the initial understanding that that additional $1.5m would be available? From everyone in sport I have spoken to, that understanding clearly existed in people's minds. What is the basis on which that understanding was made? What was the basis of the decision not to grant it? What is the reason given by the Sports Commission for taking money that may well have been available to other sports to top up this needed amount which everyone understood was to be provided by the Government?

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister obviously referred the matter to the Sports Commission, which examined it, acknowledged the importance and the significance of the Games and contributed accordingly. As to whether understandings existed over time, I am certain that, had there not been a surplus from last year, a transport credit, sufficient interest or whatever, the Government would have found another way. There was no way that we would leave our Olympic athletes unable to get to Barcelona. It would have been done in any event. I am sure that is what Mrs Kelly was referring to when she was debating it with Senator Baume.

—-I will leave it at that. I think my colleague Senator Crichton-Browne has some points to make. I conclude my comments on the Australian Sports Commission by noting that no new staff positions are to be created without the approval of the Commission. This was in reply to a question I asked as to whether a staff freeze had been imposed. I was told there was no staff freeze, but that the Commission was not going to appoint any more staff without approval. Is the pressure that is now on the Commission such that it is running so short of money that there are staff requirements that will not be met? Is this shortage of money related in any way to the $1.5m that it has to find for the Olympic bid?

—-I think the difference is that, if there is a staff freeze, then as people leave they are not replaced. As far as the Sports Commission is concerned, if anyone leaves, it is still going to be in a position to replace them and I am sure it will do so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Could I raise a question in relation to the Australian Sports Drug Agency? It was a matter I raised during the Estimates deliberations. It refers to the secrecy provisions, section 67 of the Australian Sports Drug Agency Act. The Department seems to have thus far generously interpreted it as meaning that certain information was not available to the Estimates Committee. I referred Senator Richardson to a subsequent opinion given by the Attorney-General's Department which was tabled in this chamber by Senator Tate. He said that general secrecy provisions do not constitute declarations under section 49 of the Constitution and, therefore, do not apply to members of committees and others who receive information in the course of the committee's work. Has the Department had an opportunity to review that question which I raised at that point? If so, does it now acknowledge that the secrecy provisions do not prevail in respect of disclosures of the nature which I referred to for the purpose of Estimates committees, the Committee of the Whole or, in fact, the Senate?

—-The motion is that the Committee consider certain items reserved by Senator Baume which relate to expenditure of the Department of Arts, Sports, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Can Senator Crichton-Browne lead me to where this matter was raised by Senator Baume?
—-I am sorry, Madam Temporary Chairman, I missed that.

—-I am raising the question, Senator Baume, that the motion before the Committee is that the Committee consider certain items reserved by Senator Baume. The point is that, if this matter raised by Senator Crichton-Browne is not a matter that was reserved by Senator Baume, he should, in fact, be seeking leave if we are actually departing from the motion which is before the Committee.
—-Thank you, Madam Temporary Chairman, for so kindly guiding me. I did have a reservation of my own but, if it would be more expedient and the will of the Committee, I seek leave.
—-It is not a matter of expediency; it is the actual motion that is before the Committee.
