—-I seek leave to raise this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I do not think that a great debate can ensue because we do not actually have the final opinion yet. As Senator Crichton-Browne would be aware, we can consult economists and get different opinions, and we can with lawyers too. I think the Solicitor-General in the Attorney-General's Department is still discussing this matter. We expect final advice from the Attorney-General's Department soon. It has not been received yet, but hopefully it will be in the next couple of weeks.

—-I must record some disappointment that it is some weeks now since I raised this matter. It was not as if the Department were ambushed. The opinion was given on 16 August and tabled in the Senate at my specific request as the result of a question without notice by me of Senator Tate. Then, as I recall, I set out in my question the conflicting advice given by the Attorney-General's Department and the Solicitor-General. I asked whether the Minister would draw together those contradictory and confusing opinions and establish once and for all what the position was in respect of those opinions. With respect, I would have thought that the opinion given on 16 August, to the extent that it pursues that matter, is definitive and makes it quite clear that the understanding of the Department thus far is quite incorrect.

—-I agree with Senator Crichton-Browne. I am disappointed that we have not got finality on this matter as well. It is not something that I can really push the Department to do much more on. It has had its discussions with the Attorney-General's Department. In fact, I referred to the opinions of the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) yesterday in answer to a question from Senator Macdonald. They do not always come as quickly as we would like. They do sometimes take quite a while. I am certain that the Department will continue to push, and I will make sure that it does.
—-With respect, the point I was trying to make is that it might be that the opinion has already been given.
—-There was disagreement about that even in the Attorney-General's Department.

—-Is the Minister saying to me that an opinion provided by the Solicitor-General, at the request of the Attorney-General, for the purpose of asking a question in this Parliament has now been disputed by somebody else and, therefore, this opinion is no longer valid? It begs the question: what opinion do departments go on? An opinion has been provided by the Solicitor-General to the Attorney-General, tabled by the Minister for Justice (Senator Tate). Is the Minister for Social Security saying that does not satisfy the Department?

—-It is not a matter of satisfying the Department. I am trying to point out that there is some disagreement in the Attorney-General's Department about this. I hope it will be resolved shortly. The fact that lawyers disagree amongst themselves is not really new.
—-Who is going to give these opinions then?
—-When it comes to the crunch, no doubt Michael Duffy will give a tick to something; and whatever that is, Senator Crichton-Browne will get it as soon as we do.

—-I do not want to pursue it any further. The question I asked of Senator Tate was whether the Attorney-General would give me a definitive opinion. The Attorney-General did give me a definitive opinion because he tabled the Solicitor-General's opinion and said, `That is the opinion you have requested'. That was given by the Minister representing the Attorney-General. That was the opinion I asked for. I did not ask for some lackey to scribble down thoughts of his own as to what might be the case in a certain hypothetical circumstance. I asked the Government to give me a definitive position in respect of legislation which it had proceed through the Parliament. It was given by the Attorney-General. Now Senator Richardson is saying that somebody in the Attorney-General's Department is unhappy with what the Attorney-General himself has tabled in the Parliament, through his Minister for Justice representing him. Having said that, I do not expect Senator Richardson to respond, but I think he understands what I am saying.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I wanted to conclude my remarks by referring to my reservation relating to the appropriateness of having the funding of the National Media Liaison Unit through DASETT but its administration through DAS, so that no questions relating to the purposes of the DAS appropriations could be pursued through Estimates Committee C. This raises a real question about accountability. As I understand it, the splitting of responsibilities creates real problems. For example, in DASETT Estimates hearings, I asked questions relating to the functions of the National Media Liaison Service. I was told that, because employees are, in fact, employed by the Minister rather than the Department, the Department could not answer. The Minister was not there because she, in fact, is a Minister in another chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: Here we have the incredible situation of government money being expended but, because of the device used by the Government, proper inquiry as to those expenditures not able to be answered by the Department because, as it has said, `We were simply responding to requests and our function is to do no more than respond to the requests and to provide money, not to have any managerial or effective control over that funding'.

This leads me to a whole series of problems. Why has the Government chosen to use this extraordinary device which, to my knowledge, does not exist anywhere else in the Commonwealth Public Service, and have this incredible situation where the National Media Liaison Service is shown on a separate sheet in the Commonwealth Government Directory? It fits into no departmental or other structure and appears in front of all of the departments. In the pages covering DAS or DASETT there is no link of any kind with the National Media Liaison Service. It is not listed in the Commonwealth Government Directory as being under the care, responsibility or administration of any government department. This incredible device, once again when there is a political issue such as handing out money to marginal seats for sporting facilities, is handled in a Minister's office and the opportunity to ask questions and receive meaningful answers is not presented to us in a committee. I would be grateful if the Minister would explain the reason for the Government operating the National Media Liaison Service in this incredible and highly unusual way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I think this kind of arrangement has existed in government before. Customs used to be split between DITAC and the Treasury. In this case, the staff of the National Media Liaison Service, like all ministerial staff, are employed by the Department of Administrative Services under the Members of Parliament (Staff) Act. Consequently, if that Department is responsible for those salaries, staff and all the rest of it, the actual salaries will be recorded there.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister to whom the National Media Liaison Service reports is, of course, Mrs Kelly. If honourable senators have questions about the activities of the National Media Liaison Service, it is appropriate that those questions be asked of me as the Minister representing the Service before this Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Does the Minister have with him the answers to the questions I asked yesterday about the National Media Liaison Service? I had hoped to be able to study them before the completion of this section.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-No, I do not have a full set of answers for the honourable senator yet, although I have a few answers that may be of assistance to her. They are very short so I will go through them.
—-I thought you may have had a written list which I could read while Senator Baume was asking his questions.
—-I have three answers which are very short and I think it is best if I tell the honourable senator what they are and take it from there.
—-I just didn't want to interrupt this train of questioning.

—-I am sure Senator Baume will not mind if I take a very short time to give the answers I have. With his indulgence, I shall do that. Firstly, Senator Newman asked about a list of Government and Opposition members of parliament. The answer to that is yes, the National Media Liaison Service retains copies of standard lists circulated throughout the Parliament. These lists are maintained to assist with the mailing of Focal Point and to enable the speedy dispatch of material requested by parliamentary officers.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Newman asked about the involvement of the Service with the release of the Department of Defence strategic review on 30 May. Service staff played no role in producing the review. However, Service officers did circulate press releases and speeches relating to the review on behalf of the relevant Ministers. Because Service staff are employed by the Department of Administrative Services, individual staff training costs, if they are incurred, would be the responsibility of that Department, so DASETT did not meet any of their training expenses.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I thank the Minister for those quite inadequate answers. They do not take us very far at all. I am very interested that the Service has an index of Opposition members and senators for `the speedy dispatch of material'. It seems that when Opposition members and senators ask for material there is no dispatch at all, let alone a speedy one. So there seems to be no justification for that.

—-I am informed that, when Opposition offices request material which the Service has, it does dispatch it to them speedily. I think many Opposition senators and members have been the recipients of that speedy dispatch.

—-That brings me to another question. I also asked what records were kept of the type of work the Service performs and whether I could have a detailed breakdown of them. That has not been adverted to this morning. For example, what dispatches go to honourable senators apart from Focal Point?

—-It would depend on the requests. All members of parliament receive copies of Focal Point and Rural Focus, which are sent to their offices. In answering a question before, I talked about the speedy dispatch of material as requested by members and senators. So it would depend on individual requests as to what other material was sent out and, of course, whether the National Media Liaison Service actually had the material in the first place. If such material is requested, it is dispatched speedily.

—-I understand that the Minister has said in the past that he is of the view that Opposition members and senators should have access to transcripts through the Service. Senator Bolkus said in October 1989 that the Government was now prepared to make that service available to Opposition members. I put on the record the fact that this is not happening and Opposition members and senators have been refused material on a number of occasions.
—-I think it is a misconception to believe that the National Media Liaison Service has transcripts of everything that occurs in Australia. It simply does not.
—-Just to the Opposition.

—-No; the honourable senator should allow me to finish. The Service simply does not have that. Senator Bolkus was saying that, where transcripts are available, the Service is prepared to provide them. As I understand it, that has not changed.

—-I now turn to the matter about the Service which brought me to the chamber in the first place. I asked a question about the National Media Liaison Service not monitoring any radio or television interviews made by the Minister for Defence Science and Personnel, Mr Gordon Bilney, when he recently announced the $2m advertising campaign for the Ready Reserve. The Minister has told me that the Service did circulate press releases and speeches on behalf of the relevant Ministers. That is not what I asked. I asked precisely what I have just asked now and I have not had an answer, even though the Minister took that question on notice. Why can I not get a specific answer?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I thought the answer was about as specific as I could get, actually. The National Media Liaison Service staff played no role in producing the strategic review. I said that. They did not have any involvement in that production. I cannot dress that up to say that they did.

SPEECH.PARA: I said yesterday in response to questions that the National Media Liaison Service is not a huge bureaucracy and that it was not able to monitor everything. It did not monitor this. Any number of things occur in Australia on a daily basis, and it is simply not possible for the National Media Liaison Service to monitor everything. It was not done on this occasion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I did not suggest at any time that the Service was responsible for the force structure review. I asked about its monitoring of the announcement by the Minister. It was a matter of national importance: there was a large sum of taxpayers' dollars involved; there was a big flourish of publicity. It was probably one of the most momentous things that had happened in the defence community for a decade. Yet the Minister tells me that the Service did not monitor it. I find that beyond belief.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is very concerned. Both Ministers responsible for defence have made it clear that they are very concerned to see what the public reaction is to this Ready Reserve proposal. I cannot accept that there was not some requirement on the Service to monitor the announcement and the aftermath. Can the Minister tell me differently? I just do not believe it.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I am sorry that Senator Newman does not believe it but it is nonetheless true. I would imagine that, when the Service is making decisions about what it will monitor and what it will not, it takes into account what will be available to the Minister directly. In this case, the Department of Defence has a public relations set-up. I am sure that the Service would have believed that that public relations team could adequately monitor the press reports of the Minister in making the announcement. From what I have seen, it did.

—-I do not intend to pursue this further today, except to say that it is quite clear that the staff need a lesson in manners. Not only have my staff been rudely treated by the Service, but so also have the staff of some of my colleagues. If ever people on the public payroll need lessons in manners, it is the people employed in the National Media Liaison Service. Having said that, taking up the Minister's offer of easy access by the Opposition to transcripts, I now ask formally whether I could have a copy of every transcript monitored by the Service for the next month.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I would think the provision of every transcript to any individual would be a total waste. No-one in the Government gets it. I have no idea, therefore, why Senator Newman should. I will certainly not be instructing the Service to do that.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of lessons in manners, all I can say is that David Epstein, who runs the Service, is an urbane and charming gentleman. I am sure he would not be guilty of any offence on the telephone. My former private secretary has just gone to work for the Service as well and she is in exactly the same category. I am not aware that the Service ought to be criticised. In fact, a member of Senator Newman's staff is the subject of a complaint from the National Media Liaison Service for persistent rudeness. Maybe when we are handing out the lessons on manners over the telephone we should hand them out where they ought to go, and that is in Senator Newman's office.

The other point I should have made on the question of monitoring, and it involves the transcripts, is that it is a minor function of the National Media Liaison Service. In the priorities of the Service, it comes a long way behind the dissemination of information.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I thank the Minister for coming back to the question of priorities of the Service. I have asked exactly for a breakdown of the work of the Service. The Minister has so far refused to give it to me. Is he going to persist in refusing, at the same time as getting stuck into a member of my staff, who I know to be one of the most courteous and pleasant employees in this building--and anybody else will vouch for her too? I have said to the Minister that the staff in the Service have been rude to the staff of my colleagues as well. I would suggest that the odium should stop where it belongs--in the Service.

SPEECH.PARA: Getting away from the personalities involved, I ask the Minister for a breakdown of the work that aNiMaLS performs. I asked for a detailed breakdown yesterday. I also want to know what records it keeps. It is very hard when a publicly funded body such as this avoids accountability.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The people who work in the Service are employed as ministerial staff.
—-On the public payroll.

—-Of course they are on the public payroll. I am simply stating the obvious--that they are employed as ministerial staff. The guidelines for what is supposed to be done by the Service have been tabled before in this place. I am happy to table them again.
—-I did not ask that. I asked--

—-Senator Newman should just listen for a moment. If she is an example of the rudeness, I can understand the problem. If she would simply listen to what I am saying she might learn something. The role and functions of the National Media Liaison Service have been tabled before in this House. The role and functions are matters of public record. I can repeat the dose and table them again; it will not change much.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not believe that anyone in the National Media Liaison Service sits down and writes down everything he has done in the course of a day. No-one in my office does; people do not have time. I imagine that no-one in this Service does either. If that was a requirement for the entire Public Service I think we would be in all sorts of strife. No-one does it. Senator Newman is asking of the National Media Liaison Service something that no-one else does or is going to do.

I cannot give Senator Newman a list of everything the National Media Liaison Service has done, nor can I tell her everything it will do. I can show her what the role and functions are supposed to be. I know of no examples where it has gone outside that role or those functions.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Minister has just said that transcripts are not a priority in the work of the Service. This Service is publicly paid for, no matter which category we put the employees in. Its wages and running costs come out of the public purse. It must be one of the least accountable and most invisible public bodies in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: When I ask in this Committee for a breakdown of the work, I am not asking for a day-to-day running sheet; I am asking for information in more detail than we have ever been able to get before. I am not asking for guidelines yet again; I am asking what it is actually doing. If transcripts are not a priority, what are its priorities? What percentage of time would the staff in totality give to the various aspects of the work they are required to do? Is that too much to ask to be told to the Committee?

TALK.START.PARA: —-If we were not talking about the National Media Liaison Service but about any other department--
—-With any other department we would get that information.

—-No; the kind of question Senator Newman is asking would be very difficult indeed to answer. One wonders what a whole range of departments would say in response to that. I will certainly get a report from the Director on what the activities of the Service have been in recent times and where he sees the Service going over the next few months and provide that to Senator Newman. That is not a difficult thing to do. It must be remembered that there are quite a number of people with the Service who do not even work in Canberra. There is a representative of the Service in each capital city and in a few provincial cities as well. These people are spread out and what they do will differ dramatically from what people in Canberra do. They all do their jobs. I will get a report although, judging from the tone of Senator Newman's question, I do not think any report will satisfy her. I will make an effort to satisfy her and see what I can do.
—-I thank the Minister but I have asked for a detailed breakdown. So I remind him of that in conclusion.

—-Is it correct that on occasions the National Media Liaison Service provides transcripts and other material to the Press Gallery for its consideration, drawing to its attention certain remarks or comments that might have been made by a variety of people, whether they be Ministers, members of the Opposition or public commentators? It would assist if I could have a simple yes or no answer to that in the first instance and then perhaps a further question can follow.
—-There have been occasions when transcripts have been provided upon request. If they are available then they can be provided, but very often the kind of instances of which--
—-I am not talking about requests.

—-Senator Vanstone is talking about the Press Gallery. People in the Press Gallery might have requested it and there could be, if it is available, a response to that request. On many of the occasions when I have seen disputes in publicity about this, it has not been the case that transcripts were provided. Often a journalist asks about a particular quotation and very often if there is some important event on and a member of the service in one of the capitals, for example, is listening to a program, it is not hard to jot down one quote, and that can be provided. It does not add up to a transcript. The number of transcripts that are produced is nothing like what members of the Opposition seem to think it is.

—-I was not asking--and perhaps I did not make that clear in my question--what aNiMaLS might do in relation to requests from people. I was specifically asking whether material is provided in one form or another to the Press Gallery other than by its request. Are transcripts, news clippings, or it might be something else, ever provided by the National Media Liaison Service to either the whole gallery or members of the gallery other than at their request?
—-The National Media Liaison Service does not actively disseminate material to the Press Gallery.
—-Does it ever do it?

—-I am not certain if in all the years of its existence I can say that it has never done so. It does provide transcripts when they are available. Sometimes, if a Minister's office has one, it is quite possible that a staff member might disseminate a transcript more widely because perhaps some ministerial staff can rightly take on a more political role.

—-Can the National Media Liaison Service say whether in the last financial year and up until this portion of this financial year it has ever distributed material to the Press Gallery other than at the Press Gallery's request, or individual members thereof, other than at their request?

—-Obviously there are times when it does distribute material. Press conferences can be held here, and everyone in the gallery is very interested in getting the transcript of a press conference which may go for an hour. So while the transcripts can take some time to produce, and there is a lot of interest in them, then, naturally, the Media Liaison Service, as part of the dissemination of information, will get that out because that is what people are requesting.
—-Does it ever distribute information, other than on request, other than transcripts of press conferences?

—-If there are a lot of requests for something, the Media Liaison Service will give it to everyone. If it has had quite a few requests, rather than go and attempt a delivery to 10, 15 or 20 people, it will give it to the gallery; I think that has been done before--it will just box it.

—-Is one of the journalists in the gallery, whom I believe to be a credible person, lying when he tells me that the National Media Liaison Service distributed, either in whole or in part, portions of my very excellent little red book on the goods and services tax? Is he lying when he tells me that the National Media Liaison Service distributed that, at the very least to him and, he thinks, to other people in the gallery as well?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The National Media Liaison Service did receive a copy of Senator Vanstone's pamphlet. The Government is particularly grateful to Senator Vanstone for producing it--we have been dining out on it ever since. We wait for the next edition. The National Media Liaison Service did receive a copy of it from a journalist who had been given it by Senator Vanstone. Whether it is the same journalist whom Senator Vanstone has just spoken of, I would not know. But that is how the National Media Liaison Service, and a number of Ministers in the Government, came into possession of a copy.

SPEECH.PARA: I should like to take this opportunity to request Senator Vanstone to get many more of them printed. I should like to be able to assist her in the dissemination of that information. It is quite important that we get them out as soon as we can.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The answer still has not been given. Did the National Media Liaison Service distribute to journalists portions, or the whole thereof, of that booklet, the contents of which we can quite happily debate at another time. I want to know whether the service distributed it.
—-Are you ashamed of it?

—-As I said, the contents of that can be distributed at another time. If Senator Faulkner does not want this to go on, he should shut his mouth if he does not have a question. My advice to him would be to let the Minister answer.

—-The National Media Liaison Service did not distribute Senator Vanstone's pamphlet. I understand someone in a ministerial office may have helped out Senator Vanstone by getting this around the gallery, to give it the kind of publicity that we thought it deserved. It had not been getting a good run, and I know one Minister's office wanted to help it along and give it a run. I will see whether my office can give it some assistance as well over the course of the next few weeks.

—-I take that as a categorical denial that aNiMaLS has distributed it--I do not mean just the booklet as a whole because there were not enough copies for it to possibly do that--and that no copies or extracts thereof were distributed by the National Media Liaison Service; is that absolutely correct?
—-Absolutely.

—-In which case, I have a final question, and perhaps the Minister would direct it to the Minister who assisted in this matter--and I will be directing it to other Labor members: on what basis did they feel free to distribute the material without seeking some agreement from me on compensation for breach of copyright. That leads me to my final question on the National Media Liaison Service: has it been negotiating with the Copyright Agency Ltd for payments to that agency on the breaches of copyright that are clearly undertaken by the National Media Liaison Service in the reproduction not only of newspaper articles but also transcripts, excerpts from what people say and excerpts from what people write? If it has not been so negotiating, what consideration has it given to the lifeblood of reproducing other people's work?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-It is not their lifeblood. I have made it clear on several occasions today that that particular part of its activity is a minor one; it is certainly not its major activity. As far as negotiations over copyright are concerned, I know of no newspaper in the country stupid enough to attempt to suppress material that has appeared in the paper.

SPEECH.PARA: The circulation of newspapers depends upon the publicity that is generated. So the more widely things are read that are printed in newspapers then the happier newspaper editors and proprietors are. Certainly, I do not think there would be any attempt by the unit to do it. But if Senator Vanstone or anyone else seeks to produce information for members of the public and believes that it is going to be of some benefit to them, she cannot expect it to remain a secret.
Furthermore, Senator Vanstone's pamphlet was the subject of a parliamentary question. I am not certain what copyright she thinks she has in the Parliament but I suspect it is not real big.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I am grateful for the Minister's dissertation, despite the fact that it did not display any understanding on his part of the operation of copyright law in this country or elsewhere.
—-You have been hurt and I am sorry about that but it happens.

—-Despite the fact that it displays complete ignorance on his part, I certainly hope that what he has just said was not a briefing from the officers and, therefore, displays ignorance of the copyright laws in this country on their part. The question that was put to the Minister was whether negotiations have been held with the Copyright Agency Ltd. He answered as to whether the newspaper proprietors would be happy for copyright--
—-That is because you referred to it.
—-I did not refer to the newspaper proprietors; I referred to the Copyright Agency Ltd.
—-You referred to newspaper articles. You did.

—-Yes, that is exactly right--whether there have been negotiations with the Copyright Agency Ltd for some copyright payment in relation to the reproduction of newspaper articles. The reason why that relates to the Copyright Agency Ltd, and not exclusively to newspaper proprietors, is that the law in this country is that the copyright in newspaper articles reverts to the journalist once it has been used for the purpose for which it was created, which is reproduction in a newspaper.

SPEECH.PARA: The Copyright Agency Ltd is currently negotiating with the Attorney-General's Department--and any other body which is sucker enough to be sucked into this stupid arrangement--to get a payment of 10c per page from that Department. It occurred to me that, if the Attorney-General's Department is sucked in by this, the Government might be stupid enough to be sucked in by it and be negotiating with it too. It is 10c per page for the residual copyright which rests with the journalist, and there is a portion for layout and design which rests with the newspaper proprietors.

There is every reason to ask why aNiMaLS might be negotiating with the Copyright Agency Ltd which purports to be acting on behalf of all journalists but, in fact, is not--and certainly not acting on behalf of some of the more creditable ones. The question is, is aNiMaLs negotiating with the Copyright Agency Ltd?

As for the Minister's remark that he does not see why newspaper proprietors would want to get payment for the reproduction of their newspaper articles, he might like to look at what is happening overseas in respect of this where the copyright laws are slightly different, and where there is a clear recognition that the newspaper proprietors own the copyright and there is no residual copyright with the journalists. He would find that clipping services--and aNiMaLS, in that respect, is not that different--most certainly pay copyright fees to the newspaper proprietors who are happy to make a buck in any way that they can.

It still begs the question: does aNiMaLS understand the process which it is engaged in, and does it understand, with the law as it stands at the moment, the risk it is running of being clamped down on for higher payments? Why does aNiMaLS feel justified in breaching copyright law so readily and frequently?

TALK.START.PARA: —-There are two problems with the line that Senator Vanstone has taken. The first is the one to which I referred earlier. It is a fact that newspapers--and, I might say, most journalists--are absolutely delighted when their material receives wider circulation. It enhances their reputations and many of them enjoy basking in the publicity. Having said that, the National Media Liaison Service purchases from the company Monitair clippings and articles and, of course, Monitair has an arrangement on copyright.

—-As the Minister says that so confidently, perhaps he would like to explain what the arrangement is. He tells the chamber that Monitair has an arrangement. I would be interested to know what it is, because it is not my view that there is one. Or is the Minister guessing?

—-It is not a question of guessing. I am advised by the National Media Liaison Service that it has an arrangement with Monitair which, in turn, has an arrangement with the Copyright Agency. I am quite happy to seek from Monitair the exact details of this arrangement, and I shall do so.

—-In answer to a question on notice recently the Minister advised that there were two National Media Liaison Service people in Townsville, both fairly highly paid--I do not have the figures in front of me. In Townsville there are two daily newspapers and two radio stations and there is a newspaper in Cairns and one in Mackay. There are also the offices of the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Northern Australia (Senator Collins) in Townsville, plus a Labor senator, plus Mr Lindsay, plus several other Government departments. Why is it necessary to have two officers in Townsville in particular?

—-Two officers is a bit strong. There is a person employed to disseminate information and conduct the normal role and functions of people engaged by the service. There is also a person engaged to do secretarial work for that person. Senator Macdonald says `two officers', but there is only one engaged in the operations of which we are speaking today. As to why that is, I think that is just an acknowledgment of how important the Government regards the north to be. The person in Townsville not only covers matters that occur in Townsville and Cairns, but also an area to the south--given that the general term `north Queensland' covers a pretty fair area--over to Mount Isa, and up to the Gulf. We regard this as a very important area of Australia and we want to make sure that it is well serviced.

—-My junior staff member--a receptionist--covers all of those media and does it in the first hour of her day. In those circumstances, I wonder why it is necessary to have two highly paid officers in Townsville doing what my junior staff member does in the first hour of every day.
—-Fortunately, Senator Macdonald's junior staffer does not have to cover the work of 30 Ministers. That is what the person in Townsville has to do.

—-A week or so ago, my senior staffer found it necessary to make contact with aNiMaLS. We fully understand the crude political nature of that operation but what I cannot abide is the fact that he was sworn at, abused, refused any cooperation at all and eventually hung up on for the crime of simply asking for information and copies of speeches. This is not the first time. I have heard that complaint before. I have had dealings with people like Parks and I know the sort of thuggery that goes on. I cannot understand how the Minister can condone that sort of verbal brutality. I seek an assurance that, from the Director downwards, if staff are going to be uncooperative at least they will do it in a civil manner.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I do not condone verbal brutality on any occasion, and do not now. If anyone in the National Media Liaison Service is guilty of that, that person should be dealt with. Senator Alston says that he has dealt with Colin Parks. Anyone who has knows him to be a fairly restrained, quiet, gentlemanly individual--certainly not a person I would regard as aggressive or difficult. He certainly has not been so in any of the relations he has had with me in the last decade. I intend to talk to the Minister about counselling the staff on these matters. I have already said in here today that the National Media Liaison Service itself has complaints about a particular staffer of a senator. I am not aware that it has any complaints about anyone in Senator Alston's office. I will have the particular matter which Senator Alston has raised investigated and report back to him on it.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Progress reported.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report of Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure

TALK.START.PARA: —-I present the report of the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure on the Broadcasting Amendment Bill 1991.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Clauses 1 and 2--by leave--taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 3.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Australian Democrats are opposing this clause because it writes into the process that the amendments are putting in place a pre-vetting notification period in the event of proposed changes of ownership, an issue the Democrats strongly support; but this particular clause puts into the Broadcasting Act a provision for confidentiality in the pre-vetting of notification of changes of ownership.

SPEECH.PARA: An essential element of the work of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal has been, and in the minds of the Australian Democrats must remain, the open nature of its operations. We are aware that in many instances there will be, and there are, commercial in-confidence matters that should not be made public. However, the Act as it now stands provides for the Tribunal to make those sorts of decisions and provide for the sort of confidentiality that, one can understand, would be needed in many cases in this prior notification exercise.

Those provisions are already in the Act. The Australian Democrats cannot see why, simply because we are dealing with the prior notification process, there should be a particular provision for confidentiality. As far as we are concerned, what is in the Act is appropriate. In essence, the fundamental direction is that the Tribunal's proceedings are open and clear to the public. We are conscious that we are not talking about full inquiry. Nevertheless, the prior notification process that is being put in place is very important, and we do not see why confidentiality should be written into these amendments. As I say, if confidentiality is required, it can be put in place under the current provisions of the Act and, therefore, the Democrats oppose clause 3.

I want to put on record the fact that, since this is a matter about which we feel very strongly, in normal circumstances we would wish the Committee to divide on it. However, because of the problems we have today with time, we will not ask for a division but simply record the Democrats' very strong views in opposing this clause.

TALK.START.PARA: —-On behalf of the Opposition, I indicate that we will not be supporting the Australian Democrats. We believe that it would unnecessarily impose conditions on commercial operators to make public at an inappropriate time their intentions and what might be commercial-in-confidence information. For that reason we will not support the proposal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Government will not be supporting the Democrats, for precisely the reasons given by Senator Chapman. I add one further matter that is of great concern to the Federal Government in terms of agreeing to this proposal, and it was brought up very effectively last night by Mr Westerway in the meeting of the Senate Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure. He advised that the level of cooperation the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal is getting in the provision of this information is currently very high. It is being provided on the basis that at this point it is confidential, although obviously, if the matter becomes formal and ends up in a court, it becomes a public process. Mr Westerway made the point that in his view the exclusion of this clause would severely hamper the work of the Tribunal in examining these matters in the public interest. For that reason and for the reasons Senator Chapman gave, the Government will be opposing the proposal.

SPEECH.PARA: I do acknowledge, having had conversations with Senator Powell, the strength of the Australian Democrats' position on this matter. I appreciate the courtesy extended by the Democrats in not dividing on the clause.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I know that we are stretched for time, but I should just say that Mr Westerway's comments about how well things have been proceeding were made in the context of proceedings to date being carried out under the Tribunal's present powers. I think that confirms my view of the situation and the reasons why this clause does not need to be in the legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I was going to make this point when we dealt with a later clause. I do not want to waste the Committee's time either, but in response to Senator Powell could I say that that is not strictly correct. What is currently happening, I am pleased to say, is that people are coming forward with this information in anticipation of the legislation being passed.

SPEECH.PARA: I have to say that it would be the wish of the Government, and certainly the wish of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, that this approach be taken. It is the Tribunal's view that it is the approach that is likely to be taken in the future and that it may not be necessary to use the amendments in their full force. I have to say, with some appreciation, that the shadow Minister for communications, Mr Smith, acknowledged in the House of Representatives that he knew people were currently coming forward with this information on a voluntary basis in anticipation of this legislation becoming law.
Clause agreed to.
Clauses 4 to 6--by leave--taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-by leave--I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 1. Clause 4, page 2, at end of clause, add the following paragraph:
"(c) by inserting after subsection (3) the following subsections:

`(3A) Where a person fails to comply with a requirement in a notice served on the person under subsection (1), the Tribunal may make application to the Federal Court for an order under subsection (3B).

`(3B) Where, on an application under subsection (3A), the Federal Court is satisfied that the information or documents required to be produced by the notice are necessary to enable the Tribunal to exercise any of its powers, or perform any of its functions or duties, under this Part, the Court may order that an acquisition of interest, to which the information or documents relate, not occur until the information or documents have been produced in accordance with the notice.'.".
2. Clause 5, page 4, proposed paragraph 90HA(3)(c), line 16, omit "10 days", substitute "28 days".
3. Clause 6, page 8, proposed paragraph 92EA(3)(c), line 16, omit "10 days", substitute "28 days".

The amendment to clause 4 is being put forward in order to enhance the powers the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal has to gather information and evidence in this prior notification process. We have looked for a way to make sure that there are no delays in this process. Speed is of the essence in the prior notification process. We are dealing in a commercial situation and will be in any future use of the Broadcasting Act as amended by this Bill.

Our concern has been that under the Act as it now stands the Tribunal's powers have amounted to providing the opportunity for continued delays with, at the end of that process, fines which in themselves are not particularly significant. When we think of some of the players in the present Fairfax bids exercise, sums of $1,000 per person per day and $2,000 per day per corporate body are not particularly high fines, those concerned having gone through the courts. I do not think the question is whether people will lie or avoid coming forward with evidence which the Tribunal believes they should be providing; the problem is the potential for delay.

By this amendment, if the Tribunal feels that there is a delay, it can go directly to the Federal Court for an injunction to stop the transaction. At that point the question of whether the evidence or information exists and should have been handed over will be dealt with in the Federal Court directly. We believe that this amendment is essential to strengthen the powers of the Tribunal in pre-vetting in the prior notification period. This will be an additional tool for the Tribunal to use.

The amendments to clauses 5 and 6 are related to the question of the time that the Tribunal has to pursue the gathering of information and evidence. A period of 10 days is given in the Bill. I understand the Government's position that time is of the essence in this sort of exercise. Nevertheless, by moving as we are to amend the period of 10 days to a period of 28 days, we will not make the 28-day period mandatory. If a period of 10 days is enough, then that is all that will be used and the process will then go forward to the court. We believe that we must not hamstring the Tribunal and give a possible way out to any of the organisations or individuals being investigated in this process by limiting the time available. In the corporate context, additional time may genuinely be required.

We also point out that the Trade Practices Commission is looking to this period of time for its own deliberations. Therefore, we feel that ours is a consistent approach and could be important, if not in the present situation, certainly in situations with which this legislation might deal in future. We commend our amendments to honourable senators.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The coalition supports these amendments. In relation to amendment No. 1 to clause 4, we believe that it is essential to strengthen the power of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal to conduct inquiries prior to the commencement of the formal inquiry process. In particular, in the context of those initial inquiries, it should be enabled to obtain evidence on oath. It is essentially for that reason that we support amendment No. 1.

SPEECH.PARA: We also support amendments Nos 2 and 3 to clauses 5 and 6. I come to the debate on these amendments somewhat confused. When last night I and my coalition colleagues were called by Senator Schacht to the meeting of the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, earlier than we had agreed we would attend because each of us had other commitments in the building, we were told by Senator Schacht that the Committee meeting was about to finish. We were also told that agreement had been reached between the Government and the Democrats as to the amendments which Senator Powell has now moved to clauses 5 and 6, to the effect that a period of 21 days would be substituted for 10 days.

TALK.START.PARA: —-You will concede that you weren't told that by me.

—-I concede that and will mention it in a moment. I arrived at the meeting of the Committee to find that that Committee, far from being about to finish, had not commenced. As Senator Collins has just said, he made it clear to the Committee that there had been no agreement between Senator Collins on behalf of the Government and the Democrats on the 21-day amendment and that all he had said was that he would consider the amendment. Clearly, the Opposition was misled by Senator Schacht in that regard. We regard that as highly unfortunate. Certainly, the coalition would have been satisfied with an amendment substituting a period of 21 days for 10 days. However, in view of the confusion created by Senator Schacht, we feel that we now have no option but to support the Democrats amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I am encouraged to hear that on the issue of policy the Opposition would be prepared to support 21 days instead of 28 days. In fact, I plead with Opposition members to do so now--
—-It is too late.
—-I am disappointed to hear that. I would have thought that philosophically the Opposition would be aligned with the Government. In fact, I know that to be the case.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Chapman has accurately described what I said to the Committee last night. We were prepared to consider an extension to the period of 10 days, but we wanted to try to restrict it as closely as possible. The reason that we feel strongly about this matter is that there is a legitimate public interest here to defend, but in this democracy of ours we are also talking of the right of people to deal with what is their own property. That is the reason why we want to restrict the time. The Tribunal advised the Committee last night, as Senator Chapman will acknowledge, that the period provided is certainly sufficient so far as the Tribunal is concerned for it to conduct its business. But the Government is concerned that we do not artificially or unreasonably in the public interest delay individuals from dealing from what is their own business and with what is a legitimate commercial transaction.

The difficulty with what Senator Powell is putting to us in terms of the Tribunal being able to cut down the time required is that it cannot do that. There is no power in the legislation for it to restrict the time, and that is the difficulty. It is a set statutory period of time which cannot be restricted. The ABT has no power whatever to reduce the period of time in the way that Senator Powell is suggesting.

I plead again with the Opposition not to allow its perfectly understandable aggravation with Senator Schacht--which I am prepared to say I share, if that is what I have to say to get the Opposition on side--to interfere with an important issue. The problem is that there will be many transactions that are totally legitimate in which in the public benefit where time will not be able to be shortened. There is no power for the ABT to shorten it to 10 days, 21 days or whatever.

We are concerned not to interfere unduly in the commercial rights of people to deal with their own property. The public interest has to be dealt with, but it has to justify the intrusion that we as a Government are making into the legitimate commercial interests of individuals who in the majority of cases are engaged in legitimate business enterprises. If under this amendment we set a period of 28 days--that is a period of a month--that period must stand. Under this legislation it cannot be reduced at the whim of the Tribunal. Therefore, many legitimate transactions which perhaps should not be delayed will be delayed by a month by statute.

We thought that a period of 10 days was a reasonable compromise in intruding into people's commercial interests. We are prepared to concede that that should be increased to 21 days. We consider this a matter of some importance: there should be a limit to the extent to which government can legitimately intrude into people's private business affairs.

If Opposition senators are prepared at this stage to indicate their acknowledgment that the Democrats are not correct on this and that there is any power for the Tribunal to cut it down, I would be very happy to either move now that the period be 21 days or support an Opposition amendment that the period should be 21 days. If it would assist the chamber for me to stand here for another 10 minutes and talk about broadcasting issues in general while the Opposition has a conference about this so that it accedes, I will.

The Australian Democrats are quite wrong; the period cannot be cut down. The majority of these concerns will be dealt with openly and honestly. It will be the exception, not the rule. We do not want to hold up, for a month, legitimate transactions where people deal with their own property, when that does not have to be the case. We simply ask the Opposition to again consider supporting a 21-day statutory period instead of the full month that is being proposed by the Democrats.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I want to add a point of clarification. I apologise for having had to be elsewhere. Is Senator Collins saying that the only distinction would be the number of days? He is not talking about more or less flexibility. Is that right?
—-That is correct.

—-I indicate that we would be prepared to support the 21 days in those circumstances. I understand that the Minister has indicated that what Senator Schacht had to say was thoroughly erroneous and misleading. We trust it will not happen again.
—-I say for the record that I am prepared to acknowledge all of that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-It is important that I also acknowledge that there was no deal between the Government and the Opposition on 21 days. I was as stunned as anybody else to have that reported to me. We have had a great deal of discussion with the Minister representing the Minister in the other place--with the Minister in fact--and with both Senator Alston and the shadow Minister. I do not recall 21 days being mentioned in any of those discussions. The only person I did not talk to was Senator Schacht.

SPEECH.PARA: The point I want to make is that we are dealing with transactions in which there is a concern about whether the cross-media rules which this Government has put in place, with strong support from the Australian Democrats, are being contravened. It is not a situation in which we should be looking at all haste because people's commercial operations are important and we do not want to impede them.

In the public interest, practically the only decent, useful, honourable media policy item that has been put in place by the Hawke Government, which is cross-media ownership rules, is at risk. We should certainly give the maximum time that this chamber believes is necessary to protect that piece of public interest against the interests of any commercial operator. If it is going to be 21 days, I can certainly accept that. It is certainly better now than it was in the original legislation. Irrespective of whether Senator Schacht had anything to do with it, we are very happy that we are moving at least from the 10 days even though it is not to 28 days.

TALK.START.PARA: —-As Senator Alston just indicated, the coalition will now support an amendment to make the period 21 days rather than the 28 days moved by the Australian Democrats. We acknowledge the Minister's comments with regard to the commercial realities that apply in this situation and that they should not be unduly trespassed upon. Equally, the point made by the Democrats is valid. We believe that a longer period is needed under this provision than was originally provided in the legislation. Therefore, we believe that the 21 days compromise will adequately fulfil that requirement, particularly in view of the Minister having acknowledged his concern about Senator Schacht's misrepresentation of the situation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I would like to add my views. I totally support what my colleague has said. I aimed to get to last night's meeting. I was told it was at 9 o'clock but, when I turned up at that time, I found out, without being told anything else, that it started at 8.30 p.m.

SPEECH.PARA: Motion (by Senator Collins)--by leave--agreed to:
That the order relating to the interruption of business at 12.45 p.m. be suspended to enable proceedings on this Bill to be concluded.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I appreciate the position that Senator Powell has adopted on this matter. I did not indicate to the Committee last night, as Senator Powell's staffer would know, that there was any agreement between the Democrats and the Government on this issue. To retain the fact that this is a Democrats amendment, as an amendment to amendments No. 2 and 3 of the Democrats, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment No. 2, omit ``28 days'', substitute ``21 days''.
Amendment No. 3, omit ``28 days'', substitute ``21 days''.

TALK.START.PARA: —-We will have to take the clauses separately now. The question is that amendment No. 2 be agreed to.
—-The question is that the amendment moved by Senator Collins to amendments Nos 2 and 3 be agreed to.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —-The question is that amendments Nos 2 and 3, as amended, be agreed to.

INTERJECT.PARA: Remainder of Bill--by leave--taken as a whole, and agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill (on motion by Senator Collins) read a third time.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Order! It being after 12.45 p.m., pursuant to sessional order I now call on matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I have spoken in this chamber on a number of occasions about the performance of the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) and, in particular, Senator Cook's ability to play fast and free with the facts.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable senators would recall that Senator Cook has constantly tried to assert that the living standards of Australian workers have improved under his Government. I have produced figures, based on Senator Cook's own definition of living standards, which have conclusively exposed the disgraceful record of this Labor Government in relation to the living standards of Australian workers. In particular, I have drawn attention to how the accord has significantly cut household disposable income per capita in recent years. Not only has Senator Cook's accord cut living standards but it has also cut jobs, as we now know. As a result, we now have one million Australian workers unemployed.

I remind Senator Button that these people are unemployed as a result of his Government, which, as his former Treasurer--the man he would like to be the leader of this country--has admitted, engineered and planned the recession. There is no debate about that particular issue, I would have thought. Mr Kerin said in a recent speech, reported last night from overseas--he did not have the guts to say it in Australia--that this recession we now have is the worst for 60 years. Some record for a Labor Government! What a disgrace.

I acknowledge that my colleague Senator Crane has drawn attention to the disgraceful comments of Senator Cook on Robe River. Whatever induced Senator Cook to attack one of Australia's most productive mining companies is for him to answer. We can be absolutely sure that the answer he may give ultimately will have nothing to do with Australia's national interests.

However, today I wish to draw the attention of the Senate to another example of Senator Cook's capacity to mislead this chamber. I refer to Senator Cook's comments on industrial disputes in Victoria, my home State and Senator Button's home State. These comments were made in answer to a dorothy dixer when Senator Cook referred to recent figures produced by Mr Des Moore of the Institute of Public Affairs, which is one of Australia's most eminent think tanks. For the record, I would like to quote Senator Cook's own words in this chamber on 5 September. He asserted:

Since the Hawke Labor Government came to power the rate of industrial disputation in Victoria has dropped by 72 per cent compared with that of the Fraser years. Held against a national average of a fall of 62 per cent, it can be clearly said that the rate of disputation in Victoria has fallen further than in other States.

It is certainly true that the economy in Victoria under the Kirner and Cain governments has fallen further than those of other States but, as I will show, this assertion by Senator Cook in relation to strikes is not accurate. This is a fantastic assertion which, on Senator Cook's own figures, is misleading, even if we accept his statements as an accurate measure of the true rate of industrial disputation.

Senator Cook's source for his assertion was the ABS figures on working days lost. The fact is that the rate of industrial disputation, as measured by the ABS, fell sharply in the last year of the Fraser Government, 1982-83, and the change since then has been much less than Senator Cook's figures imply. In fact, since 1982 the number of industrial disputes in Victoria has been higher in two years than in the last year of the Fraser Government. These years were 1986, when 245 working days were lost per thousand employees, and 1990, when 239 working days were lost per thousand employees. This compares with 227 days lost in the last year of the Fraser Government.

Yet Senator Cook's misrepresentation in the chamber did not stop there. Senator Cook neglected to mention that the ABS figures, which he misleadingly represented in this chamber, failed to give the full picture on the level of industrial disputes under the Hawke Government. The ABS figures do not necessarily include disputes arising from bans, limitations, picket lines, et cetera, because these disputes do not involve any measured loss of working days, although their effect on the companies involved can be quite serious.

These forms of industrial disputes have become increasingly significant in recent years as a result of the tactics the trade union movement has adopted and as a result of the important capacity of employers to resort to civil court action to deal with union intransigence and union thuggery.

When these forms of industrial disputes are taken into account, the picture of industrial disputes under the Hawke Government is much worse than even when Senator Cook's preferred measure, when accurately quoted, is used. Over the past year, these disputes, while not appearing in ABS figures, have averaged 80 per month, fully 24 per month in Victoria alone. I know that Senator Button is sensitive about these figures, and so he should be.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I am extremely sensitive about the pimples on your tongue.

—-It is his State, it is an associated government, and if I were in his shoes I would be extremely embarrassed about it. If we are speaking about pimples on tongues, I hope that Senator Cook does not put out his tongue.

SPEECH.PARA: Let me give some examples of the serious nature and extent of the disputes which Senator Cook fails to mention. The first example is the bans and other tactics used by the AMIEU which are crippling the Victorian meat industry and which have contributed to the closure of 12 abattoirs.

The second example is the bans and other tactics by the Victorian Food Preservers Union which have led to a decline in investment in Victoria in this important industry, as Senator Button will know from his constituents. The third example is the frequent failure of Victorian train services to run because of disputes over what is euphemistically called `award restructuring'.

The next example is the bans by Victorian TAFE teachers on night classes, in connection with attempts by the Victorian Government to reduce the excessive number of teachers. The examples go on and on. I have a big list here which I can see from the clock I will not have time to read.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Good.

—-Let me mention to Senator Faulkner that just today in the Age newspaper we read that teachers are preparing to ban the VCE. The VCE was that great initiative by the Kirner Government. Remember that, Senator Button? They are planning to ban it altogether as a result of teacher disputes with the Victorian Government. Now the interesting thing is, with the examples I have mentioned, Senator Faulkner--
—-Order! Senator Kemp, I have been very tolerant. You should address your remarks through the Chair.
—-I am sorry, Mr Acting Deputy President. I will address my remarks to the Chair. Unfortunately, Senator Faulkner on the other side is calling out and I have responded to the provocation from him.

SPEECH.PARA: The interesting thing about these examples is that none of them, not one of them, would have been mentioned in the statistics that Senator Cook produces in order to demonstrate the effect of strikes on working days lost in Victoria. They are a very poor measure indeed. In conclusion, I mention just one example of a major dispute in our State which has imposed huge costs in recent times on the SEC in Victoria.

In response to the massive increase in industrial disputes hitting the SEC which saw disputes in 1989-90 total some 392 compared with an average of only 42 per year for the preceding six years, the Industrial Relations Commission was forced to introduce tough new powers to dock the pay of or stand down disputing workers.

The SECV estimated that industrial action during 1989-90 had cost it $22.6m, and during the period July 1990 to March 1991 the cost was some $30.9m. These wildcat bans, introduced by workers at the SECV, went largely unnoticed by the public. It is a new union tactic which has been very effectively used in Victoria to impose as much harm as possible on business or government enterprise, without attracting public attention.

Of course, Senator Cook's measure of industrial disputes, the massive costs borne by the SECV, which led to the strong intervention of the Industrial Relations Commission, would go unmentioned. Yet we should not assume that Senator Cook was not aware of the extent of these disputes, which the ABS figures, which he used in his statement to this Parliament, do not reveal. Indeed, Senator Cook's own Department prepares monthly reports, each called `Monthly Report of Industrial Disputes'. They are some 40 to 50 pages long and include specific reference to the kinds of disputes not measured by the ABS and certainly not quoted by Senator Cook in this Parliament.

That is 40 to 50 pages each month which Senator Cook leaves unmentioned, 40 to 50 pages which document case after case of disputes which Senator Cook would rather ignore--and little wonder. Senator Cook's explanation for leaving his Department's reports unmentioned was that those figures do not represent working days lost, which is the basis, as I have mentioned, of the ABS figures.

As I have said, the measure `working days lost' simply does not represent the full picture of industrial disputes which affect industry in this country, which affect the jobs of workers and which, ultimately, affect our living standards. When these disputes are taken into account, the record of this Labor Government--and its failed accord--is shameful. The real position is far from what Senator Cook would have this chamber and the Australian people believe.

The nature of Senator Cook's deceptions concerning the true nature of industrial disputes is twofold. Firstly, he misled this chamber by incorrectly quoting the ABS figures on the rate of industrial disputes over the life of the Hawke Government. Secondly, he failed to acknowledge that the ABS figures reveal less about the true level of industrial disputes in Australia than his Department's monthly reports.

Such deceptive bending of facts and figures by Senator Cook joins his misleading statements on living standards, his unjustified attack on Robe River Mining and his slavish adherence to the accord--an agreement which has seen nearly a million workers unemployed and which has seen the standard of living of all Australian workers fall dramatically.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Last week the Senate examined a number of documents relating to education. There was not time then to speak to all of them. One report, in particular, was of some importance and I have chosen to speak to it now, rather than under General Business. The report I am referring to is the one on Australian Research Council awards for 1991.

SPEECH.PARA: The introduction to the report includes the major policy issues facing the Australian Research Council. Today I wish to raise some of these issues. Page 5 of the report refers to the Stephen review of the Institute of Advanced Studies of the Australian National University. However, the report does not go on to provide any information about the outcome of the review. Since this has not been reported, I want to take this opportunity to inform the Senate of what has happened since the review and to tell honourable senators about the role of the Australian Research Council in relation to the Institute of Advanced Studies.

Since the beginning of the year the Government has put forward a very significant proposal to involve the Australian Research Council in the funding arrangements of the Institute of Advanced Studies. The Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) proposes that there should be a joint agreement between the ANU and the Australian Research Council on the terms of reference and membership of committees that will review the individual research schools of the ANU and the Institute of Advanced Studies as a whole.

The ANU was strongly opposed to the ARC involvement and argued that all members of the committee should be independent and of internationally recognised academic and scholarly status. After a lengthy exchange of correspondence between the ANU and the Government, Minister Baldwin wrote to the ANU on 15 August setting out the final statement of the Government's position on the future of the Institute of Advanced Studies. He said:
I do not resile from my belief that the ARC is the most appropriate body to provide advice to the Government on the allocation of funds to the Institute of Advanced Studies.

In response to this letter, the Institute passed a resolution on 5 September to the effect that it continued to hold the view that the arrangements proposed by the Minister were against the best interests of research in Australia. It stressed that the Institute would continue to be managed and controlled within the university, as required by the Australian National University Act. The Institute also expressed the view that it regarded the university's position on review procedures for the Institute to be better than the Minister's proposals.

The Institute believes that there should be a diversity of research funding and research direction across the nation, and that was also a finding of the Stephen review. The Institute is also of the opinion that it is not appropriate for the panels proposed by the Minister to review the research schools in the Institute to make recommendations on levels of funding for each school, and that it is not appropriate for the Government's allocation of funds to the Institute to specify those individual schools. The Institute is still opposed to the Minister's statement that there should be a joint agreement between the ANU and the ARC on the terms of reference and membership of all the review panels.

At the meeting on 13 October, the ANU Council reaffirmed that it would not resile from its previous position that the ANU Council should be responsible for the reviews of individual research schools and centres of the Institute of Advanced Studies, with the participation of the Australian Research Council. There the matter rests at the moment; it is a deadlock. The Minister will not resile from his position and the ANU will not resile from its position.

It is an important issue because it is yet again another example of how this Hawke Labor Government is eroding the independence and the academic integrity of all Australian universities. There is much disquiet in the academic community about the loss of independence and the loss of funding in real terms, especially for research. There have been constant warnings from our universities about the detrimental effects of reduction in research funding, particularly for university research infrastructure, which is one of the outcomes of the centralisation in the hands of the ARC.

The Pro-Vice-Chancellors Committee issued a statement last month expressing concern about the ability of universities to maintain the nation's research performance unless further infrastructure funding is provided to individual universities. The Chairman of the Committee, Professor Max Neutze, issued this warning:
Australian research cannot keep up with its international competitors and train postgraduates for the twenty-first century if it has to be carried out on outmoded equipment.

I will keep the Senate informed of the progress of the impasse between Mr Baldwin and the Australian National University. It is in all our interests that research in Australia be independent and be of the highest possible standard. This has to happen if we are to achieve the clever country or, more importantly, urgent needed research to solve important world problems.
