(2) That intervening business be postponed till after the consideration of Government Business orders of the day No. 8 (Family Law Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991) and No. 3 (Arts, Sport, Environment, Tourism and Territories Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1991).
(3) That this order have effect till 2 p.m. this day.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 16 October, on motion by Senator McMullan:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The coalition is not opposing the Family Law Amendment Bill (No. 2). The legislation to increase the retiring age of the Family Court judges from the present 65 to 70 years of age is the first of what I hope are to be many positive results of the Joint Select Committee on Certain Aspects of the Operation and Interpretation of the Family Law Act.

SPEECH.PARA: The Joint Committee was established pursuant to a motion of the Opposition on 13 March of this year and we actually took on board the suggestion by the Attorney-General of Western Australia that we first looked at retiring ages of judges. It was our understanding that a Western Australian Family Court judge was approaching his sixty-fifth birthday, hence the necessity to deal with this expeditiously.

The Committee formed the view that in light of evidence that showed the inconsistency in the present legislation regarding retiring ages and the increased community preference for fixing no retiring age for any occupation, and given that the retiring age of judges for other courts was 70 years, there was no good purpose to be served in remaining with the notional 65 years. A referendum at the last Federal election also endorsed increasing retiring ages of judges from 65 to 70, so in many respects this legislation is merely enacting the community's wishes.

Some submissions made to me prior to the establishment of this Committee complained that the courts were out of touch with the community, that judges were too old to identify with the problems of young families and that the Family Court judges ought to be more in tune with the modern Australian society and more flexible in their judgments. It was suggested that this could only occur if Family Court judges were younger. Strangely enough, the older I get, the less inclined I am to accept that view.

There is probably no right age for any individual to retire, and equally there is no appropriate minimum or maximum age at which one is suitably qualified to sit in judgment on family disputes. Clearly, it is expected that Family Court judges have sufficient experience to be able to determine with some authority the legal and moral merits of the arguments put to them, but people also want to feel that those same judges have some understanding of families and the difficulties involved in raising children. What fixed age can be applied? Is it when somebody is too young to know or too old to care?

The Committee took the view that an important qualification for judges of the Family Court was their awareness of social values. The Family Law Council said in evidence that there would not be a substantial difference in this area between judges who were 65 and judges who were 70. The previous legislation did not preclude any judge from retiring before 65 or 70, or indeed at any age, if they wanted to for any reason; many have. Some have been appointed at 41 and have retired at 43. Others have retired at 44, 55, 59, 60 and 65 years of age. Presently in the Family Court there are 17 Family Court judges with life tenure and 34 with a tenure to 65 years. Of those judges appointed for life some have already chosen to retire. They have retired at the ages of 44, 54, 60 and 65, for a variety of reasons.

From among those who are opposed to increasing the retiring age it was put to the Committee that if the retiring age were increased, it would increase the risk of judges staying too long and remaining past their prime. However, the Committee came to the view that `there is no reason to assume that judges of the Family Court have a diminished capacity to make a sound decision after age 65 when all other Federal Court judges are considered competent to adjudicate up to age 70'. That, frankly, is the only reason that needs to be put in justification of this legislation and in support of the recommendation proposed by the Select Committee. If we allow High Court judges and Supreme Court judges to continue until age 70 on the presumption that they are mentally competent to do so, then it must follow that the Family Court judges are equally competent, given that some have commissions in both courts.

Let me say in summing up that to be consistent, especially with the Federal Court, particularly as some judges hold commissions in both those courts, to make optimum use of the skills and abilities of current judges, to prevent the loss of human capital, to have the potential to save taxpayers' funds, and to encourage the development of consistent principles and guidelines through precedents, the Opposition supports this amending Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-in reply--I appreciate Senator Brownhill's support for the legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Motion (by Senator Richardson) agreed to:
That consideration of the committee stage be deferred to a later hour this day.

DEBATE.TITLE: ARTS, SPORT, ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 22 August, on motion by Senator Tate:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I commend the Government for its very sensible decision to agree with the amendments we have proposed, particularly the one that gets rid of age discrimination. Senator Patterson, Senator Chapman and I have been expressing some concern about that for quite some time. The Senate is aware of the fact that to try to get rid of age discrimination in some of the Government's organisations, in the boards of some statutory bodies, we have even put up private members' Bills--for example, for the National Maritime Museum.
—-And had them knocked back.
—-And, as Senator Patterson says, had them rejected by the Labor Party, supported by the Australian Democrats. Our aim was to get rid of the age limit of 65 that exists in some governmental bodies.

SPEECH.PARA: The reasons given by the Government for rejecting our endeavours, over something like the last 12 months, to get rid of this age discrimination, have been, on the face of it, quite sensible. The Government said it was having a look at the whole issue and that, for example, it had to work out how to resolve the problem of compensation in the event of injury because Workcover does not cover people over 65.

I must say that all through this debate the Opposition has taken the view that, while that is a coherent response, it is not an adequate one. The Opposition took the view that the Government's decision to review the whole problem, and not to do anything about it until it had been reviewed, was not the correct way to go, particularly as there were many governmental bodies which did not have that age limitation. For example, the Australian National Gallery had Mr Whitlam as its Chairman when Mr Whitlam was in his seventies. That was not an isolated instance. There were many other instances of governmental organisations where there was no age limit and where, in fact, remarkably significant contributions were made by people over the age of 65.

We were particularly concerned about the National Maritime Museum. If one could think of any one structure that would probably benefit from people aged over 65, it would be the National Maritime Museum, through being able to have on its board retired mariners who, one would have thought, might have known what the subject was all about.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Ancient mariners!

—-Senator Patterson says that there would even be some merit in having ancient mariners on that board. Unfortunately, this Government not only stoppeth one in three, it stoppeth all of them. The Government decided that in all the legislation it introduced it would maintain that age restriction rather than saying, `For those that are already there we will leave things as they are until we correct the situation'. But for all new ones surely the Government should have recognised the anomaly and allowed the provision to go through.

SPEECH.PARA: I was very depressed indeed that the Australian Democrats, in their naivety, accepted the Government's word that this matter would be resolved with great speed. I think the promise was made that early in the new year--that is, early this year--the matter would be resolved, because it had been referred to the Attorney-General's Department. It might be a charming trait of some members of the Democrats that they actually believe what the Government says. Senator Bourne remembers our discussions in the committee only too well. The cynics and the hardheads like me took the view that they would rather see this situation resolved with each new piece of legislation rather than wait for the eventual navel gazing of the Government to result in some successful outcome.

The reason that the Government's case did not stand up was a very simple one. There was, and there is, an opportunity for the Government to resolve this problem of lack of Comcare cover out of the capacity of the Audit Act to make discretionary payments. If any such problem arose there would have been absolutely no difficulty in meeting it in that way. I am not suggesting that it would have been a sensible idea to change all boards so that they would have to be covered by the Audit Act at the time. All I am suggesting is that every new organisation that is set up surely should be allowed to be on the same basis as several of the existing ones--such as the Australian National Gallery--so that there would be no problem of an ageist nature, particularly in those organisations such as the National Maritime Museum where there was clearly a need for people over the age of 65 to be given the opportunity to contribute.

However, I do not want to delay the chamber any more in the second reading debate. I would like to move now into the committee stage. I will ask Senator Chapman, who in fact first raised this matter over a year ago, to move the Opposition amendment relating to the removal of the age discrimination portion of the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Democrats have no problems with the matters in the Arts, Sport, Environment, Tourism and Territories Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2). One of the Bill's most important features is the implementation of the Government's decision that the Remuneration Tribunal should have jurisdiction over the recreation leave entitlements of full time office-holders on a number of statutory authorities.

SPEECH.PARA: There are a number of other important amendments contained in the Bill, such as raising the limit to $250,000 for which those statutory authorities mentioned need to obtain a ministerial approval before proceeding on contracts and other transactions. I note that in the case of the Australian Film, Television and Radio School this limit has not been changed since 1973, so an amendment in this instance is well and truly overdue.

In addition, the Bill increases to $20,000 the value of materials that the Australian National Maritime Museum and the National Museum of Australia may dispose of without the necessity of obtaining ministerial approval. As with other amendments contained in the Bill, the need for many of these changes has obviously come about because of inflation and the increased cost in carrying out certain functions.

In relation to the amendments circulated in the name of Senator Baume, the Democrats will certainly be supporting the first set of these amendments, which deal with the removal of age limits for those serving on these organisations.

The Government has also introduced a similar package of amendments which incorporate this ideal into the relevant legislation and, on that basis, they deserve to be commended. But one wonders whether the constant promptings of the Opposition and the Democrats on the issue of age discrimination in Commonwealth legislation have not forced the Government to respond by introducing their own amendments at this late stage.

There has been an obvious need to remove age discrimination clauses from Commonwealth legislation for some time, after the Comcare legislation was changed, and the Parliament should be acting on this matter as a matter of social right.

As the Senate will recall, the issue of age limits and age discrimination has come up previously several times in debate. Since late last year, in fact, the Government conceded the necessity to examine this matter with a view to removing the age limit requirements from all Commonwealth legislation following debate on the National Maritime Museum a year ago. Unfortunately, the Government seems to have moved quite slowly on this matter despite numerous promptings from both Democrat and Opposition speakers, who have expressed a genuine and ongoing concern over the discriminatory implications of maintaining the legislation. Perhaps the Minister could let us know when he expects the results of the Government's review of age discrimination in legislation to be available. Indeed, it seems clear that all State governments also need to accept the realities of this issue and act positively to remove age discriminations in all existing legislation.

The second set of amendments moved by Senator Baume today aims to reduce the financial limit under which a number of organisations mentioned may enter into contracts without ministerial approval. Senator Baume has argued that these increases to a new limit of $250,000 are not really justified and that a limit of only $200,000 would be more appropriate. But given that a number of these organisations and statutory authorities are already well and truly exceeding the financial limits as set by legislation, it is difficult to see how a lower $200,000 financial limit could be of benefit. We do not believe that a difference of $50,000 is particularly significant in this case.

As the Senate may be aware, the Auditor-General has expressed concern in a number of reports that some of these authorities are already breaching the financial limit that applies. This would seem to argue in favour of a higher financial limit, given the magnitude of the operations of some of these authorities.

While we would be concerned at the notion that ministerial approval of any additional expenditure be raised to a level which is excessively high, we understand that many of these authorities engage in activities and operations which should allow them some flexibility. Under the circumstances, the Democrats will not be supporting those amendments.

On the matter of the Opposition's third set of amendments to this Bill, I must admit that we have given some consideration to those matters. We recognise the case that Senator Baume has mounted and, certainly, it has been disturbing in recent times that charges have been laid against some prominent Australians who are serving on various government boards and commissions. In the end, however, we must fall back on the basic legal principle that a person is innocent until proven guilty.

The implications of adopting such an amendment are really quite unpleasant in a social sense and fraught with a number of administrative problems in a practical sense. For instance, how would people be treated if they are suspended because criminal charges have been levelled against them and their term of service on the board expires while those charges are still pending? Would they lose their position on the new board? What if they are found to be not guilty? Does that mean that they will have their position on the board or commission returned to them? There are obvious practical difficulties.

A case might be made for a board member to be stood down if the criminal charges relate to the carrying out of duties for the commission on which the member serves, but that is a totally separate concept and one for which we believe a rather convincing case could be made if it were required.
However, the amendments which the Opposition has moved today go considerably beyond that idea. As I have already explained, they are amendments which we are unable to support.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-in reply--I am asked by Senator Bourne how long it will be before the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) comes up with a comprehensive policy on age discrimination. As Senator Baume reminded us, I was told that this matter would be completed some six months ago, or even longer, but my understanding is that the day of completion is not at hand. I think that considerable difficulties have been discovered in dealing with other departments because the age discrimination legislation has considerable cost implications. I also understand that there have been some discussions, and difficulties as well, with the States. So unfortunately I am not in a position to make the confident assertion I made last time and which was wrong. Rather than repeat the mistake, I can only say that I will urge upon the Attorney-General that the matter be dealt with as swiftly as possible; but I must admit I am not becoming very hopeful.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government amendments will probably be dealt with first, but whether they are Government or Opposition amendments does not matter much. The point is that we are dealing with all the authorities in one go, as I said we should do the last time we debated this. I think that is a more sensible way of doing business.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Clauses 1 to 3--by leave--taken together and agreed to.
Schedule.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Schedule, page 3, before proposed amendment to section 12 of the Australia Council Act 1975, insert the following amendment:
"Subsection 11(4A):
Omit the subsection.".

This amendment has been circulated on behalf of the Opposition as the first of a number of amendments that we wish to move to this legislation to remove age discrimination from various bodies covered by the legislation. This follows up amendments which I, in particular, sought to move more than 12 months ago in the committee stage of legislation relating to the establishment of the National Maritime Museum.

Incorporated into that legislation were clear instances of age discrimination regarding the council established under it. Members of the Opposition regard it as totally unsatisfactory that a person should be excluded on the basis of age from serving on the councils of the various bodies and statutory authorities that are affected by this particular legislation.

It is entirely unacceptable to exclude someone who has reached the age of 65 years, or whatever, from appointment as a member of a council, whether it is the Australia Council, as is the case with the amendment that we are dealing with now, or the other bodies for which we will move amendments later. People in the community who have reached that age often have particular expertise which they can provide to advisory bodies such as these councils. We ought to be seeking the opportunity for that expertise and input to be provided to these organisations. Rather than seeking to exclude these people, we should be encouraging them to be involved in that way.

The legislation that we dealt with over 12 months ago relating to the National Maritime Museum was referred to the Standing Committee on Environment, Recreation and the Arts, acting as a legislation committee, for consideration of these and other matters. We heard all sorts of nonsense from the Minister for Social Security, who is also in charge of this Bill today, about reasons why we should not remove age discrimination.

The Minister told us that the Attorney-General's Department was investigating this matter and that it would come up with a comprehensive program for the removal of age discrimination. We were told that we ought to wait for that, rather than doing it on a piecemeal basis. When I subsequently asked representatives of the Attorney-General's Department about that in the Estimates Committee, they had to admit that they were not doing any work on it at all and that they could not advise when those amendments might be forthcoming.

It is, as I said, unacceptable to us that people should be excluded from filling these positions simply because they have reached a certain age. It has long been the policy of the coalition to remove age discrimination, as it has been policy to remove other forms of discrimination. It is on that basis that we believe that this and the other amendments with regard to age discrimination which I will subsequently move should be accepted.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Would it suit the convenience of the Senate if Opposition amendments Nos 5, 7, 11 and 14 were all moved together?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Those amendments are virtually the same as Government amendments Nos 1, 2 and, I think, 3 and 4. The difficulty is that the Government amendments will be dealt with first. But we will all take credit for it in the end. Procedurally, that is just what happens. It is not my doing anything cute. That is just the way the chamber works. However, we are opposed to the amendment which is moved by Senator Chapman.

SPEECH.PARA: We will support the other amendments for the reason that we agree that, where we have people sitting on boards of all these bodies, it is appropriate that there be no age discrimination. The difficulty is when we get to executive positions. In the case of this one we are talking about a full time chairperson. Of course, on the role of executive chairman the Government has another view. Whilst I will be moving Government amendments to remove discrimination on all the boards, we do not agree with executive positions being included.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Australia Council, for example, does not have a full time executive chairman. I think the chairman receives $21,000 a year only. Although there was some discussion at one stage about possibly having a full time executive chairman, that proposal was hit on the head. I cannot see that there is any difficulty in this particular case.

SPEECH.PARA: Progress reported.

Bill agreed to.

DEBATE.TITLE: ARTS, SPORT, ENVIRONMENT, TOURISM AND TERRITORIES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Committee is considering the amendment moved by Senator Chapman to the schedule, Opposition amendment No. 1. The question is that the amendment be agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —-In his remarks a few moments ago the Minister indicated opposition to our amendments as far as they related to executive officers of these bodies. I do not accept his objections to that because within the Public Service Act there is a provision for full time permanent public servants to have their terms of employment extended beyond the age of 65 years at the discretion of their senior officers and that has been in place for quite some time.

SPEECH.PARA: The executive officers of the Australia Council, the National Maritime Museum, the Film, Television and Radio School and the other bodies that we are dealing with in this legislation should not be denied a similar opportunity if it is determined that there is value to be gained by those organisations in their continuing in office beyond the age of 65 years. That opportunity to continue should be provided in the legislation and those officers should not be excluded from doing so. That is why our amendments relate not only to members of the councils and advisory boards of these organisations but also to the executive officers of those organisations so that they are placed in the same position as public servants.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The difficulty is that whilst that provision exists for public servants it has almost never been used, and in this case we are legislating not for some exceptional circumstance but for anyone. So it seems to me that there is a clear difference between the two positions. If you were going to--
—-So someone like Sir Ninian Stephen--
—-I am sorry, I did not hear that. One has a real difficulty if one legislates here for full time people to have no age limit upon them. The Government cannot accept that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Whatever the merits of the case--and it is an arguable one; the Minister has made a point about it rarely being used if ever, and Senator Patterson is saying there are some very distinguished Australians who make--
—-There are very distinguished people serving on committees now.
—-Yes, but serving on committees is different.
—-All of them are intact and able to contribute--

—-Senator Richardson's point is in terms of executive positions. Often the Commonwealth has appointed people as executive chairmen of bodies--such as the Bicentennial Authority. After all, the Government may well have thought that someone over 65, such as a person who was retired from business, may have been the appropriate person to appoint. As things stand, that person would be precluded from taking that role.

SPEECH.PARA: The merit stands with our side of the argument but I do not believe we should press it. The Government is now aware of our view that it should move in this direction. I would hope that our strong views on this would be taken into account in that review of the general question, about which I notice that the Minister is now being very cautious in giving an indication of anticipated resolution.

In that case, we would withdraw our amendment No. 13, for example, which deals with the executive director of the National Maritime Museum. But that is why I had, in fact, only listed amendments Nos 5, 7, 11 and 14, which do exactly what the Minister has said he wants them to do, which is remove the age discrimination from non-executive directors, while we reserve our rights on the merit of the position that Senator Chapman and Senator Patterson have stressed.

This process started over a year ago and we originally moved these amendments individually and then as a group and that is why we feel that there is great merit in acknowledging that they are our amendments, and they should proceed.
Amendment negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —-This is the first amendment of Senator Chapman's regarding the permanent full time position. Is that correct?

—-Opposition amendment No. 1 is the one that deals with the chairperson's job at the Australia Council. Then Opposition amendment No. 5 and a series after that are the same as Government amendments Nos 1 to 4.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Yes, the Minister is quite right, we included that one because in fact there is no full time executive chairman of the Australia Council.
—-But there can be.

—-There can be, but there is not. The consequence of the Government defeating this amendment would be that all other non-executive members of the Board of the Australia Council could be over 65 but the Chairman of the Australia Council could not be over 65. That does not seem to me to be a rational way of approaching it. I would not go to the barricades over it, but it seems to me not a sensible way to proceed, particularly when there is no full time executive chairman of the Australia Council. There is in fact a Chairman who, as I understand it, is paid only some $21,000 a year. I do not think we should pass legislation which disadvantages a Chairman in the present position in the event that there may possibly be a change of government policy to create a full time position of executive chairman.

SPEECH.PARA: Motion (by Senator Richardson) agreed to:
That discussion of Senator Chapman's amendment be postponed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —-by leave--I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Schedule, page 3, after proposed amendment to subparagraph 14 (2) (b) (ii) of the Australia Council Act 1975, insert the following amendment:
"Section 14:
Add at the end:
`(4) The Council may suspend any member charged by the Crown with an offence punishable by 12 months' imprisonment.
`(5) If the member is not convicted of that offence, the Council must terminate the suspension.
`(6) If a suspension is terminated, the rights, privileges and seniority of the member continue as if the suspension had not occurred.
`(7) If the member is convicted of that offence, the Council must terminate the appointment of that member.'.".
Schedule, page 3, after proposed amendment to subparagraph 14 (2) (b) (ii) of the Australia Council Act 1975, insert the following amendment:
"Subsection 19B (2):
Omit the subsection.".
Schedule, page 3, proposed amendment to paragraph 34 (1) (a) of the Australia Council Act 1975, omit the amendment, substitute:
"Paragraph 34 (1) (a):

I have heard the Australian Democrats' quite proper expression of concern about the consequences of these amendments. Their view is that the amendments would have the effect of judging someone guilty unless proved innocent rather than the other way around. We do not take that view. We take the view that in public office there is a particular requirement, which is met by politicians, who are required to stand aside when they are under any challenge or threat of a legal nature. As I understand it, even the former Premier of New South Wales stood aside while an investigation took place. He was found to be totally innocent and was reinstated. It is a convention among politicians.

It seems to me that there should be some convention among members of boards. The Australian Democrats do not feel that this is an appropriate convention. We think that there should be particular standards of propriety and appropriate conventions for people in these positions, particularly as we have seen some people who had been members of boards charged with very serious offences.

The one case that perhaps prompted this was not so serious, and in fact the charges were withdrawn in the one case immediately prior to this matter. But our view simply is that, if it is good enough for politicians to be expected to stand aside, we should establish some rules for members of government authorities pending the outcome of their case, with reinstatement and all rights being restored in the event of their not being found guilty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I understand Senator Baume's position, because he raised a question about a member of the Tourist Commission board who had had charges laid against him. I would have thought the fact that the charges were later withdrawn tends to bear out what the Government believes and what the Democrats believe. Had we acceded to the views of people, including Senator Baume, who thought that the person should stand aside, I think that there would have been some sort of black mark against the person in those circumstances. That person had the charges withdrawn a few weeks later, so I think we would have been taking action against him very unfairly. In fact, it is that case that leads me to believe that the Government is correct in rejecting the amendments.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments negatived.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I am prepared to allow the Opposition to move its amendments. I am in a generous mood today so I will bow to the Opposition.
—-Senator Baume, do you seek leave to move amendments 5, 7, 11 and 14 en bloc?
—-Yes.

—-If it is of assistance to you, amendments 5, 7, 11 and 14 are the equivalents of amendments 1, 2, 3 and 4 to be moved by the Government. The Minister has kindly conceded and said that the Opposition could go first.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Amendments Nos 5, 7, 11 and 14, which have been circulated on behalf of the Opposition, relate, as did amendment No. 1, to the matter of age discrimination as far as appointments to councils and advisory bodies are concerned, particularly with regard to the various bodies being dealt with in this legislation, including the Australian National Maritime Museum, the Australian Film Commission and the Australian Sports Commission. Arguments have already been put quite adequately in relation to the reasons why age discrimination should be removed from appointments to the councils and advisory bodies for these organisations.

SPEECH.PARA: As I said earlier, in principle they were put more than 12 months ago, when we were dealing specifically with legislation relating to the Australian National Maritime Museum. The Government would not accept our amendments at that time, for reasons which we did not accept as justifiable. The Government refused to accept our amendments. We believe that the amendments to legislation should have been dealt with as particular pieces of legislation came up that dealt with these bodies. We now welcome the fact that the Government has agreed to accept the amendments that we seek to have placed into this legislation so that we can gain the expertise of people who are over the age of 65 on the advisory bodies relating to these organisations. It is in that context I seek leave to move this block of amendments and urge their support in the Committee.
Leave granted.
