TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: -Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —-by leave--I inform the Senate that the Minister for Defence, Senator Robert Ray, will be absent from the chamber today. Senator Ray is overseas on Government business. Any questions which would normally be directed to Senator Ray in relation to his portfolio should be directed to Senator Richardson.
—-I direct my question to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Are we in our most severe recession for 60 years?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I have seen reference in the newspaper to comments on this matter by the Treasurer, Mr Kerin. I cannot say what the basis of his comparison is. Perhaps it is related more to particular difficulties faced by sections of the rural community at this time than on previous occasions. The question of whether this recession is worse than the previous one is not entirely relevant, although comparisons will always be made.

ANSWER.PARA: On some indicators, such as employment, the situation now is obviously serious; however, the evidence is mixed. For example, the participation rate is quite different from that which it was at the time of the previous recession. The 1982-83 recession was a greater problem for the economy in that regard. In 1982-83, we had the double whammy of inflation and unemployment, which left the economy structurally weak.

TALK.START.PARA: —-And a drought, and a world recession!

—-There is a recession now in all the Anglo-Saxon speaking countries. If Senator Kemp does not want to recognise that fact, perhaps he should start recognising it. There are a few facts that Senator Kemp has to recognise which he has sought to ignore in the past day or two. The important question is how we come out of the recession. The shadow Treasurer was gracious enough to point out this morning that picking the worst amongst a number of recessions over a very long time scale is something of an academic debate; Mr Reith said that on the AM program this morning.

ANSWER.PARA: As I have said before, the unemployment situation is bad. At the present time, there are clear gains on the inflation front, the trade front and the fiscal policy front. These improvements allow us to reasonably expect a stronger, more structurally sound economy in the 1990s compared with what was left to us at the beginning of the 1980s.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Mr Acting President, I ask a supplementary question. Why has not the Prime Minister, the Treasurer, Senator Button or any other member of the Government been prepared to say publicly, in response to the innumerable times the coalition has asked the Government this question over the past 12 months, that we do face and we are in the most severe recession in 60 years--instead, it has been left to the Treasurer to admit it from thousands of kilometres outside Australia--or do I take it from the Minister's answer that he is yet again publicly disagreeing with one of his senior Cabinet colleagues?
—-You're causing some trouble!

—-I am going to cause some trouble for Senator Boswell later. In terms of any disagreement with the Treasurer, the Minister for Finance, who is Acting Treasurer this week, will give an answer about that in the House of Representatives and Senator Short can look at it in Hansard. That will be something for him to do over the two-week break.
—-We'll have four versions by the end of the week.
—-I am afraid that will not be the case. I am sorry to disappoint Senator Short. Senator Short asked why we have not publicly agreed with the Opposition over this issue.
—-Why have you not said it publicly in Australia in the last 12 months?
—-We have not done that largely for the reasons articulated by the shadow Treasurer in the radio program this morning.

—-I address my question to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. I draw the Minister's attention to the fact that consumers are now well aware of the damage being caused to the environment by some products and are looking for environmentally friendly products when they make purchases. Can the Minister inform the Senate what is being done to assist consumers in their effort to use their purchasing power in the marketplace to benefit the environment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I am very delighted with the action of Grocery Manufacturers of Australia in publishing yesterday a code that will regulate throughout Australia this $30 billion industry which puts all those grocery items on our supermarket shelves. By self-regulation, they are ensuring that shoppers and customers, as they go down those alleyways of supermarket shelves making their purchases, will be assisted in making a purchase which helps the environment and lessens the damaging impact on the environment.

ANSWER.PARA: The consumers, the shoppers of Australia, do want to use their dollars in order to protect the environment if possible: if they are faced with a choice, they will go for the item which is in some way environmentally friendly. There is no doubt that there is also a certain cynicism or scepticism amongst shoppers that some of the claims that are made are too broad, rather outrageous and quite clearly advertising hype rather than conveying real information about how a particular aspect of a product--its manufacture, the way it is packaged, the way in which the package can be disposed of, or the product itself--actually helps the environment. The information which is provided ought to be absolutely clear and justifiable and defensible. This is what the grocery manufacturers have attempted to do with their code. For that reason, yesterday at Woolworths in Belconnen, I was very pleased to launch their code.

At the end of the day, the Government also has in its armoury, under the Trade Practices Act, a provision which provides a $100,000 fine for those who engage in misleading or deceptive advertising. If there is an attempt to deceive the public into buying a product under the guise that it is environmentally friendly to do so, and it turns out that that claim cannot be justified, the Trade Practices Commission has, under this Budget, been given extra resources to investigate those situations and, if necessary, prosecute to the point of a successful conviction and the imposition of a fine of that order.

Most honourable senators would consider it far better that the industry regulate itself in this regard. I believe that supermarket shoppers, as a result of this code, can be more confident in the purchases they make with their dollars of enhancing the quality of our environment rather than having a disastrous impact on it.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I direct my question to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Does the Minister agree with the Secretary of the ACTU, Mr Bill Kelty, that interest rates should be dropped by one per cent immediately?
—-I answered this question last week. I am always inclined not to speculate about interest rates. The best answer I can give to that question--because Senator Reid used the word `immediately'--is no.

—-I direct my question, which concerns forest initiatives of this Commonwealth Government, to the Minister representing the Minister for Resources. What is the Government doing to facilitate the development of ecologically sustainable, internationally competitive forest industries?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Government is committed to the development of a national forest policy by the end of 1992 aimed at providing a national framework for forest use. We cannot, of course, underestimate the importance of this policy. It will mean that, for the first time since Federation, Australia will have a national policy on one of the more controversial areas of public policy in this country--the conservation and judicious use of Australia's forests.

ANSWER.PARA: The policy is anticipated to encompass a number of themes: environmental protection; facilitating value added investments; employment generation; and community awareness of forest science and ecology. Importantly, the policy will draw together the outcomes of the Government's other forest policy initiatives, of which there are many, including: resource security; the Resource Assessment Commission's inquiry into the use of Australia's forest resources; the ecologically sustainable development working group on forest use; the national plantation strategy; endangered species and biodiversity programs; award restructuring; workplace reform; training; occupational health and safety; the review of forest taxation; the review of wood pricing; and the adoption of legislatively based codes of forest practice for public and privately owned forest. There are many other elements in that list, including a national forest inventory.

With the above initiatives in mind, the Government's vision for the forest industries for the year 2000 builds on the measures taken so far. Our objective is to steer a path consistent with our environmental agenda and to create a better and more productive industry, that is, an industry which can become the base for a sophisticated paper making industry in the future, providing more jobs for Australians and more prosperity for our nation. It is, in short, a clever industry.

The Government is absolutely committed to ensuring that this renewable industry is conducted in a way consistent with this Government's respect for and protection of our shared environment. I am confident that this policy framework will help facilitate the resolution of forestry issues in a transparent and predictable way and without the level of discord that has characterised the forests debate in the past.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. Now that the New South Wales Government has declared the Solitary Islands a marine reserve, can the Minister confirm that the Government will declare the adjacent Commonwealth waters as a complementary marine reserve and, if so, when will this declaration occur? Will the Minister confirm that oil exploration and development will not be permitted within this marine reserve as with the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park?
—-I am afraid that I do not have any information in the DASETT folder on that question. I will seek the information from the Minister and try to get back to the honourable senator as soon as I can.

—-Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Given that the Minister is going to provide a more complete answer, perhaps he could address himself to this additional question. Given that the delay in declaring the reserve has the potential to set an important precedent in this matter and especially that offshore oil development would be allowed in Commonwealth marine reserves, can the Minister confirm that the Department of Primary Industries and Energy views the situation as a test case for the Government's announced plans to establish a national marine reserve strategy which is being developed under Ocean Rescue 2000?
—-Again, I will endeavour to get an answer to Senator Bell's question.

—-I address my question to the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs. The Minister will be aware of the terrible massacre in Texas this morning. Can the Minister give an assurance that the Australian Police Ministers Council and Special Premiers Conference will agree on urgent steps to prevent Australia experiencing such gun-ridden violence which, sadly, is so characteristic of the United States? Is the Minister able to ensure that the issue of criminal violence depicted in film and video, together with other aspects of the `culture of violence'--a phrase which the Minister himself coined some weeks back in answer to a question in this place--is fully examined when gun control laws are considered at the forthcoming Premiers Conference on violence?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I believe many of us were shocked to hear, on our morning news services, of the massacre in Texas. It seems that a semi-automatic pistol was used in that massacre. There have been very stringent regulations in Australia for decades governing the importing and availability of such semi-automatic hand guns. I believe that they are at a level of stringency which does not need a great deal of improvement. But it is encouraging to know that in relation to other semi-automatic weapons--certainly the military style and, I believe, all semiautomatic rifles--there is a convergence of views now between the Commonwealth and New South Wales Government which augurs well indeed for the Police Ministers Council meeting to be held in Melbourne next Wednesday leading up to the Special Premiers Conference.

ANSWER.PARA: I believe that, for the first time, the Special Premiers Conference will be able to put in place nationwide proposals to deal with gun control which will have the support of the Australia-wide community, without reference to the petty divisions which sometimes can cause jealousies and turf disputes between States in matters as important as the availability of these lethal weapons in our community. Senator Reynolds is quite right to point to the need to deal with other elements in our culture. One could refer to the question of domestic violence, which is a euphemism and misnomer for criminal violence in the home. I believe that the women's refuge movement initially, and governments latterly, with their various programs, have brought that problem to the forefront of the consciousness of Australians. I believe that is an area in our culture which certainly needs continual addressing, as does the question of child abuse.

One could also refer to violence on the sporting field. In recent weeks, for instance, the South Australian football grand final, a soccer grand final in Sydney and also the grand final in Tasmania were marred by terrible violence. Once again, one has to look at violence on the playing field as containing elements of criminal assault which need to be dealt with as such.

TALK.START.PARA: —-On videos too.

—-To come to the question of films and videos, which Senator Reynolds raised, it is true that once again there needs to be a stringent application of the various criteria relating to the classification of videos and films in circulation around Australia. I believe that limits on what sort of violence can be portrayed in films and videos in Australia are already reasonably categorised so that excessive violence, explicit or unjustifiable depictions of violence associated with sexual activity and violent scenes which are relished or cruel are already denied or refused classification. But I do not think that censorship Ministers have been altogether happy with some of the applications of those criteria.

ANSWER.PARA: Indeed, as recently as the meeting of the censorship Ministers in July of this year considering the film Silence of the Lambs--and I must say that I thoroughly enjoyed it as a film--I believe that the Ministers indicated that there could be a more stringent examination of the appropriate classification for films to ensure that violent films are not necessarily available for general viewing.

In short, I believe that the Special Premiers Conference will be well placed to deal with the whole question of violence in our community, not only in relation to the question of gun control but also in relation to the whole social underpinning of our culture. I believe that this will help prevent that slide into the gun-ridden violence which, as Senator Reynolds says, characterises much of United States society.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I refer the Minister for Industrial Relations to his answers to questions on 5, 9, 10 and 11 September in relation to Robe River. Is the Minister now prepared to acknowledge that he misled the Senate, and apologise for such errors?

—-I have replied to these baseless accusations before. I have not misled the Senate. It brings the Senate itself into disrepute if honourable senators use that accusation lightly, particularly if they have not got the guts or the moral fortitude to back it up by moving a censure motion and adducing their so-called evidence for the whole of the Senate to consider. It devalues the process of censure considerably. At an appropriate time I intend to make a statement. That statement will show not only that I did not mislead the Senate but also that Senator Winston Crane did.

—-Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does Minister Cook acknowledge that he nominated 13 June 1989 as the first date on which an appeal was lodged by CLS--not Robe River--to the Commission from a case of 6 June? Does he acknowledge that, in fact, that appeal was not dismissed but withdrawn?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Senator Crane has been warned that I will make a statement which will reveal that he is, in fact, misleading this chamber. I do not intend to comment now on his accusations. I say again that the use of the word `mislead' in the context in which it has been employed by Senator Crane and by Senator Bronwyn Bishop in debate--no, I do not think it is true in Senator Panizza's case, but at least in the case of those other two--and, indeed, by Senator Kemp today in a fraudulent expose devalues the importance of the crime of misleading the Senate by making it a petty political accusation. It should be a considerable misdemeanour in the eyes of this chamber.

ANSWER.PARA: However, having said that, I say that whoever is supplying Senator Crane with his information has supplied him wrongly. It may be that they are at fault. The fact that he would choose to parrot the information that he has supplied without checking original sources is, however, a reflection on his discrimination. When I make my statement, that will be revealed.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services. It has been suggested to me by developers of modern energy efficient office space that, when seeking to lease such offices to government departments, they are advised that the main criteria applied by government departments is the cost per square metre of space. Apparently, there is no consideration given to the savings to be made over time due to substantial reductions in energy costs in such buildings. Can the Minister advise the Senate whether this reflects the Government's policy when seeking rented premises? If so, does the Minister agree that this is not only economically questionable, but it is also contrary to the Government's commitment to reduce CO2 emissions by 20 per cent by the year 2000?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Senator Devereux does, in fact, raise a question which has been under government consideration. The answer to his question, in respect to both aspects of it, is essentially no. Before I go into it in major detail, I should ask the Senate and Senator Devereux to take into account that my Department no longer has a regulatory role in relation to accommodation standards. As part of the Government's common services reforms, which were announced and introduced on 1 July 1989, individual departments and agencies have responsibility for decisions relating to their own accommodation needs. Within that context, my Department provides services to assist other departments in making their decisions, and these services are provided in a competitive environment. The departments can choose whether they take DAS services or not.

ANSWER.PARA: However, when a government department is deciding on its accommodation requirements, I think it is fair to say that it does take into account a whole range of factors of which total cost is a key factor. For instance, where the APG--the Australian Property Group of Administrative Services--is engaged to assist departments to analyse accommodation options, advice provided by us includes concepts such as full life cycle costing of occupancy. These considerations, of course, include not only rent, but also outgoings which include energy costs. We recognise that energy management is an important matter, and it is one that should be considered by government departments in their choice and use of office accommodation. Within that, we keep in mind the target of reducing CO2 emissions by 20 per cent by the year 2000.

As Senator Devereux and the Senate would know, we build buildings. We are responsible for standards in relation to buildings that we construct. In respect of those buildings, we take great consideration in achieving energy efficiency and conservation. I think there have been four instances in recent years where Commonwealth construction through DAS has had energy conservation as a target in its construction and has succeeded quite enormously in achieving the objective. The first example I can point to is in my home state of South Australia, in Adelaide. The Commonwealth Centre there had design operation concepts which included an atrium, efficient lighting through the use of programmable time switching and dimming based on occupancy and also computer-based air-conditioning operation using ambient air for cooling the building. In fact, the Adelaide building was so successful that it won the BOMA, the Building Owners and Managers Association, award for excellence in 1988. A special mention in that award was made of its overall cost effectiveness and quality of services which promoted low life cycle costs. Of course, energy is a very important aspect of life cycle costs.

In Senator Devereux's own home state, in Hobart, the Hobart Place stage 2 development includes concepts which reduce reliance on energy and make the building energy efficient. Air-conditioning is one aspect of it. High performance glazing and lighting, which once again is sensitive to demands rather than being kept on broadly through the building at all times, are also incorporated.

So energy efficiency has been a major consideration in those two buildings, in Sydney Central and also Casselden Place. Senator Devereux raises a point which is important not only in terms of an overall energy and environmental concern, but also in respect of the Government's target of 20 per cent CO2 emissions by the year 2000. It is one where I think DAS is leading by example. As I say, we have indicated by example that it is a major consideration for government.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. Firstly, does the Minister agree that the bad debt hangover of the banking sector, which is reported to be in excess of $30 billion, severely curtails its ability to provide capital for business expansion? Secondly, does the Minister agree that the new prospectus provisions in the corporations law create a further significant impediment and expense to capital raising for business expansion? Thirdly, recognising his own frank comments on Australia's uncompetitive business tax environment and the cost of capital, does the Minister agree that his Government's fiscal, monetary, taxation and corporations and securities policies have created not only a recession but also a capital crisis which will create a rolling recession and not a recovery? Finally, where does the Minister expect business will find capital to fund the investment required to create jobs for Australia's one million unemployed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I am not here to answer questions like that which might as well have simply been put in the form of `are you responsible for everything?'. The answer to that question is no. The Government is not responsible, for example, for the somewhat extraordinary lending habits of the banks during the 1980s. We are not responsible for that. We are not responsible for financial institutions which made loans to almost anybody who went into some of them on the basis of very little security or presentation of adequate business plans or anything like that. Let me make that quite clear.
—-What about Burke's policies in 1987 and 1988?

—-Senator Crichton-Browne might have got something out of it. He should not be bitter about it. It is all over now. He cannot go back with his nose in the trough again, for the reasons which I identified in Senator Campbell's question.

ANSWER.PARA: I will try to provide Senator Campbell with a more detailed answer, but there are one or two points that I can deal with directly. Senator Campbell referred to a figure of $30 billion being the estimate of non-performing debts in the banks. I have not seen that figure. I saw a figure pretty close to it. I do not think the size of the figure is the point. He asked me whether that sort of figure curtails the ability of banking institutions to provide finance. I think it would be pretty obvious that it does; of course, it does.

Secondly, he asked me whether the new prospectus provisions are an impediment because of their complexity to companies and financial institutions. Certainly, they are more complex than previous prospectus provisions and, certainly, there is a debate in the financial and business community about the contents of those provisions.

In trying to resolve some of the issues to which the honourable senator points in the first part of his question, I suspect it is certainly an improvement on the sort of situation which has prevailed previously. As far as I am concerned, some companies complain about the complexity and other companies see the provisions as a necessary thing.

The honourable senator raised the issue of what he called `uncompetitive business tax' and my alleged frank admission that we had an uncompetitive business tax system. I have made no such admission. If I had made such an admission, the honourable senator might have been able to point to it. However, what I have said is that we have from time to time reviewed business taxation and we are doing it again at the present time because, in terms of the competitiveness of the business taxation system, the whole world is changing.

Since 1988, when we introduced the lowest corporate tax rate this country had ever had, there have been corporate tax rate changes in the United Kingdom, I believe in Canada, and in certain other European countries. Historically, we have always compared ourselves with OECD countries in terms of the business tax environment. All I am saying is that it is a dynamic environment internationally and one of which we have to take account. I am not saying we have an uncompetitive tax structure; I am saying it is an issue which has to be examined constantly.

I think those were the essential parts of the honourable senator's question. He went on to ask me all sorts of questions about whether the Government admitted responsibility for everything that could be listed in his demonology. I cannot answer that part of the question, but if I have missed anything I will try to provide him with a more detailed answer in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for that response and ask him to clarify whether he perceives a capital crisis in Australia which will limit the ability of business to provide the expansion required to find jobs for one million unemployed Australians.

—-Undoubtedly, there are capital problems in Australia and they are exacerbated by capital problems throughout the world. The fact of the matter is that a capital shortage is probably developing in Europe as a result of events in eastern Europe. There are probably problems in capital markets in Japan and North America, and I agree there are capital market problems here. In so far as there is a shortage of readily available capital that is detrimental to the question of new investments which may in the longer term create wealth and then employment, the answer to that question is: yes, in the longer term.

—-My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Tourism and Territories. Can the Minister advise what promotional activity the Australian Tourist Commission is currently undertaking in the United States of America and how successful any such promotion there has been? Could the Minister also advise what indications there are that North American tourists are increasingly looking towards Australia as a preferred holiday destination? What are the economic spin-offs of increased tourist numbers from the USA?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-As I am sure Senator Maguire is aware, over the last 18 months or so there has been a drop in the number of tourists from North America, which has been a matter of concern to the industry here and, of course, to the Tourist Commission. Accordingly, the Tourist Commission recently completed the screening of what it called its `Fair Dinkum' television and print media campaign in the US which featured Greg Norman.

ANSWER.PARA: The campaign generated the largest response since the heady days of the Hogan advertisements a few years back. This response augurs well for a big increase in the number of visitors from, what is for Australia, an incredibly important market. The Norman campaign ran in major magazines from February to June and on television from 27 May to the end of June. It attracted more than 270,000 inquiries--that is, 110,000 for television and 160,000 for the print media segment. This was followed by a campaign on New York taxi cabs featuring Greg Norman, which was also very successful. It ran for five weeks from late August until September and attracted a further 72,000 responses.

There are a number of encouraging signs from this that the US visitor market is starting to pick up, given that it has been sluggish for quite some time. I think this response suggests that it will now recover strongly and the short to medium term prospects for growth are very good.

Arrivals from the US grew by 17 per cent in June. I suppose this figure cannot be taken too much at face value because there was a Lions convention in Brisbane which was very big and no doubt caused an increase that will not be reflected every month. Nonetheless, that is very significant and it is the first significant rise in the number of US visitors since before the Gulf war.

A high level of visa applications from the US over recent months also leads us to make some fairly confident predictions about the growth in the number of US visitors. In July, total visa issues in the United States were more than 75 per cent higher than in 1990, with some posts recording increases of more than 100 per cent. In August, the result was 23 per cent. They are quite phenomenal figures.

The increase in US visitor interest obviously reflects that Greg Norman campaign, as well as the extraordinary fares which are now being offered because of airline competition on the route--in particular, the addition of Northwest to the route. Obviously, the economic benefits to Australia are quite considerable. The Bureau of Tourism Research estimates that for every 26 US visitors to Australia an additional job is created in the industry. So, with an average expenditure of more than $2,050 per visit, the US market alone contributed $520m to Australia's economy last year. About half of that amount was spent on food, drink and accommodation. Although arrivals from the US to June are slightly below 1990 levels, all the information I have just imparted suggests that they will go up again, they will go up solidly and they will contribute to a deserved recovery in our tourist industry.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I direct my question to the Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for Public Service Matters. I preface my question by reminding the Minister that one year ago next Wednesday Mr Howe claimed at the launch of the Public Service Commission's disability information strategy that the declining recruitment of people with disabilities in the Australian Public Service was `totally unsatisfactory'. Mr Howe's statement was based on the fact that base grade recruitment of people with disabilities had dropped from 5.2 per cent to 3.1 per cent between 1986 and 1989. I ask the Minister whether he agrees with the Deputy Prime Minister that:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . the Government cannot accept a situation where the public service is operating in a manner that is inconsistent with the broader objectives that the Government has set for the employment of people with disabilities.
What work has the Minister done in the last 12 months to arrest and turn around this slump?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I certainly do agree with what the Deputy Prime Minister is saying, although I will make some qualifications about it.
—-Senator Button doesn't!
—-The first qualification is that those figures are better understood--
—-Poor old Senator Kemp!

—-I am sorry, Mr Acting President, I am not quite sure what the theatre of the absurd is down here in the front. The first is a point of explanation: during the period that the honourable senator has referred to the total number of Commonwealth public servants has fallen; that is to say, we have slimmed down the Public Service. Therefore, recruitment has not been as great as it might have been in ordinary years and the slimming down process has led to some distortions--one of which the honourable senator has referred to.

ANSWER.PARA: The second part of the honourable senator's question asked whether I was doing anything about it. In the first place, yes, I am concerned about it, but I am not the only Minister and I do not share this concern alone with Mr Howe. I know that Senator Richardson is concerned about it too. Indeed, all of our departments are collaborating to bring forth a submission on what steps the Public Service Commission should now take to correct the position. But I make the point that if recruitment levels are falling and the number of people in the Public Service is dropping we will get temporary distortions of this nature while the problem is being ironed out.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services. On 21 February, in response to a question from me, the Minister indignantly refuted any notion that the Commonwealth Government, in its provision of access to child-care, was constructing that access on a basis which discriminates against one-income families. Is it a fact that the current Budget imposes an inequitable fee relief system between dual-income families and one-income families which discriminates against one-income families despite income test levels being met? Is it a fact that the Budget envisaged that over the next six years there will be no growth in occasional child-care places, mainly accessed by one-income families? If those are the facts, will the Minister admit that his indignations previously displayed were misplaced? If they are not, will the Minister kindly advise the Senate in what way they are not correct?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I cannot actually recall the degree of indignation or enthusiasm with which I refuted some proposition put by Senator Harradine in relation to the provision of child-care in the Australian community. I would have, no doubt, mentioned that the Federal Government is extremely proud of its record in the provision of child-care in the community. The Government has done a tremendous amount to increase the number of child-care places available.

ANSWER.PARA: In so far as the Budget has, according to Senator Harradine, led to a shifting of emphasis in particular categories, I will examine those shifts and see whether the emphasis which is brought about by the Budget leads to the sort of characterisation which Senator Harradine wishes me to adopt from his colouring of the picture. I will undertake to do that and provide Senator Harradine with the answer, firstly, as to the facts and, secondly, as to a fair description of the situation.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. In response to my question on Monday, 14 October, the Minister said:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . if in terms of investment--
the Government--
were to have industry's preferred definition of effective life it would be highly beneficial for investment, but it would be disastrous for the revenue base of this country.

Can the Minister explain to the Senate what is the point of the Government reviewing its business taxation with the aim of encouraging investment, yet not adopting policies such as economic life depreciation which it confesses would encourage investment?

TALK.START.PARA: —-The point will be seen when the review is concluded. There has always to be a balance in legitimate protection of revenue against claims which are based on a whole range of assumptions and which are suitable to particular companies but are not fair in respect of the total tax regime. With respect to the depreciation issue which Senator Watson raised with me on the previous occasion, I will give an example of what I mean. If a company is in a position where it can nominate the effective life of a piece of equipment, perhaps at five years or 10 years, and then passes that equipment on to a subsidiary company, with no rules as to the economic life in the hands of the second user, that would be a very difficult situation open to all sorts of abuse. That is all I meant by that. Senator Watson is not in favour of encouraging abuse of the tax system, but one should not open loopholes in the tax system for abuse.
—-You did that when you lowered the company tax.

—-I thought that Senator Crichton-Browne would not have objected to the Government lowering the company tax rate. If he does object, he should put it on the record. There is a matter of striking a balance between the legitimate desire to encourage investment and the prevention of loopholes in the tax system, which would perhaps encourage investment but would also provide temptation to do other things. Senator Watson knows that perfectly well.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. I ask what the Government's response is to the comment in Monday's Australian Financial Review that Kalori, one of the bidders for the second telecommunications carrier licence:

QUESTION.PARA: . . . does not believe that the second carrier's industry development plan is important to the Government.

How can the Minister be expected to make a decision on the bidding for the second carrier network licence without being informed of a prospective purchaser's network roll out plans? When is the Minister planning to make his decision as to who will win the second carrier licence, bearing in mind that it would appear that the initial deadlines will not be met?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-When executives from Kalori were contacted by Government officials, they in fact expressed some surprise at the comments in the Australian Financial Review. Mr Beazley advises me that, in line with the schedule that was set in November last year, the Government is confident that it will be able to consider offers in November this year and make a decision on this matter before the end of the year. The Government is confident of a successful outcome to the selection process.

ANSWER.PARA: The Kalori consortium has advised the Minister that it is working intensively on the final details of its proposal. It has given every assurance that a substantive bid will be forthcoming and that the bid will outline firm innovative plans for network development to provide a comprehensive range of services. Both consortia are acutely aware that government development opportunities is one of the key selection criteria so far as the Government is concerned. These will be taken into consideration when this evaluation is made.

I can confirm that both contenders expect to be putting forward firm innovative plans for the purchase of Australian sourced equipment and export opportunities. The details must remain confidential at present, but the Minister has been advised that these plans are highly regarded by the relevant officials and hold out prospects for significant gains to Australian industry over the next decade. The consortia have also provided recent briefings for the industry in a number of States on their approach to industry development and the opportunities that will be available.

TALK.START.PARA: —-How will the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support redeem his now broken promises in his aviation portfolio, as well as for waterfront reform? Can the Minister yet advise firm operational dates for the new $20m Alice Springs Airport terminal which has been mothballed for the last two months and the new $50m Darwin Airport terminal which the Minister failed to open, as promised, on 1 October?
—-Why knock the Territory?

—-I never knock the Territory. Senator Bolkus should listen to this question. Why have the temporary demountable buildings used for security and for waiting lounges in Alice Springs been removed, throwing thousands of passengers and tourists into the gutters and car park areas and the heat and dust of central Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —-As I have indicated on previous occasions, Senator Tambling's interest in the establishment of these vitally important tourist facilities for the Northern Territory is a very latter day interest indeed. During the 10 years of blood, sweat and tears that it took to get these terminals for the Northern Territory, Senator Tambling contributed absolutely nothing. All that he has done is knock these projects, along with his colleague in the Northern Territory Mr Fred Finch, who is the Northern Territory Minister for Transport and Works.

ANSWER.PARA: The petty minded, negative, attacking approach that has been taken to these facilities by Mr Finch, who is the relevant Minister in the Northern Territory--and I am going to commend Senator Tambling in this respect--has been taken to the extreme. Despite repeated invitations from the Federal Airports Corporation to inspect the now completed magnificent facilities in both Alice Springs and Darwin, the Minister For Transport and Works in the Northern Territory is so petty minded that he has never set foot in either terminal. It is a disgrace. I hope he does not have the hide to turn up to the official opening. On the other hand, I concede that Senator Tambling has responded to these invitations and visited both facilities.

The interesting thing about the security arrangements at Alice Springs--and as the relevant Minister I have checked with my Department and the FAC--is that, so far as these temporary arrangements for security that have allegedly thrown thousands of people into the gutter are concerned, the only complaint that has been made has come from Senator Tambling.

I have been fortunate enough recently to visit again the completed Darwin terminal. Without a doubt, it will be the best terminal building in Australia. It has been a most successful design. Senator Tambling has been one of the chief critics of the artworks in the building. Could I say to him in passing--and I am throwing this out to tantalise a few people into coming to the opening--that the Aboriginal artwork Feathered Serpent, which is now in place on the wall of the main entrance of the building, is one of the most spectacular Aboriginal artworks I have ever seen. If Senator Tambling has seen it I know he will concede this. We will be opening these facilities at both Alice Springs and Darwin early in December--$100m worth of badly needed facilities for the Northern Territory.

Recently I wrote to the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, Marshall Perron, and I expect to get a positive response from him, pointing out that, along with Senator Macdonald and a number of my Senate colleagues, I recently officiated at the opening of the new airport terminal in Mackay. It is a beautiful terminal building, but a tiny building compared with Darwin--a $16m project. Some 32,000 people turned out in Mackay for the opening of that building and the associated air shows. It was a magnificent day for promoting the district. As I pointed out in the letter to the Chief Minister, when the Northern Territory is finally going to get $100m-worth of tourist facilities, the Northern Territory Government and the senators representing the Northern Territory, instead of continually knocking the project, should get behind it to help promote the Northern Territory as a tourist destination.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I wish to ask a supplementary question, when the jackals on the other side stop crowing. I ask the Minister to turn his attention to the fact that he promised to open the Alice Springs Airport terminal on 14 August. It has now been mothballed for several months. He is now saying that it will probably be in early December, without a fixed date. He promised to open the Darwin terminal, in all its magnificence, on 1 October. That has not been done and it may now be opened in early December. There are no fixed dates. I asked him for a firm commitment to particular dates. I also asked him a very important question, which he failed to answer, relating to the temporary buildings at the Alice Springs Airport, which last Saturday had the highest ever throughput of people. People were forced to sit in the car parks--
—-On a point of order, Mr Deputy President: if Senator Tambling wants to make a personal explanation at the end of Question Time, that is the time to do it. There is no supplementary question.
—-Order! Senator Tambling, if it is a supplementary question, it is becoming rather long. I ask you to conclude your question.

—-I ask the Minister to turn his attention to the part of my question he did not answer about why the demountable buildings used for security and waiting lounges have been removed. In addition, will the Government indemnify the FAC for any death, health or injury claims arising from travellers and Alice Springs residents who are now required to risk the unsafe and unsatisfactory facilities?
—-Mr Acting President, my colleague--
—-I wouldn't give him an invitation to the opening.

—-He will turn up anyway. My colleague the honourable member for the Northern Territory, the Hon. Warren Snowdon, MP, will be opening the Alice Springs terminal building on 8 December. I will be opening the Darwin Airport terminal building the following weekend. As I have said before, the difficulty Senator Tambling has is that both he and his colleague Mr Finch have made a five-year career--
—-When are you going to open the third runway?

—-In 1995, and I will be turning the first sod before the end of this year. Senator Tambling and his colleague Mr Finch have made a lifetime political career out of predicting that these terminals would never be built. Will Senator Tambling finally acknowledge that these terminals have been built and will be of enormous benefit to the Northern Territory? Because I am a generous and forgiving person, I invite Senator Tambling to the opening of the terminals. I also invite any of my Senate colleagues, if they really want to see a good terminal building, to come to the Alice Springs and Darwin openings on 8 and 14 December.

—-I refer the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce to recent comments by Senator Kemp in which he said that a number of Australia's major trading partners in the Asia-Pacific region had goods and services taxes. Can the Minister advise whether this is true and whether it will be considered in the review of the business taxation system announced last week by the Prime Minister?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I did see comments by Senator Kemp on this issue. I heard them on Tuesday afternoon when he was speaking here in the Senate. I do not normally watch the television, but I was attracted to this particular performance of Senator Kemp by the fact that he was so excited about it. Here he was, a middle-aged young Liberal, at last arriving in the big time. At last he had arrived in the kitchen, and he was attacking Senator Button and having the time of his life. Senator Kemp was clearly enjoying himself. One might say he was loving himself. At that stage I got a bit alarmed because I thought, `This young man will go blind if he continues like this'. So I thought I ought to do something about it. I have already accused Senator Kemp, in relation to this speech, of having pimples all over his tongue, and he ought to have, if he has any respect at all for the facts.
—-Carr would do better than this. Why don't you retire and bring him in?

—-I thank Senator Macdonald very much; he ought to go and have another drink. Senator Kemp springs from the great think-tank in Melbourne, the Institute of Public Affairs. If the Institute is advising the Opposition about its consumption tax on the basis of the information Senator Kemp alleged in the Senate on Tuesday, then the Opposition is in for deeper trouble than it ever imagined.

ANSWER.PARA: I saw how Senator Kemp tried to set a trap for me at Question Time with a whole lot of silly questions. Senator Kemp and Senator Bishop sit there like the two principal characters in Waiting for Godot, each sitting in a garbage can and occasionally putting their hands out for one purpose or another. Those two sat there together and worked out what they thought were some very subtle questions on this issue. Senator Kemp alleged in this place that the question of comparative taxation related to the Asia-Pacific region, our major trading partners and the fact that they had a goods and services tax. That is what Senator Kemp said.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I said a number of them do. Read Hansard.

—-Senator Kemp said `he will find that one element of the tax system which makes it different from the tax system we have in Australia is a goods and services tax' in our major trading partners. That is wrong. That is a lie. If Senator Kemp is going to use the Asia-Pacific region countries as a model--
—-I raise a point of order. The Leader of the Government in the Senate has accused Senator Kemp of a lie in this place. That is unparliamentary and should be withdrawn.

—-Mr Acting President, the reason why I rise is simply that Senator Kemp would know that he is the person who has regularly accused people of lying in this place. We have not sought to take points of order on that because we do not regard his saying it as being very important. But I do not think we should have two different standards applied--one when he speaks, and one when someone speaks about him.
—-The word is unparliamentary and I ask the Leader of the Government in the Senate to withdraw it.

—-I withdraw the word. Perhaps I can substitute words like `crass error' by Senator Kemp. I apologise for the length of this answer, but I want to get a few facts on the record which Senator Kemp can contemplate during the week or more that we are away from this place.
—-Mr Acting President, I raise a point of order.
—-We cannot have a circus without a clown.

—-And you're the clown. Mr Acting President, Senator Button is attempting to put what he says is his construction of the truth on the record. I wonder whether you would mind asking him to include all of it, and include the words of his own Deputy Secretary, Dr Bell, who required in his speech that we, indeed, move to a VAT-type tax.
—-There is no point of order.
—-There is no point of order, and that observation is as silly as the other observations that come from these two seats. The Opposition has a problem with those two sitting together.

—-I raise a point of order. I thought that Senator Button might have got the message when he was forced to withdraw a word during what was then a very long answer, at which stage he was clearly debating the issue. He is now clearly reopening and continuing the debate, and he is out of order in that respect.
—-There is no point of order.
—-The fact of the matter is that there are a number of major Asian economies which do not have consumption taxes of any form.
—-But a number do--Korea, Indonesia, Taiwan, the Philippines, Japan.
—-Senator Kemp!
—-Those are the ones that have them.
—-Senator Kemp!

—-Mr Acting President, I am dealing with a crass misrepresentation which was made on Tuesday in the Senate. The major economies of Malaysia and Singapore do not have consumption taxes. The closest Singapore gets to it is a sales tax on food and beverages in restaurants.
—-Singapore, major?
—-Malaysia has no such tax. Japan has a consumption tax of 3 per cent on sales. Korea--
—-Order! Senator Kemp, I have asked you on two occasions to cease your interjections. I am warning you.

—-Mr Acting President, I am not disagreeing in any way with your warning to Senator Kemp but I do say that if we are going to have proper order in this chamber, Ministers have to abide by the rules as well. Senator Button has already had it drawn to his attention by you that his answer has been going on far too long. It is way outside the length for answers that has been laid down by the President and he is clearly intending to continue in defiance of those rules.
—-The Minister is not continuing in defiance of any rule. If the Minister were heard in silence I think that his answer would conclude.
—-Japan has a consumption tax of 3 per cent.
—-What about Korea?

—-Korea has a consumption tax of 10 per cent; Taiwan, 5 per cent; the Philippines, 10 per cent; and Indonesia, 10 per cent. There are no 15 per cent or 12.5 per cent rates such as are reportedly contemplated by the Opposition. The Opposition should look at what its Leader has said on a number of occasions about exemptions. Korea exempts all basic foodstuffs and educational services. The Philippines has a long list of exemptions. Taiwan has 29--
—-I raise a point of order. Mr Acting President, Senator Button is clearly continuing to debate this question and I ask you to bring him to order.
—-Senator Button is providing information. There is no point of order.

—-Taiwan has 29 categories of exemptions including rice and flour. Indonesia has a luxury sales tax on top of VAT. If Senator Kemp thinks, as he tried to represent in the Senate, that there is a consensus view on the introduction of a GST he should get out his think-tank and look at the details.

—-This chamber is descending into a rabble. On a point of order, I point out that all the Minister is doing is confirming the points that Senator Kemp made in his speech yesterday. I think he has satisfied his purpose. He is continuing to debate it and I ask you, as did Senator Durack, to ask him to terminate his answer.
—-Senator Bishop, I agree with your first sentence, but there is no point of order.

—-When Senator Kemp raised this issue on Wednesday what he sought to do was to say that in looking at business tax in this country the Government--and I in particular--was really concerned about consumption taxes amongst our major trading partners. That is not true. It was never true. Senator Kemp has misled the Senate in what he has said about the consumption taxes in the Asian-Pacific region.

ANSWER.PARA: I have said this now in order to give Opposition senators time to do a bit of work on their proposal before they start to misrepresent this next week when they are away from the Parliament.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Mr President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Knowles Sen S.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) to a question without notice asked by Senator McKiernan this day relating to countries with a consumption tax.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Yesterday Senator Herron asked me a question concerning statements in the Courier-Mail allegedly made by Dr John Nearhos, the Health Insurance Commission's Medical Director. In answer, I can say that the Health Insurance Commission has established that in the first quarter of this year 3,684 GPs ordered $58m in pathology out of the total of $160m for that quarter. On a population basis, more GPs fell into the category of high orderers of pathology in Queensland than in any other State. In Queensland 34 doctors per 100,000 population ordered more than $10,000 in the quarter compared with 10 doctors per 100,000 population in Victoria.

ANSWER.PARA: Other work done by the Health Insurance Commission compares the bulkbilling rates of those GPs in the high ordering category with all other GPs who order pathology. The percentage of all GPs who direct billed 91 per cent to 100 per cent of their services in 1990-91 was 32 per cent. The percentage of GPs in the high pathology ordering category who direct billed 91 per cent to 100 per cent of their services in 1990-91 was 44 per cent. The Health Insurance Commission has not done any work in comparing pathology ordering rates on an international basis.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I seek leave to make a statement on reforming the industrial relations system, and to move a motion relating to the statement.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —-This Government came to office in 1983 with an economic reform strategy in which industrial relations was a crucial ingredient. By industrial relations reform, the Government means both a restructuring of the institutions and formal requirements of the system and a total transformation of the culture in the workplace.

SPEECH.PARA: There has been significant and valuable change as the result. This is acknowledged by all the parties actually involved in the issue. This is not to say that the reform process is complete; it obviously is not. Much has been achieved, however. The purpose of this statement to the Parliament is to explain how the process will continue. The Government has decided to provide for a collective bargaining form of workplace agreement within the present system. In making this decision, the Government rejects the system now operating in New Zealand and the imitation of it by the New South Wales Government.
I shall return to the details of the Government's proposal in a moment. First, let me put the whole question of reform of the industrial relations system in a rational perspective.

In any logical debate on this issue, the greatest attention would be focused on the greatest obstacles to reform. The problem with much of the debate that we have is that it tends to be misdirected. It pays more attention to the amount of working time lost than it does to how productive is the time we spend at work.

As an illustration of this weakness in much of the present debate, it is worth looking at the attention given to lost working time. This debate concentrates on the symptoms rather than the causes. Moreover, it concentrates on the least important of these symptoms--that is, strikes--and all but ignores the far more important ones of absenteeism and work-related illness and accidents.

The accord between the ACTU and the Government has been enormously beneficial in many ways. One of the most significant of its benefits has been its impact on the level of industrial disputation. Ten years ago, this was a major problem for industry. The number of working days lost through industrial action has consistently been 60 per cent lower during the accord than during the preceding period of coalition government. The accord was aimed, among other things, at resolving conflict over income shares. Its spectacular success in this regard is shown by the fact that working days lost as a result of disputes over wages have fallen by 80 per cent.

Of course, there are many sources of conflict at the workplace over which public policy can have little direct influence. There has been no major reduction as yet in disputation over what the Australian Statistician defines as managerial policy issues. In recent years, however, the accord process has set in train a process of workplace reform which will--with the goodwill of the parties--see a major improvement in workplace relations.

There has been a clear move towards greater cooperation between management and unions. This process still has a long way to go in most areas and, during the transition to a more efficient, dynamic and participative workplace culture, there will inevitably be disagreement about how work should be organised. Nonetheless, the time lost through disputes over managerial policy, wages or any other issue pales by comparison with that lost through absenteeism and work-related sickness and accidents.

Studies undertaken during the 1970s suggested that time lost through strikes was only one-twentieth of that lost through other forms of unapproved absence from work. The comparison would be even starker now because the large decline in disputation has yet to be matched by a large decline in absenteeism. In 1979 an average of 3.8 per cent of full time employees were absent from work because of illness, accident or absenteeism. In 1989 the figure remained relatively steady at 3.4 per cent of full time employees. This reflects the fact that management has yet to address fully issues such as work organisation and job satisfaction which are central to reducing absenteeism.

Unjustifiable absences from work are widely accepted as being a symptom of unfulfilling work, poor job satisfaction, weak organisational commitment and rigid work organisation which makes difficult the blending of work with family and other responsibilities. It is not that Australian workers are idle. Such absences will not be solved by sanctions against them. The truly effective way to solve these absences is by making work more interesting and rewarding and by giving workers more responsibility and more influence over how work should be performed.

Work-related sickness and accidents have been estimated to cause the loss of nearly 14 million working days a year of productive industry time. The reality is that, for many Australians, the workplace is a dangerous place to be. About 500 workers lose their lives each year in work-related accidents; at least 300,000 workers are injured.

The answer to this problem is not just to concentrate on compensation for work-related sickness or accident--hugely expensive as this is--but also to tackle the much more complicated business of making the workplace safer. This means involving workers in planning the way work can be designed, organised and performed so that it is safer and healthier.

The average employee now loses less than 1 1/2 hours a year in working time as a result of taking part in industrial action. The 1991 Australian Workplace Industrial Relations Survey--the most comprehensive, up-to-date survey available--found that 72 per cent of workplaces had never had any industrial action. A further 10 per cent had not had any form of industrial action for two years or more.

These facts are not reflected in the debate over industrial relations. This debate is characterised by an extraordinary imbalance resulting from the ideologically-driven preoccupation with industrial relations as an issue of political conflict. At the workface, however, employers and employees have to operate in the real world. They have to make a living in this practical real world; they have to get results to make a living. Using industrial relations to score political points or as an ideological laboratory is a self-indulgence that neither they nor the community as a whole can afford.

The Government has designed an industrial relations reform strategy that deals not with ideological marginalia but with the real impediments to industry efficiency and productivity that stem from such issues as absenteeism and occupational sickness and injury. The fundamental principle in this strategy is cooperation rather than conflict. The essence of the strategy is to stimulate teamwork, goal sharing, consultation and participation at work; to facilitate the development and spread of skills acquisition throughout industry; to encourage equal opportunity in skills development and career prospects; and to strive for greater safety in the workplace.

Industrial awards have been modernised and restructured to get rid of the old task based job classification structure which so obstructed the more flexible use of labour. A union rationalisation program and the move to single bargaining units is helping to eliminate the complications associated with union coverage which have been identified by many investigations and ignored by previous governments over the years.

Wages policy has been used as an incentive to revamp industrial awards, thus facilitating structural efficiency, underpinning the new decentralised focus of the system and increasing the viability of bargaining at the workplace level. A greater degree of cooperation than ever before is now taking place between Federal and State industrial relations systems. This should help bring about more consistent outcomes, less forum shopping and simpler and more cost effective procedures. So far the Government has allocated $40m to its workplace reform program. This promotes labour market reform and industry restructuring and encourages better work and management practices, work organisation and industrial relations.

Work related health and safety has been brought to the forefront as a reform issue. Occupational health and safety regulation is basically a State responsibility. The National Occupational Health and Safety Commission--Worksafe--has, however, been active in promoting it as a national issue with high significance for the costs and performance of industry. Worksafe has carried out valuable work on such issues as the industrial use of chemicals; the health and safety factors which have special impact on women workers and workers with non-English speaking backgrounds; and the development of national health and safety standards.

Much remains to be done in a task that has been complicated by the fact that it has been put off for so many years by governments of all political persuasions. The new productive culture has yet to take hold in all workplaces, to be reflected in work design, work organisation and work decision making. Management and union structures still need to adapt to accommodate the move in a decentralised system away from control and hierarchy toward integration and teamwork. Industry has yet to develop the flexibility to enable it to take up the fullest potential offered from among women and other workers whose skills have traditionally been under-recognised and ignored. Most companies still prefer to buy the skills they need rather than develop their own skills and offer their employees better career prospects through training programs.

The central thrust of the Government's reform strategy is to establish a framework and offer financial and other resources by which these issues can be tackled. It is up to industry itself to take advantage of this assistance. The Government has established the Australian best practice demonstration program as a catalyst in the process. It has allocated $25m to this program, which is designed to illustrate the productivity gains made possible by analysing international benchmarks and striving to achieve them, a process already under way in our own enlightened enterprises. The Government is seeking to galvanise both management and the work force into cooperative action by this process. Only those enterprises which can demonstrate that they are prepared to undertake a comprehensive reform and restructuring program within a reasonable time frame will be eligible to take part in the scheme and share in its rewards. The Government will continue to support these foundations of reform.

Having put the foundations in place, the Government has to consider the structure of the system to be built on them. The Confederation of Australian Industry and the Business Council of Australia have both recently put forward reform proposals which acknowledge the significant progress achieved in the reform process. They go on to make the valuable point that it is now timely to consider further change to the system which will build on this progress. The Government shares their view.

Indeed, accord mark VI committed the Government and the unions in February last year to move beyond the award restructuring outcomes that were available at the time through the centralised system and to embrace the concepts of decentralisation and enterprise level industrial agreements. The accord, the debate at the recent ACTU Congress and the reform proposals recently issued by key employer organisations indicate that all parties are agreed on the need to keep the process of change going. This kind of change goes beyond what the current national wage case review of wage fixing principles can consider. This review is necessarily restricted to what is possible within the present structure.

In all the circumstances, it is appropriate that the Government should now express a view which, while grounded in its accord commitments, describes the logical conclusion of the moves made towards greater flexibility, more freedom of choice and the process of managed decentralisation. The Government has had extensive consultation with leading employer bodies and the union movement on this issue. Many interesting and sometimes challenging suggestions have emerged. Essentially, however, there is broad agreement that there is a place for bargaining beyond the existing conciliation and arbitration framework for those who are able to do so responsibly.

Experience with section 115, certified agreements, under the Industrial Relations Act demonstrates how effective and constructive such agreements can be. The Government believes that more could and should be done to encourage such an approach to the joint determination of employment conditions and work relationships. To achieve this objective, it proposes to reform the present legislative arrangements which recognise the direct bargaining process. This should take account of the views of the representative employer and employee organisations.

The Government does not accept, however, that unions should be excluded from a revised system, nor does it accept that there should be no mechanism to protect the public interest where it may be jeopardised by the direct bargaining process. Both sensible economic management and equity require a measure of regulation of the formal bargaining process. Workplace agreements should be reached fairly and freely. This, however, does not imply restricting the organisational rights of workers and their unions nor ignoring public interest requirements. The Government disagrees with the proposition that tribunals and unions should have no part in reaching and finalising workplace agreements. It has aptly been said that the typical relationship between an employer and an individual employee is one between a person with power and a person without power. Labour law operates in civilised societies to prevent this natural inequality from being abused.

The Government included provisions in the Industrial Relations Act when it was introduced three years ago to encourage greater flexibility, particularly at the workplace level. These amendments gave employers and unions the capacity to operate in an environment of their own design, with internally determined agreements on wages and conditions certified by the Australian Industrial Relations Commission. Employers and unions were given the scope to reach agreements which covered as much or as little of the employment relationship as they wanted. Examples of the results can be seen at ICI sites such as at Botany and at Southern Aluminium in Tasmania. Similar agreements are operating at the Daimaru department store in Melbourne and are likely at the new Toyota greenfield site at Altona.

Essentially, the Act allows the parties to reach agreements and bring them to the IRC for certification as awards. The provisions of the Act have some important characteristics. An agreement will be certified where the IRC is satisfied that it is in the interests of the parties concerned, but not if it regards the agreement as contrary to the public interest. Certified agreements operate for a fixed term and can be varied in only a limited range of circumstances. Notably, they do not have to conform with the IRC's wage fixing principles which regulate other awards. Provisions exist to prevent the flow-on of the terms of certified agreements to other awards.

Though this regime has allowed parties in the Federal system to reach some very productive agreements which now have the force of awards, many employers and unions regard the provisions as not providing enough guidance or a sufficiently clear alternative to the usual arbitral process. It is fair to say that the IRC itself has not found the current provisions free of difficulty.

Let me explain what the Government sees as essential elements in the direct bargaining alternative to be provided for in the Act. Broadly, the Government considers that this option should be more clearly defined and separated from the mainstream conciliation and arbitration system. For the reasons I have already given, the IRC should have a role at the entry point of the process. It should be satisfied that the decision by the parties to regulate their relationship by such agreements has been reached fairly and with a full understanding of its implications. Bargaining outside the arbitral framework, however, would not occur in an `anything goes' way.

There is a common view among employer representatives and unions that direct bargaining carries with it both rights and responsibilities. The obvious flexibility which such a system implies should be tempered by recognition of the need for bargains, once struck, to be observed. Clearly specified consultative and grievance processes must be followed. The parties could request a role for the IRC in resolving disputes arising under an agreement without varying its intent. Standard conditions of employment should be observed to avoid exploitation. Workplace agreements should not be vehicles for leapfrogging and flow-ons.

Importantly, having opted for such an industrial relationship, a party should not be able simply to abandon it unilaterally during the term of an agreement without the consent of the other party. There should, nonetheless, be a place for the IRC to review the continuation of the agreement if it appears to be operating in a manner contrary to the public interest.

There should be no industrial action during the life of the agreement over matters that are the subject of the agreement. Equally, the parties should, subject to reasonable conditions, be able to have resort to certain forms of industrial action in periods of negotiating new workplace agreements.

One final point should be appreciated by all concerned. When governments, or anybody else, entertain options for remodelling the industrial relations system, they cannot avoid addressing the question of the legal framework--including rights and penalties--that should underpin the integrity of the remodelled system. There has been much debate of late about the finding by a key United Nations body--the International Labour Organisation--that our present legal framework appears to contradict our commitments to freedom of association which we assumed when Australia ratified ILO Convention 87. This finding by the ILO Committee of Experts on the Application of Conventions and Recommendations--an independent body of eminent jurists--has already underlined the need to revise the existing machinery for securing compliance under the present system.

Opening the system to direct bargaining, as the Government proposes to do, makes the question raised by the ILO even more pressing. This question is not just about legal sanctions or the right to strike, to which most of the current debate is confined. With a fundamentally reformed system, we need to be sure that the existing legislative framework can guarantee its integrity. I have already explained that the Act should prescribe when industrial action is permissible in direct bargaining and in what circumstances. The fact is that workplace bargaining cannot be genuine without the right by both parties to engage in certain forms of industrial action.

The Government has been consulting widely on this issue for some time, particularly in the National Labour Consultative Council, which brings together employer, union and government representatives. But narrowly focusing on rights, obligations and penalties can deflect attention from the main game: to develop a cooperative culture in the workplace. We will give most attention to this objective. Success in achieving this broader goal will render much of the current debate over rights and sanctions irrelevant and anachronistic.

Let me conclude by making the Government's position clear on reform of the industrial relations system. It is a system which has already undergone a great deal of reform in recent years in order to make industry more flexible and productive. Encouraging and facilitating more bargaining at the workplace level is a logical extension of this reform process. The Government intends to encourage it. Such bargaining must be done freely and jointly, however, and in ways which do not damage the public interest. The system will be reformed so as to accommodate these essential conditions. The whole process raises questions about the shape of the legal framework which must be fairly and honestly addressed. I commend this statement to honourable senators. I table the statement and I move:
That the Senate take note of the statement and document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I rise to respond to the statement that has just been tabled by the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook. It is a long and totally uninspiring statement. Indeed, when trying to find one's way through the morass of words and strange phrases and tortuous language that it contains, one can only really conclude that the main purpose of it is to get the Minister back into the industrial relations game.

SPEECH.PARA: The past six months has been a highly confused game indeed, with a lot of notable players taking up new positions--contradictory positions, conflicting positions--with the result that the Industrial Relations Commission, which the Government and the ACTU tried to marginalise in April, has called for a second national wage case much earlier than would normally be the case. I think that case is still proceeding.

As I said, the attempt by the Minister now--I suppose on behalf of the Government--is to make some positive contribution to this debate, which is, of course, the first attempt to do so made by the Government since the national wage case six months ago. Just to recap, the decision of the IRC in the national wage case last April was repudiated by both the Government and the ACTU on the ground that the Industrial Relations Commission had the cheek and the nerve to reject the submissions made to it by the Government and the ACTU. It exercised some independence.

TALK.START.PARA: —-That is not true.
—-It just goes to show how much he knows about his portfolio.
