—-That just shows how marginal and how irrelevant Senator Cook is. I remind the Minister what his friend the Secretary of the ACTU, Mr Bill Kelty, said when that case was brought down. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: It is a sickening decision, but there is no reason for the trade union movement to eat the vomit.

That was said by the Government's mate, its big mate, Kelty. That is what he had to say about the matter. The Government said--and the Minister announced this--that it would implement the accord in the Commonwealth public sector--the only area, of course, in which it could act. The Government has in fact acted in that area. In public, the Government--perhaps not in such revolting terms as Mr Kelty's--was very critical of the decision of the IRC.

The Minister was critical of the IRC despite the fact that he had been chiding the Opposition in this place for not respecting the umpire. The Government did not respect the umpire's decision in that case; in fact, it rejected the decision. It is just hypocrisy for Senator Cook to come in here time and again and try to suggest that the Government will have some respect for the IRC in this statement, after the way the Government and the ACTU have treated that body for the past six months. How the Government could believe that in future the IRC would be able to assert any authority in the industrial relations world, after the way it has been treated by it and the ACTU, is a complete mystery.

As I have said, this statement is very long indeed. It contains a great deal of generalisation and points to matters about which Senator Cook has great concern, a lot of which would be shared by the Opposition. At the end of his speech, the Minister said that the Government's object in this matter is to develop a cooperative culture in the workplace. If the Government is interested in achieving a cooperative culture in the workplace, then I point out that the Opposition is offering a policy which is very much more designed to develop that cooperation than anything the Government has come up with or anything the ACTU has been able to come up with. I will come back to that matter later.

The real defence of the Government is still its relationship with the ACTU and its much vaunted accord. It is interesting that the Minister should spend a great deal of his time criticising what he calls the obsession with strikes of so many participants in the industrial relations debate. He seems to be doing a great deal of shadow-boxing in this respect because, indeed, that is a debate that has occurred in the past. It is not at the forefront of the debate at the moment.

The Minister uses some interesting statistics that are a severe reflection on the Government's record in relation to matters to which the Minister claims it pays great attention; namely, the degree of absenteeism. Indeed, on the second page of his statement, he regrets that there has been little achievement over the years of this Government in relation to encouraging people to work more regularly or harder or more happily. I quote from his statement:

In 1979, an average of 3.8 per cent of full time employees were absent from work because of illness, accident or absenteeism. In 1989, the figures remained relatively steady at 3.4 per cent of full time employees. This reflects the fact that management has yet to address fully issues such as work organisation and job satisfaction . . .

Typically, he tries to put that responsibility on management. Perhaps the Government should look at itself and at how far its famous accord has worked in achieving the alleged goals of the Government. As I said, the general goal of cooperation instead of confrontation in the workplace has always been shared by the Opposition.

The Government is still sticking to the accord as the linchpin not only of its industrial relations policy but of its policy generally. We should reflect on where the accord is at this stage. What has it achieved for the average member of the work force, for ordinary Australians? We keep hearing claims by the Government that the accord has done remarkable things for the people of Australia. One thing the Government does claim is that the accord has caused fewer strikes. It has always claimed that the accord is not simply a wages policy or an industrial relations policy; one has to look also at the totality of the Government's economic policies in relation to the standard of living of ordinary Australians.

What is the result of 8 1/2 years of Labor government in relation to the standard of living of Australians? First and foremost, it has delivered, as the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) has finally admitted, the worst recession in Australia for 60 years. At last the truth has been admitted by this Government. The worst recession for 60 years is what this Government has delivered to ordinary Australians. What about employment? According to the latest statistics, the unemployment rate is 10.2 per cent, and there is a forecast by the former Treasurer that unemployment will go higher this year. All the economic commentators agree that it will go higher. So we are looking at more like 11 per cent unemployment. This is what the Government has delivered to the Australian work force. Ordinary Australians, whom the accord is supposed to help, have had this treatment by this Government.

There are a few other features of the accord that also ought to be recorded. It has delivered lower real wages in Australia, and that is the constant complaint of the Government's great mate, Mr Kelty. He has threatened to pick this up in subsequent wage cases, by enterprise bargaining or by union muscle or whatever--he does not care much. A man who thinks and speaks the way he does is hardly going to be squeamish about the methods he uses. He has identified the great weakness of the accord. All the Minister is saying in this statement is that the Government is virtually going to carry on in the future the way it has in the past. It is pleased with the accord, despite all the criticisms of it, the failures of it and the rejection of it, in effect, by the union movement.

The statement records some of the new developments that have been occurring very rapidly over the past few months. One of the bases on which the national wage decision in April was rejected was that it threw a bucket of cold water over enterprise bargaining. Certainly, the Opposition shared with the Government that criticism of the decision. But what the Opposition means by enterprise bargaining, what the Government means by it and certainly what the ACTU and the unions mean by it are probably very different things. Nevertheless, there has been a good deal of discussion about enterprise agreements being reached over the past few months. In so far as these are movements towards genuine enterprise bargaining, the Opposition has welcomed them and will continue to welcome them. However, during this time there has also been a great deal of confusion, and presumably this statement is meant to clarify in some way where the Government stands.

It is a bit odd that the Government has brought this statement down at this particular time when the national wage case has been brought on early in an attempt by the Industrial Relations Commission to reassert some of the authority it deserves to have and which it does have under the legislation but which has been severely damaged by actions of the Government and the ACTU. The national wage case has proceeded in a fairly normal way. The Government and the employer bodies have made submissions to it, but as yet there has been no decision by the IRC in relation to the matter. One would think the Government might have waited until that occurred before it made a general statement of this kind. The timing of the statement is a little odd.

It seems that the Minister is so anxious to get himself back in the game in which he has been a bit player for so long that he has decided to amend the Industrial Relations Act. This is the solution now to the major economic and social problem that has been facing Australia for many months! It is the typical answer by the Government: `We will pass some legislation and that will fix it up'. We had the national wage decision in April, followed by the confusion created by the Government, by the ACTU and particularly by Mr Kelty. It was not helped very much by the then Treasurer, Mr Keating, who seemed to be fully in agreement with Mr Kelty at that stage, although he left the field altogether shortly afterwards, and that has probably led to even further confusion. It did seem that there might have been some sort of special relationship between the ACTU and the Government at that stage and that there might have been some new way of proceeding, but the rug came out from under that when Mr Keating resigned.

We have a statement by the Minister in which he says that the Government is going to bring in legislation. I do not know when that will come forward. Of course, we will have to wait until we see the details of it before we can state any position in relation to it. What marvels me about this particular proposition is that the Minister is going to amend section 115 of the Industrial Relations Act. This is the very section of the Act which the Minister has fallen back on in defending himself in debates in this chamber when the Opposition has been calling for a new voluntary enterprise agreement and enterprise bargaining at the shop level.

We have been saying that true enterprise bargaining is not possible under this present system and that the system has to be radically changed. The Minister has constantly poured scorn on us. He said, `Well, this is within the existing system. Here it is. Section 115 is working very well indeed. The Opposition does not seem to understand the system. It does not understand about this. It is not necessary because of section 115'.

What is the Minister doing now? The one solution he has is to amend the very section that he has seen as the answer to the Opposition's complaints about the system. He does so because he says that there are some elements in section 115 that are too restrictive, although it has had some benefits. It is fair to say that the IRC itself has not found the current provisions free of difficulty.

Let me explain what the Government sees as essential elements in a direct bargaining alternative to be provided for in the Act. One's hopes are raised. At last the Government has seen the light. It is accepting the criticisms that we in the Opposition have been making of this system for years now. In 1986, the Opposition basically unveiled the policy which we have in industrial relations--correct, true enterprise bargaining at the shop level or on a larger scale if the parties wish, but an option that they can take up without the interference of the ACTU, the Government and the Industrial Relations Commission.

In this new proposal, the Government is now moving a step further towards the Opposition's own policy. It is certainly accepting the very consistent and heavy criticisms that the Opposition has made for many years about the way the system is working--the system which Senator Cook defended time and time again in this chamber and elsewhere. Senator Cook said that the system was working all right; he now says it is not working all right and the Government is going to tinker around and make some changes to it.

It is rather difficult to understand exactly what the proposal is. I do not propose to speculate about how it could work. The Minister is very vague about what the Government is going to do. We will see the legislation and, as I said, we will then decide what our view of it is. What can be said about the decisions is that the Government is accepting the criticisms that we have made about the system for a long time. It is moving further towards a freer system of enterprise bargaining and, at the same time, it is still trying to preserve a role for the Industrial Relations Commission and, presumably, for all the big players, their mates in the ACTU and the employer organisations--all of whom love the existing centralised system.

The system is still going to be bureaucratic. The Industrial Relations Commission is going to determine the entry point of this process--whatever that means--and Big Brother will still be there keeping an eye on how these agreements are being entered into and the way they are going to be operated. Big Brother will still be in the system, and in that regard, of course, the Opposition totally rejects the principles of the legislation as stated by the Minister.

In conclusion, I reaffirm the pillars of the Opposition's policy on industrial relations. Firstly, we will free up the system to give employers and employees the freedom to decide their own terms and conditions of employment in a voluntary agreement.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Exploitation!

—-Rubbish, absolute rubbish. Firstly, we are not suggesting that we will abolish the IRC. If people do not want to enter into agreements or if they cannot enter into agreements, then the industrial relations system is still there for them to use if they want to. But it will be a very different role for the Commission under our system. Secondly, we will end compulsory unionism. I think that will be one of the major and most welcome steps for Australians in the future. Thirdly, we will allow for the establishment of enterprise unions instead of these great big amalgamated unions that we have debated here and opposed here. We will allow people to form themselves into unions at the enterprise level. That will, of course, greatly assist in the implementation of our policy. Finally, of course, we will preserve the rights of people in this community as exemplified by sections 45D and 45E. We will preserve the exercise of those rights in the Federal Court.

SPEECH.PARA: I notice that those matters have not be dealt with in this statement by the Minister. If it means that he is abandoning his plans for abolition of these rights, abolition of the Federal Court, the establishment of some new fancy court called the Labour Court--if the absence of that in this statement means that--then we will greatly welcome it. But this statement is silent on that very vital matter.

This statement is a most inadequate one. It is not going to solve the problems that are truly facing this nation and its industrial relations system. It does not really augur well for the future and the legislation which this statement may give rise to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I would like to congratulate the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook, on his ministerial statement on reform in the industrial relations system. Senator Durack, who has just led for the Opposition, said that what the Government and the Opposition say and mean are entirely different. That is the only thing that I can agree on with Senator Durack. Senator Durack said it was an uninspiring statement and contained strange language. Once again, I can understand that from Senator Durack because he cannot understand the language of the industrial workplace as it is in Australia in this decade, particularly as a result of the vast changes that have occurred in this country under this Government. They were probably strange words like `spreading skills acquisition', `encouraging equal opportunity' and `career prospects for ordinary people'.

SPEECH.PARA: You, Madam Acting Deputy President, will appreciate this: there are people here with law degrees, including Senator Durack, Senator Reid and Senator Bishop. They understand what it means to have a career with a starting point and finally a point of success that they can aspire to. But this Government is giving to ordinary people, who have not always had the advantage, the opportunity of a career within industry. This is a revolutionary change that has occurred which is, I believe, something that Senator Durack cannot comprehend.

`The flexible use of labour' is an expression best exemplified by the fact that the Minister has announced the program for best practice demonstration. The money going into that program indicates that the Government is giving its full support to what is new in industry--not the blind conservative policies we just heard Senator Durack talk about but the movement towards a cooperative culture, so that we can transform industry and thereby compete with the overseas countries that are challenging our tradition in industry. So the language is entirely different.

The essential thing in what the Government is proposing is collective bargaining--the form that workplace agreements will take within the system in the future, as the Minister has outlined. We have to contrast that with the Opposition's approach, which contains two basic characteristics. The first one, and Senator Kemp demonstrated this again today, is the obsession with industrial dispute figures. The Opposition always concentrates on the industrial disputation figures; yet, as the paper points out, only one-twentieth of time is affected by industrial disputation compared with the tremendous sickness, accident and other aspects that affect our work force and which are the direct result of our archaic system, which has not given enough emphasis to the development of the most precious thing we have in this country--our human capital. This Government is trying to develop that human capital. Unfortunately, the Opposition is concerned only about the machinery; it does not understand that it is the people who make the tremendous difference. In this case, the Minister has shown that the Government, through a variety of means, is attempting to develop that precious resource--our human capital.

So, firstly, we have that initial traditional obsession of conservative oppositions. Secondly, we have the simple proposal by the Opposition to favour capital over labour. That is what enterprise bargaining is. It is very crude and deliberate, and as time goes on I hope more and more people will come to understand that. I welcome the Minister's clear statement that he rejects the New South Wales Greiner Government's proposals and, of course, the New Zealand experiments. There is a common thread in the New South Wales and New Zealand legislation: it gives employers enhanced bargaining power over employees. In New South Wales, the employees will be locked into a three-year agreement but, as I will point out, there is a vast difference between this Government's proposals and what the Greiner Government, the New Zealand Government and Senator Durack would do.

Senator Durack has outlined the way in which the Opposition would do things, so let us look at that. The most serious issue of all is what happens before an agreement. What Senator Durack has not told us is that he will give us a one-sided system. He will give us a system in which, as Senator Cook pointed out in his paper, a person with power and a person without power will characterise the system. Senator Durack, under his proposal, will make sure that that is what happens. When Senator Durack says that there will be a lot of freedom, he is really talking about freedom for the employer. People who are now members of a trade union--for example, 40 people in a factory--according to what Senator Durack has outlined will form their own enterprise union. Who will be the secretary of a union with 40 members? Effectively, those people will be on their own. But the employer in this situation will remain a member of his association. He will still have access to the lawyers and the economists; he will still have industrial knowledge from the employer organisation about what is happening everywhere else--and, of course, knowledge is power. However, the people in the enterprise union, so-called, will be left to their own devices.

When Senator Durack says that he wants a freer system, he means that he wants a free kick for the employers to give them unlimited power in dealing with their employees. It is absurd. When Senator Durack talks about not giving preference to unions, he really means smashing unions. Even now in the Australian community people with New Right tendencies are challenging the system. One can well imagine what would happen if these people--particularly some ruthless employers--had a system that allowed them to have open slather. Charles Copeman of North Broken Hill-Peko is a type of employer anarchist, a person who is out to destroy the system.

I have recently been involved with a dispute in New South Wales. I have some knowledge of and a background in the printing industry, and at Vista Paper Products in Emu Plains there has been an industrial dispute involving an employer who refuses to follow the rules. This company has 55 employees and has produced carbonless paper. For 20 years, while it was owned by several different companies, including the American giants Nasua and Visyboard, it did not have an industrial dispute. Under the new employer, an industrial dispute has been going on for five months. For five months there has been a picket because the employees were locked out in the course of an industrial dispute.

The employer undertook no effective negotiation. In other words, he did not follow the proposals set out in Senator Cook's paper whereby people would have a free choice, proper negotiation and the ability to bargain properly. This employer reduced the hourly rate from $13.22 to $12.49, lengthened the hours of work, and effectively cut the pay rate by 11 per cent. The employer's attitude was, `Stand and deliver; you take it or you are out the door'.

I have mentioned this dispute because it has all the ingredients of the proposals that are in place in New Zealand and will be put in place in New South Wales if the Greiner Government is successful. They will turn our society upside down. One of the characteristics of this dispute is that, although the employer in this case has the Chamber of Manufactures behind him, the workers have their union behind them. Under the Opposition's proposals, those workers would be defenceless and they would be crushed by the power and the finances of the employer organisations, which could be mobilised to destroy a group of people. Senator Durack had the audacity to talk about Big Brother from the unions. Compare that with the power of the employer organisations.

The important thing is that, in this dispute, ordinary men and women who have never been involved in an industrial dispute are still out there battling. Australians will never be slaves. So no matter how the Opposition thinks it will crush the people, it will not be effective. As in this case, people will continue to go ahead. The Australian people will not accept the system Senator Durack has outlined because, as Senator Cook has said, the system must be fairly and freely negotiated. That is at the heart of this Government's proposal. It is the very opposite to what has occurred in the Vista dispute to which I have referred, and it is in contrast to the other developments that would result if the formula Senator Durack outlined to the Senate were to be implemented.

I congratulate the Minister and point out that the $25m proposed for the best practice demonstration program is a particularly important and positive development. It is something that shows an increasing Government commitment to the attempt to modernise our industry.

I also congratulate Senator Cook because I know that for some time he has pressed that Australia play its part in adopting ILO conventions. There is nothing more important than for us to move in conformity with ILO Convention No. 87--the freedom of association and the protection of the right to organise. It is one of those things that should have been done before. It is to Senator Cook's credit that he now takes us further in adopting that proposal. I think that proposal sums up the spirit of the Minister's statement, and I congratulate him on it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-We have been presented with a statement which has as part of its title `Reforming the Industrial Relations System'. The statement translates into some eight pages of written script, telling us--
—-Just a little.

—-Yes, just a little. It consists mainly of generalities, and I contend that it lacks precision. As an introduction to a debate about the industrial relations system of Australia, it is extraordinarily gentle.

SPEECH.PARA: The first part of the statement expends most of its energy emphasising the virtues of the present system and its achievements. We are told further into the statement that the system needs reform; in fact, that is in the title--`reform'. I looked forward to hearing some actual details of those reforms, but this statement does not provide them. The lack of detail enables us to agree with some of the statements, not because they are particularly inspirational but because they are bland and unsensational.
Early in the statement the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) refers to and identifies the causes of time lost from the workplace. Quite rightly, he emphasises:
Nonetheless, the time lost through disputes over managerial policy, wages or any other issue pales by comparison with that lost through absenteeism and work-related sickness and accidents.
Further, we are told:
Unjustifiable absences from work are widely accepted as being a symptom of unfulfilling work, poor job satisfaction, weak organisational commitment and rigid work organisation--
I strongly agree with this statement a couple of sentences later:
The truly effective way to solve these absences is by making work more interesting and rewarding and by giving workers more responsibility and more influence over how work should be performed.
As far as I am concerned, that means worker participation in management decisions.

The Australian Democrats were looking forward to a few hints as to how this might be implemented. What we really have is a statement by the Minister which is notable not so much for what it says but, rather, for what it fails to say. It fails to lead us directly to a system which would include effective worker participation, profit sharing or sharing of the decision-making process, whether that be through board membership or any other vehicle which brings about the understanding that workers, owners, shareholders and all interested parties share a mutual interest in the success of any enterprise. I was looking forward to seeing some of that in this statement. I think it skirts around the issues.

My interest was sparked when we were told in the statement that at least 300,000 workers are injured at the workplace each year. As a country, we should be ashamed of that statistic. It brought home some immediate relevance. I think we were all horrified with the graphic colour pictures and even the graphics that we saw on the front of the Age newspaper recently of a little boy who was injured by machinery in an avocado packing place.

At the moment I am not questioning who was liable in that case, nor am I questioning the machinery, the layout, whether it was up to Australian standards or whether particular industrial safety practices were followed. That is not what is at issue here. I am drawing attention to the potential for immense costs to workers, their families, their employers and the community in general. Senator Crowley mentioned that the cost to the community would possibly have been quite immense in that instance. Nobody in the community would dare question it; in fact, I think the community is elated that we have in Australia the technical and medical expertise to meet the problems that would have been faced by that little boy. In fact, we triumph with the community that this particular accident was probably medically overcome.

I draw attention to the fact that we had an accident that occurred at the workplace which may have been preventable by having effective work-based child-care. That is an issue which has not received a great deal of attention. Perhaps that is because it is not immediately apparent to those who are involved just what costs there are to the community in not having sufficient and effective work-based child-care. Those costs may be graphic, as we saw in the case of this little boy; or they may not be so graphic, not so easily understood. We should look at the cost to the community of having a very large part of potential contributors to our economic success in this country unable to attend work because of our lack of work-based child-care. Perhaps that problem would at least be addressed by what we are told by the Minister in the last sentence on the second page of the statement. It states:
This means involving workers in planning the way work can be designed, organised and performed so that it is safer and healthier.

I was pleased to note--the statistics helped to make it a little more attractive than the surrounding wordage--that there was no industrial action in 72 per cent of our industries; a further 10 per cent of our industries had not had any form of industrial action for two years or more. In other words, most employers and employees are mainly concerned with actually getting on with their own common task.

I was also very pleased--I am sure that it was part of the language that Senator Childs was telling us we should be familiar with; I must admit that it was unfamiliar to me--to know that the Government is not concerned with ideological marginalia. If I had to be concerned with that I would be thoroughly confused. We were told that the Government is not concerned about that. That is most pleasing, indeed. The fundamental principle in this strategy is cooperation rather than conflict. That message, after struggling through the previous terminology, was made quite clear to me. The Government believes that the most important principle in this is cooperation rather than conflict.
Further on, I came to some conflict in reading the statement. On page 4 of the printed statement we are told:

Industry has yet to develop the `flexibility' to enable it to take up the fullest potential offered from among women and other workers whose skills have traditionally been under-recognised and ignored.

That to me says that the status quo is far from satisfactory. The Democrats would certainly support that statement. We contend that these considerations of flexibility, in finding a way to bring about a greater contribution from those people who have traditionally been under-recognised and ignored, should not be considered in isolation.

Industrial relations is not a subject which stands in isolation. It is fundamental and integral to the economy, the environment and our education, health, welfare and social justice systems--indeed, our whole socio-economic environment. To properly consider this, we ought to ask some fundamental questions. For example: what do we define as work?

Anybody in receipt of any payments through either the Department of Social Security or the Austudy system has to grapple daily with the definition of work. While people are studying or preparing themselves for a career, seeking work, engaging in voluntary work or in what is euphemistically termed domestic work, they are nevertheless all working. Some are in receipt of benefits, social security payments or pensions and others are in receipt of nothing. When considering these injustices and different levels of equity, we really should be considering a proper definition or redefinition of work.

We are told in the statement that industry is yet to develop flexibility. I contend it is not only industry but also all Australians who need a different attitude to employed versus unemployed. When we consider those things then I will consider that we have moved from the superficial to a level of debate which might achieve something. If we accept that the present system is not perfect then this statement, in this part, is certainly superficial in its discussion and its proposals.

Further in the statement, we are informed that the Confederation of Australian Industry and the Business Council of Australia recently put forward reform proposals. We are told that they go on to make the valuable point that it is now time to consider further change to the system which will build on that process. That is one of those statements with which it is very hard to disagree. It does have a certain blandness. I could stand here and say that the Democrats agree with that.

However, the point that is most important to support is the need to consider what further improvements should be made and not just that improvement is needed. Really, we should be getting down to a discussion of what further improvements can be made. Until we do so, again, it is very much a case of agreeing with not very much. I am pleased to see that the word `flexibility' is repeated consistently throughout the statement. Therefore, the centralised and monolithic nature of the status quo will be challenged.

Also further into the statement there is something else with which it is certainly possible to agree, and that is the statement that there is broad agreement that there is a place for bargaining beyond the existing conciliation and arbitration framework. However, we are eager to see exactly what the Government proposes doing rather than agreeing that there is a place for such bargaining beyond the existing arbitration framework as defined by the Government.

We were told of the essential elements of any direct bargaining system. We were given a hint on what would be contained within any proposition to remove the centralised arbitration system from the linchpin of this system and replace it with a direct bargaining system. We were given a hint about that but no direct proposition.

Near the end of the statement, we were told, with reference to the ILO and its participation in this process and the deliberations of the committee of experts, that that underlines the need to revise the existing machinery for securing compliance under the present system. What will the Government do to meet that need which has been identified? We are anxious to see what the Government will do to meet that need.

There is no hint in the statement of heavier penalties. That is an assumption that has been made by many commentators on this issue. It is an assumption which I do not think such commentators have the right to make. In this statement we are told quite plainly on the final page, as we have been previously, that narrowly focusing--this is characterised as an obsession, and I would agree that commentators have been obsessed with this--on rights, obligations and penalties really can deflect attention from the most important part, and that is the need to develop a cooperative culture in the workplace. I certainly do not ridicule that statement; I support it completely.

Such a statement does not ring hollow with me as it might with Senator Durack. The words are quite plain and they are words which need to be endorsed. The Democrats certainly support the Government in that aim to bring a cooperative culture to the workplace. I contend that such a development will not occur without leadership, example and an indication of how we can leave that narrow, blinkered, misguided concentration upon one aspect of the lost time, or the reduced productivity in the workplace.

If we are to have our attention turned away from industrial action and towards cooperation at the workplace, then cooperative models must be identified quickly and provided so that we are able to follow and be inspired to adopt the cooperative model instead of being allowed to assume that the only model to follow is one of confrontation. With that hope in mind, I look forward to the next statement in this area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Devereux Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I join my colleague Senator Childs in congratulating the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) on this very positive statement which is about moving to the next stage of industrial relations reform that has been carried out by this Government, a reform unrivalled by any government in the history of this country. It is about reforming the whole workplace culture not only for workers but also for management.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not want to traverse the areas covered by my two colleagues who have already spoken. I want to talk specifically about one area and give an example of exactly what has been achieved and the hard work that was needed. Before doing so, I should comment on what has been said by Opposition members and the Democrats.

Senator Durack commented that for the past six months the Minister has been a bit player who, along with many others from the ACTU and other areas, has been making conflicting statements. In reality, in the past six months there has been a debate about moving to the next stage of this industrial reform. We are not afraid to have that sort of debate in a public way. There is nothing wrong with that.

Unfortunately, Senator Bell joined Opposition speakers in `the magic wand club'. They think they can solve all of the problems in the industrial system that have been built up over years and years simply by coming into the Senate or by going public and saying, `We will make a few changes here and write a few things in somewhere else and all the culture that has been built up over the years that has been the big problem within industry in this country and the efficient operation of industry will disappear as if by magic overnight'.

That just will not happen. We have to work very hard on it. There is a lot of work being done by unions in the workplace and, to their credit, many employers, to change this culture and create a much more effective workplace.

Senator Durack said that what this statement really did was entrench the Big Brother, because there would still be a role for the Industry Commission and big unions would still have a role. He said that the answer is to adopt the Opposition's policy. I suggest to the Senate that if we were to adopt the Opposition's policy we would certainly entrench Big Brother all right. We would simply turn back the clock by 50 or 60 years and allow all the little employers around this country to exploit workers just as much as they liked.

What we would have, if the Opposition's policy were to be implemented, is hundreds of unions all over this country--the very thing that I have heard the Opposition complaining about in the past. People in small workshops would be absolutely exploited. They would be in such a position that they would have absolutely no chance of achieving any justice. I suggest that the establishment of the Big Brother syndrome is simply what the Opposition's policy is all about.

Senator Durack quoted from the statement and said that it was the Government's intention to develop a cooperative culture in the workplace. He said that he certainly agreed with that and that the Opposition's policy would achieve it. I suggest that the Opposition's policy in no way would achieve it. What it would achieve is that eventually we would return to where we started 40 or 50 years ago, workers would get to the stage where they had to rebel against the system and there would be enormous conflict in the workplace. What has been said in the Opposition's policy is simply a recipe for confrontation and has nothing whatsoever to do with cooperation in the workplace.

I want to use as an example what has occurred in my State with one of the major enterprises in that State. I want to use it to highlight just how this Government's policy is working, how there is cooperation going on and what can be achieved in the future. I speak of the Hydro-Electric Commission in Tasmania. I suggest that in terms of the diversity of skills available in that organisation there is probably no organisation comparable to it in Australia. It is involved in the construction of power stations and dams, and the construction, installation and maintenance of power lines across the State. It delivers services through power distribution to industry and to all the individual consumers in the State. There is an incredible diversity of skills and work carried out by that organisation.

It is only in the last six months that that organisation has been completely changed. Until a couple of years ago there were 13 awards in that organisation--some were State awards and some were Federal--and there was an enormous number of unions. Within those awards there were 3,500 classifications, which was a quite ridiculous situation. In order to change that, what the Opposition would have done--if one looks at its policy--is confront the workers at the HEC and try to break down the system, and there would have been enormous upheaval.

What has occurred by cooperation, by the policies of this Government being put into place, by the cooperation of the unions and by discussion with the workers--not going out browbeating them--about how they could establish career paths and so forth, is that we now have one consolidated Federal award covering all of the workers in the HEC across that diverse range of work. In that award there are now only 42 classifications. In addition, an apprentice now, for example, could start with the HEC, and it is possible for that apprentice to proceed along a career path and end up in the top classification--which is a senior engineer in classification 42--and to achieve all that by working through the system and doing additional education.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Government stopped it when you stopped work on the dam.

—-In the past the position was that an apprentice working anywhere in the system had no way to get any accreditation and no opportunity. In fact, such an apprentice was debarred from entering any engineering courses. That is the sort of thing that has been achieved.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to give one other example of what has occurred. I heard Senator Walters make a comment about the dam a moment ago. The HEC workshop is now the biggest engineering workshop in Tasmania and probably compares, in terms of skills, with any in Australia. In 1983-84 people like Senator Walters and others were running round the country saying, `If you don't dam the Franklin River this place will dissolve. There will be no workers left here in this workshop'. I must admit, the workers in the workshop had very much the same view and they were very despondent about their future.

What has happened over the last two years--and I have to give credit where it is due; the opportunity to do this was due to a Liberal Government in Tasmania--is that an organisation called HEC Enterprises has been set up and allowed to go out and compete on the open market. Initially when it was set up people did not really take up the opportunity but, because of the greater cooperation between the unions, management and the workers themselves and much greater discussion, they have realised the potential that they have.

What has happened at the workshop is that now it is doing some extremely heavy engineering work for major private companies around Tasmania and companies on the mainland, and they are now involved in doing work overseas. A lot of that work has been carried out in that workshop. I venture to say that it will expand and become one of the biggest and most effective workshops in Australia.

All that has occurred because there has been a change in this mind-set due to the policies of this Government and the cooperation between this Government and the trade union movement in trying to get the message across to workers that there is a need to change their attitude, and there is a need for management to change its attitude. It will not be changed by simply trying to browbeat them.

I say this to establish the credentials of this Government in what has been achieved. That is just one example of where it has occurred. It has occurred in many other places. I guess none of us on this side would pretend that we have a perfect world at the moment. There is a lot more to be achieved. But those examples can be used as role models for other industries--a path for them to go down and to achieve the same sorts of things.

This Government can really hold its head up and say that it has done an enormous amount to change the industrial system in this country. I congratulate the Minister for this paper, which now identifies where we are going. There has been a debate about what ought to occur in the future. We are now moving to the next stage, and I think the next stage will be just as beneficial for the workers in industry across Australia. I commend this statement to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —-We are debating the statement on reforming the industrial relations system by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook). He deals with two areas. First, he spends several pages telling us how good the accord is, and then he winds up telling us of the reforms that the Government is indulging in. This Government has been in office for eight years and now it is starting to tell us about reforms.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Devereux explained how good the HEC workshop was. He acknowledged that it was all the result of the Liberal Government in that State of Tasmania. I agree with him. I agree with him entirely. It was because the Liberal Government in that State opened it up so that it could compete in the private market; I agree with him. That has nothing to do with the reform of this Government--not one iota. Senator Childs said that we do not understand the terminology. I ask Senator Childs what `ideological marginalia' means?

TALK.START.PARA: —- That is your speciality.

—-He does not know, nor when I offered him time could he explain what marginalia meant. I do not have a clue; and he does not have a clue because he cannot answer me. Yet he claims that we do not understand industrial language. What absolute rubbish!

SPEECH.PARA: Let us look at the first of the Minister's statements on the accord. He told us how magnificent it had been for industrial relations. The accord was so good and worked so fantastically in this country that the former Treasurer, Mr Keating, decided that things were so crook he would have to engineer a recession. So we have had the recession we had to have. The present Treasurer (Mr Kerin) has assured us that it is the worst recession for 60 years--a wonderful result of the accord! All the accord has done is to encourage dreadful, obscene work practices. It has encouraged people to take sickies. There has been a lack of productivity and it has resulted in the worst number of bankruptcies that this country has ever seen. We have over one million people unemployed--a wonderful accord! It is a wonderful accord for those who are still in the work force.

When we talked about the recession and what a dreadful situation the accord had produced, Senator Maguire stated, `But we have got a lower inflation rate'. Those opposite should go out and tell the one million people in the dole queues what a wonderful accord it has been for them. Frankly, I do not think they will believe those opposite.

We all remember Robe River and the action the Government took there. Look how viable it is now. We all remember that. We all remember SPC Ltd--where a solution had been worked out between the employer and employees--and the Government's interference there. We all remember how the action by government employees who formed a picket line at Mudginberri sent it broke. As all this has gone on, the standard of living in this country has gone down and down--all because of the accord. It is absolutely wonderful.

We have been told--and I would like to quote from the Minister's statements--that the accord has reduced strikes. In the middle of the worst recession in 60 years, it is not likely that people will go on strike too often. The Minister said that these factors are not reflected in the debate over industrial relations. Does the Minister not understand that the number of sickies that are being taken are a direct result of an accord that says, `You will get paid whether or not there is productivity; you will get paid whether or not your business goes broke or whether it is viable; you will get paid and you do not have to do a darned thing'? The Minister either does not understand or he will not listen to our industrial relations policy. Our industrial relations policy makes it possible for an employer and an employee to come to some agreement about sickies.

We have had the instance of ICI Australia Ltd. That organisation came to an agreement with its employees that sick leave would be unconditional. Its employees could have as much sick leave as they liked, so long as there was no abuse. The first time that any person was caught abusing the sick leave provisions, that person would be sacked. All the employees agreed and that agreement has stuck. ICI now has fewer sickies than it ever had before. This is the sort of agreement that we in the Opposition believe is the only way to overcome the problems, the ills, of this country.

Let us look at some of those work practices that I have been talking about. The Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support, Senator Collins, has told us that he has done wonderful things on the waterfront. Indeed, he promised that he would resign if he did not achieve them. This has been going on for quite some time. The problem is that he is attempting to reform the waterfront at the margins. He has not even tried to increase productivity in any real way. Since 1989 attempts have been made to improve the waterfront by creeping along and making a few redundancies along the way, so the Minister tells us.

Britain has achieved a 130 per cent productivity improvement in its ports, while we have been creeping along doing nothing. New Zealand has improved productivity in its ports by 98 per cent. We have had Bill Kelty telling us that there must be a halt to waterfront reform because we have gone far enough. Yet in Australia it costs $237 to shift a 20-foot container, almost double what it costs in Singapore at $137, or in Britain at $150. That is the sort of reform that this Government is attempting.

We also have Australia's biggest stevedoring company, National Terminals (Australia) Ltd, saying that, even if the reform that the Minister is telling us is achievable is accomplished fully, it will only average a movement of 23 containers an hour. Yet the American port of Philadelphia already shifts 33 containers an hour. We can achieve something so long as we do not set our goals too high. That is pretty easy.

These are the sorts of reforms that the Minister is talking about. He has made this statement because he has been dragged screaming by our policy to do something, just to say something about enterprise agreements. He is now advocating enterprise agreements, a term that was not acceptable in any situation by the Government a couple of years ago. Enterprise agreements were out. The big unions and the Industrial Relations Commission had the say. Now that the Government has had a brawl with the Industrial Relations Commission, when the Government set the accord and it was ignored by the Commission, the Government is threatening the Commission and moving towards enterprise agreements.

We know that the last accord was not accepted by the Commission, and the Government and the ACTU would not accept the umpire's decision. So now the Minister for Industrial Relations has made a statement setting out some new rules, but he will not go all the way. He will not take the final step that would set this country on the right path. There is a very big difference. Why not go for voluntary unionism? Why does the Government insist on forcing people into a union? Despite that, unionism is decreasing rapidly in this country because it is not supplying workers with anything at all. I quote from the second page of the ministerial statement:

Unjustifiable absences from work are widely accepted as being a symptom of unfulfilling work, poor job satisfaction, weak organisational commitment and rigid work organisation which makes difficult the blending of work with family and other responsibilities. It is not that Australian workers are idle. Such absences will not be solved by sanctions against them.

ICI managed to come to an agreement with its workers. That company told its employees that they could have unlimited sickies, but made it clear that the first time they abused the system they would get the sack. The Minister said that such absences would not be solved by sanctions, and continued in his statement:
The truly effective way to solve these absences is by making work more interesting and rewarding and by giving workers more responsibility and more influence over how work should be performed.

We say yes, definitely, that is the way to go; that is part of our policy. We believe that if the employees and the employer get together and decide on how the work will be performed, decide on the hours so that some people can work different hours from others, the work will become more meaningful because they will have some say. They will not be in the same position as those who were involved in the Mudginberri dispute, where the union said, `You will only slaughter X number of beasts per day'. Those involved will be able to come to an agreement that employees can work as hard as they like; they can slaughter as many beasts as they want to. They will not be restricted by a union telling them what they can and cannot do.

If I were in a union where I could not work as I wanted to, if I could not work with my employer and decide what action I could take or how hard I could work but was told by a union that I could not slaughter more beasts a day, although I was prepared to do so, I would not want to be in the union. Is it any wonder that the unions are losing power and members? There is a vast difference between the steps this Government is prepared to take and how far it is willing to go and what the Opposition is prepared to do.

This Government is trying desperately to hang on to some sort of Industries Assistance Commission input. We have been telling the Government for years that people want to be free to work as they want to work. In the end it does not matter what ideology one has, people will demand that freedom. They are demanding it now, and this is why the Minister is coming screaming along, telling people, `We are not really against enterprise bargaining, we are really for it'. But he is not telling the full story and saying, `However, only if the union agrees'. Later in his statement the Minister says:
Essentially, however, there is a broad agreement that there is a place for bargaining beyond the existing conciliation and arbitration framework for those who are able to do so responsibly.

What arrogance on the part of the Minister! Who is he to say who can do these things responsibly? Does `responsible' mean according to the Government's view on that or does it mean according to the employees' and employers' decisions? The statement continues:

To achieve this objective, it proposes to reform the present legislative arrangements which recognise the direct bargaining process. This should take account of the views of the representative employer and employee organisations.

The reference there is not to the employees but to the employee organisations. What happens in a business where none of the employees are union members? I do not know what would happen; the Minister has not spelt it out. He has not said that in such a case an employer would have to seek out a few unions and make sure that they came along and negotiated on the part of his employees who are not union members. I do not know what the Minister is talking about; certainly he has not attempted to clarify the position.

Senator Devereux was talking about Opposition members wanting hundreds of unions. I make it clear to him that, if necessary, we would want to see thousands of unions. Any business, it does not matter how small, can have a union for that particular business if it wants to. We are objecting to the fact that there are perhaps hundreds of unions in the one workplace, as there are in many workplaces at the moment. We believe that there are not enough small unions but that there should be only one to each workplace. This is not what the Government wants. It wants large, powerful unions so that if one union goes on strike it can hold the whole country to ransom.

To return to the statement, the Minister says how wonderful the accord has been. I would ask him to go out and tell the unemployed how wonderful it has been. The accord has been a disaster for the unemployed. It might be all right for those who still have a job, but as unemployment continues to grow the Government will be told what the people think of the accord. It does not take me to do that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —-It is amusing to listen to the litany of lies and stupidity over a number of speeches in this chamber. I should like to put the record straight because I am in a position to do that, having had many years experience in the trade union movement. I have been part of making that history, not talking about it, as do those ignorant people on the other side of the chamber. They get their experience out of books and newspapers. They do not know what it means to be involved in industrial relations. They believe in confrontation and not consultation.

SPEECH.PARA: All my life in the trade union movement I was considered to be a militant and a fighter, but one of the very important things in my armory was the capacity to talk in a friendly way to employers, to look at consultation and to seek agreements that are honoured. I never went to the question of legalities, but to what was fair and equitable.

Senator Walters and other Opposition senators talk about penalties for workers who do not do the right thing and lie down when they are told to and get up when they are told to. If the workers make a suggestion to the boss, they are told that they are not paid to use their brains and that they only have to do what they are told. According to the Opposition, penalties should be imposed on workers if they strike. I suppose that a better idea would be to throw them in gaol, as has happened in the past.

Industrial relations is about establishing performance and behaviour standards for people in industry who create both services and products--that is, consumer goods and capital goods. It goes to the question of work practices; health and safety; payment for work done and not done; hours of work; and human relations, treating people as human beings and not just as figures on a balance sheet or an extension of the machines they use.

The legislative framework within which these rules are made is tremendously important. If that legislation provides certain requirements for the standard of behaviour of both labour and capital, it provides the opportunity and the compulsion on both sides to seek to reach an agreement that can be mutually beneficial. The Liberal Party does not have that view, but the Labor Party has had it for many years. If we talk about history and some of the terrible things that have been perpetrated on workers, there are those who would say to us that we should not look at history but at the current situation. My experience has always been that intelligent people realise that one has to look at the past and the present to see where the future might go.

Senator Walters talked about the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) being dragged into a situation where he had to talk about enterprise agreements. I have heard some rubbish in the Senate in my time, but that nearly tops the lot.

TALK.START.PARA: —-If you ever listened to yourself--

—-Unions have been making enterprise agreements--and Senator Crane can either show his ignorance or agree with me--for many years. I have made many where there was a set of rules for wages and conditions in a particular workshop or enterprise or construction site which covered many unions and many members of unions. Those agreements were made with people who were intelligent, mature and sophisticated and who represented employers in those areas. On the other hand, they were made by trade union officials who were looking to get a set of wages and conditions that would benefit their members. They agreed to conditions such as no strikes for two years and so on.

SPEECH.PARA: The unions would never agree that there could not be a strike if a safety issue was involved. However, they did say that they were prepared to isolate safety issues and work on all the other parts of the site or in every other part of the enterprise. Very often, employers would use safety issues to create a dispute. While there has been much talk about the level of disputes and the intensity of some of the struggles, I can assure the Senate that many disputes were created quite consciously and purposely by employers. In fact, I have been instrumental on many occasions in advising members of one or more unions not to tumble into the trap and to stay on the job.

The enterprise agreement proposition is one that the Labor Party, the ACTU and individual unions have been involved in for many years. The main attraction in an enterprise union has always been for the employer. For example, an employer may have been in a position to pay additional money and placed a very high value on continued production--in other words, he did not want any disputes. Those agreements were made and registered in the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission over a long period--20 years or more, to my personal knowledge.

It is true that at one time we had overaward payments in many areas, but the unions that were thoughtful about the matter made a decision that we should try to get rid of those overaward payments and enterprise situations and look at an across-the-board award payment where people doing similar work would get similar rates of pay. For instance, when one looks at how manufacturing, which I know well, developed in this country and in other countries before Australia had a manufacturing industry in a fairly rudimentary way, one can see that it was very crude. It is well known to those of us who were involved in industry and have read many things about it that in America there was a proposition called tailorism, which took the skill of the tradesman and divided it up into many tasks. That created a position where people with very low skills were doing parts of a particular task, with no real responsibility for care. They had very limited value and very limited capacity to work outside that job.

It was the employers' wish that that be done in this country, so the metal trades award was established and developed whereby lower rates of pay were paid to people who did part of a journeyman's job. That meant that the skill base in this country was never developed in the way that it should have. It was even against the interests of those employers who were not prepared to look at it in a constructive way.

We went through a period where employers were quite happy, for instance, to build a ship in a shipyard on a cost-plus basis. They did not care how long it took or how inefficient it was. The longer it took the more wages they paid, and the more expenses they had the more profit they made. As time went on, they had to have fixed price contracts. They had to put in a price, and if they did not meet that price in terms of their ability to produce the goods they lost money. The employers expected the trade unions to change overnight and do whatever they wanted them to, under the threats of no employment security, dismissal when it suited the boss to make a few bob, and total submission to the idea of supervision in the workshop or on the work site.

That did not happen. In the main, trade union people are not highly educated; they are not university graduates. They were very low loathe to make those changes, particularly when they could see that the employers were still very inefficient and hopeless managers. They used to have a view--I have heard it said and even said it myself at one time--that on that occasion it was appropriate to take action. The unions took the view that if the boss wanted to be stupid and not organise the process of production or manage his factory or workplace and went down the flue--if he went broke--that was his problem, why should we help him?

People went from job to job; but suddenly it was no longer easy for people in industry or in enterprises to get other jobs. As we developed technology, jobs structurally disappeared. Jobs are structurally disappearing even now. So the trade union movement, which is much quicker on its feet than employers, decided, `It is about time we saved these dopey managers because they cannot save themselves'. We developed a process where we advocated greater skilling for the work force; training for management; more training for workers in the workplace; and the creation of career paths. I can assure the Senate that it took a lot of convincing as far as the employers were concerned. We did that; we felt that it was our obligation, and that was our initiative. However, if one listened to those opposite in this place, one would think it was the employers' initiative.

Over time, the trade unions, in some instances but not all, have also invested quite a lot of money in training shop stewards and other workshop representatives. Contrary to what those opposite would have people believe, we realised that if we had shop stewards who were properly trained and understood the sort of system the Minister talks about in the statement--some of it has been put into place and other sections of it will be put in place to develop the cooperative, consultative approach--we would get much further down the track. The trade unions have known that, and so they have worked towards it.

I picked up a copy of the journal of the Metal Workers and Engineering Union which is made up of some seven unions. Over many years, of its own accord it has gradually amalgamated to form a very good and functional union, a very thinking union, that has contributed a lot to the education of workers and employers. This journal related a story about an engineering company in the Hunter area. One of the organisers had a talk to management and said that there needed to be some changes in the way in which management and labour operated. The organiser said that there had to be more consultation; that people had to know what the future held. He asked how people could be expected to have any loyalty towards the company or any feeling about being part of the company if they were kept in the dark all the time, did not know whether the job would last a week or a month, were given only restricted training and the old demarcation operation was still there.

Following those discussions, the demarcation lines were blunted and, in some cases, they disappeared. There were fairly constant discussions between management and the representatives of the workers in which they talked about how they would go about a particular job; what work was available; how they should quote the job; and whether they could deliver if they quoted a price and a time. It is of tremendous importance for a company to be able to do that and to have some confidence in its ability to communicate with the workers and get a result. Even Senator Crane would agree that it is important if a company can get that sort of cooperation.

One small section of the journal article quoted a crane driver. I would have fainted if I had read this 10 years ago. The crane driver said that he was going to start a welding course in the next week. So here we have a crane driver who will be trained to weld. He will be able to drive a truck and he will learn certain basic skills in areas which he would have never thought possible. That initiative was taken by the Metal Workers Union and the Iron Workers Union, not by the employer. The employer would not have dared looked at or touched that area. So that is a situation in which there is an enterprise agreement, where there is enterprise cooperation. Members who are part of a larger union of almost 200,000 members are able to operate within that enterprise in a cooperative way, having consideration for their future and recognising that the employer has some rights and responsibilities too, and they were able to make a success of it. It does not have to be a little defenceless union.

As to this proposition of enterprise unions, Senator Walters says, from a position of ignorance, that we should have thousands of enterprise unions. Do honourable senators know any sensible, intelligent employer who is not part of an employers organisation which can give advice on award conditions; how to negotiate; and how to handle any matters relating to employment? I do not. I know some dopey employers who are not members of such an organisation, but I do not know of any intelligent ones. They are all members of organisations and they are all fairly well served.

In the same way, workers are entitled to have that sort of representation, by unions which are of such a size that they can finance and carry through the sorts of programs that will train shop stewards so that when they talk to an employer--who almost always has beside him an industrial officer from a Metal Trades Industry Association, the Chamber of Commerce, or a similar organisation--they also can have their trade adviser with them. They are entitled to be in an organisation that will have enough finance available for the sort of training that will equip them to negotiate in their own right; so that they can make comparisons of the way in which operations take place in other workshops of a similar kind or that may employ people with similar skills but which may produce quite a different product. Of course, workers are entitled to that.

If we want to make small enterprise unions--some with only four or five unions--then we deny the worker his right to organise and to be trained and properly represented. For that reason, we say that enterprise unions are a device meant to deny workers of their rights. It is a device which is intended to get the most work for the least possible pay by the employer. There is nothing evil about that; one cannot go to gaol for such a thing. But I can assure honourable senators this: the trade union movement will not let it happen. Within the legislation that this Government proposes--and some of the ideas that are included in the statement--we will be maintaining and improving the unions in terms of size and their capacity to operate on behalf of the workers. At the same time--and I repeat--there will be no problem with working within an enterprise by way of dealing with the local shop steward and by way of an enterprise agreement.

We have a particular view on training. My mind goes back to the years when employers used to train people in what they called skills. They trained people sufficiently to do what they wanted them to do. They may have had a very limited production line or a particular task to carry through or a product to make; and that is all they ever did. Of course, when they shut down they sacked those workers and the workers' ability to get another job was very limited because they had not been trained properly. If they were fortunate enough to have an apprenticeship with a good employer who was proud of his training capacity, they were okay; but if they were not fortunate, the employer, left to his own devices, undertrained people and exploited them for years.

We are saying now that we want training that provides the skills that will increase productivity and get a better level of quality--and that is what we are about. We are about total quality control. We do not take the view, `Let's get a thousand of these items out the end of the line' and then when we have a look, find that there is a 50 per cent rejection rate. We want a rejection rate of one per cent or less. We want to build quality into the product. We want to build pride into the workmanship of the people who produce the product. That is quite different to the attitude of employers in the past. Some of them are now waking up to that.

The trade union movement will not cop--and this Government does not expect it to--a situation where only limited training is given. We are happy about additional training, either at the workplace if people have the facilities and the skills, or in institutions such as TAFE. We are saying that when that training is done, it has to be recognised and it has to carry qualifications with it. We do not want the situation of the employers providing the level of training that suits them, but which does not give any rights or any rewards to the workers who have done that training.

I return to the question of confrontation in terms of agreement and award making. For years, the employers used to make demands and say, `We want settlement of disputes in our agreement'. I used to look at them with horror and say, `Why would you want that? Why do you not have a prevention of disputes clause in your award? Why do you not put together a process whereby, with consultation, you do not have a dispute?'. That shows that the trade unions had a very positive view; they did not want disputes. Anybody who believes that workers want to go on strike has to be very, very stupid; there is possibly the odd exception. I do not say for one minute that every worker I have ever known or am likely to meet is perfect, totally honest and intelligent. I guess employers also have more than their share of people who do not qualify in that regard.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Haven't got anyone like Wally Curran.

—-Again, Wally Curran is mentioned. He is a bloke who has battled for years for his members in Victoria, as other meat work officials have in other parts of the State. But of course, if Wally Curran is involved in a dispute and the community is affected, everybody wants to come down on Wally. They do not say too much about employers putting kangaroo meat in boxes and sending it overseas and bringing us into disrepute. I have not heard the Liberals or the Nationals going crook about that.

SPEECH.PARA: But again Wally Curran is only one person in the trade union movement. If somebody is seen as giving an opportunity for criticism from those on the other side, they never stop pounding that one person mercilessly. They never want to look at the other side of the ledger where people have actually gone on to the job--and I have actually done it myself--and prevented a strike that employers were too stupid not to let happen. We never hear about that. We always hear of somebody doing something that might not be seen by the community as correct or based in equity or a good case being made by the trade union movement.

I have not met an intelligent trade union official, anybody in the Labor Party or anybody in the Government, who does not believe that the community out there is made up of very important people. The Party and the Government want to put into place the sort of legislation which will guarantee continued productivity at the highest possible level. We do not want to inconvenience anybody but rather we want to give recognition and we want to get reasonable wages and reasonable conditions under which to work. The accord, which has been a resounding success, has provided not only that sort of situation but also a fairly subdued demand in terms of wages to the extent that, as a result, labour costs have been reduced by some 10 per cent.

As I said, the Party and the Government want to put in place legislation which will provide for that sort of continuous production and prosperity in the community. The trade unions themselves also want a position where their members can work constantly, consistently and in reasonable conditions. There is no way that they want confrontation or disputes because their members only lose money. That is not a very smart way to operate.

But if there is an issue such as the workers being attacked by unscrupulous employers--supported by an unthinking, foolish Liberal Party--then they will stand and fight in a way that will have the least possible effect on the community. That has always been my attitude and the attitude of officials that I have known. Let us consider what is going to happen in terms of community problems; that is, certain services and goods might not be available. Let us try to use every opportunity we can to avoid having a dispute so that we do not have lost time and we do not have to cut off supplies or anything else. That has been our attitude.

For so many years trade unions were hoodwinked when asked to leave particular people on a job in a dispute. The employers would use those people to try to defeat the dispute. But we got to the stage where we did not trust them and we used to say, `Sorry, we can make no allowance; everybody comes off the job'. But we did say that we would have somebody available for any emergency, any problem within the workshop when other people were working there or within the community. Quite often those people whom the employers had said were imperative to keep on the job were never asked to do a thing. That was always a dishonest approach by the employers who were trying to take advantage of the trade union movement.

I know these things because I experienced them. I know the history because I was part of making that history. I did not read it out of books. I did not have somebody ring me up and tell me how I should attack anybody else's opposition. I am very pleased with the statement that the Minister has made. I will continue to work within the trade union movement, with the people that I know and within the Government to enhance a situation we have got where, even though there is a great deal of structural unemployment--

TALK.START.PARA: —-One million unemployed.

—-Yes, it is true that there is a lot of structural unemployment and there will be more. We have to go out there and create jobs of a different kind in other areas. We can only do that, of course, if we develop the capacity to export. Again, many employers have a great deal of skill in that area and they have applied those skills and done very well; but there are other employers who are totally hopeless.

SPEECH.PARA: There is the question of people who need finance for real productive, wealth making enterprises but who cannot get it; whereas if somebody wants to put up a 50-storey building and rent it commercially they can get all the money they like. There are certain fundamental truths that even Senator Bishop would not disagree with; I will have to find them. I will close on that note and congratulate the Minister. I will dedicate myself to creating an even better position in the future where there can be prosperity for everybody in this community; that is, where we make a bigger cake in which everybody gets a bigger share and we build the sort of trust that we need in this country for the type of prosperity that the Minister and his colleagues, including myself, seek through this sort of statement and legislation to follow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —-This debate began with the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) reading what I can only describe as eight pages of turgid prose which was meant to pass for a ministerial statement.
