I suppose we can be quite relieved that indeed he did not attempt to do it in Question Time and actually had the decency to do it outside that, unlike Senator Button who went on at great length today. Senator Burns said there might be something that he and I could agree upon. Well there is. He said that there were going to be more than one million unemployed. I certainly agree with the policies of this Government that we are going to see more than one million people who are in unemployment.

SPEECH.PARA: Looking at the document itself consisting of eight pages of turgid prose--which really says very little, as Senator Bell said earlier on--one could say that the first five pages of it were a sort of preamble which summed up why we have lost production in this country and one could say that it recites strike action and work practices which encourage absenteeism, sick leave and accidents. He tries to argue in the first part of the paper that strikes are not very relevant to lost productivity but that sick leave, accidents and absenteeism are major causes of lost productivity.

The Minister could, of course, have taken the opportunity in this paper to answer the splendid question which Senator Vanstone asked him yesterday and which he was incapable of answering. Her question very simply stated:
Why has productivity growth in Australia been so dismally low under the various accords?
In her supplementary question, when Senator Cook had failed to answer her question, she reiterated the point she wanted to have addressed and stated as follows:

Do I take it that the Minister denies that productivity growth--GDP per hour--has been markedly less on average under the Hawke Government than it was under the Fraser Government? Does he deny that it has fallen in six of the last nine quarters? How does he explain its being so poor compared with the OECD performance? How does he explain its being so poor compared with the performance of our Asian trading partners?
Then Senator Vanstone came back to her original question:
. . . why has productivity growth in Australia been so dismally low if the accord is so good?

Senator Cook, instead of trying to answer those sensible questions, seems to say that the accord has been the greatest thing since sliced bread; that the Government has done a magnificent job; and the fact that we now have one million people unemployed, a huge international debt and a recession that this Government's policy has engineered is somehow a result of the excellent policies in the economic and industrial relations area.
Page 5 of the paper actually says:
In all the circumstances, it is appropriate that the Government should now express a view. . .

I am sure we would all be very pleased if the Government really did express a view. But the turgid prose in which this paper is couched or, as my colleagues Senator Walters and, I think, Senator Durack said earlier, the rather strangled language is really a masterpiece of dissembling, because what it is really all about is a reactionary statement.

If one goes through and digs out the odd phrase, one will find that it really means to amend section 115; that it means to create the right to strike; and that it means to abolish sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act. In other words, it is aimed at getting rid of common law rights. Senator Cook could have saved us all the trouble by saying what he wanted in three paragraphs, instead of eight pages of diatribe and statements which are dressed up to make it sound reasonable. But be under no illusions; that is what this statement is about. Senator Cook says in his last paragraph:
The system will be reformed so as to accommodate these essential conditions.
According to him, the essential conditions are to ensure that the framework is changed so that bargaining can be done freely and jointly so as not to damage the public interest.

Our policy is about having enterprise bargaining which is done freely and without duress. It has the radical concept that employees should actually be allowed to talk to employers without the intervention of third parties to either harass or impede the negotiations. It has the radical thought in it about the ability to negotiate freely, with the existing system remaining in place for those people who wish to remain in it. But, for those people who do not, they have two alternatives. As I said, they can have that magnificent concept of being able to talk to each other and work out something that suits each other with a built-in guarantee in the system that nobody will be exploited. It will also leave in place section 115 agreements so that for those people who like to have an agreement which is registered, such as large corporations who have chosen to use it, it will still be available. But, most importantly, not only will we have freedom in the workplace but also we will have true freedom of association.

In his statement, and indeed in other press releases he has put out, Senator Cook likes to cite the ILO and likes to cite the conventions concerning freedom of association. But true freedom of association also guarantees that we have the freedom not to associate with people with whom we do not wish to be associated. The Government cannot have it both ways. De facto compulsory unionism in this country, as distinct from de jure compulsory trade unionism, has resulted in our industrial relations system being rigid, being unable to attract the right sort of investment and being uncompetitive. It has left us in a situation where we have run up huge international debt. With this tailor-made recession, which was the Government's way of trying to bring down our import bill, we have managed to land a million people out of jobs. That means families who are unable to pay the mortgage; kids who are unable to go to excursions in school; kids who cannot have a new uniform. It means a whole range of hardship being imposed upon 10.2 per cent of the population.
Senator Cook has brought down a statement which states that since 1983 the Government, by its reforms, has brought about valuable change. He states:
The purpose of this statement to the Parliament is to explain how the process will continue.

If that gives joy to a single constituent, I will be amazed. A continuation of that process means higher unemployment, greater debt, low productivity and basically Australia losing its standard of living.

It is the Opposition which offers freedom of the workplace and deregulation of the workplace which will make it attractive to investment. This will mean that we will get examples such as we had in the SPC case, where once work practices were changed--because the company was about to go into liquidation-- it brought about huge changes and improvements in productivity. We have seen the examples at Robe River, which Minister Cook likes to try to malign and likes to try to tell this Parliament has been a vexatious litigant. The only trouble is that, when he sets out his facts, he gets them wrong and he misleads this Parliament. Indeed, when we see that the purpose of this statement is to explain how the process will continue, I think that most readers would find a chill in the heart.

But as I read on I find other things that raise more questions. I read that the Government has allocated $40m of taxpayers' money to the workplace reform program. How is that money being spent? To whom has the money been allocated for spending? Did it end up in trade union pockets? Where is the accountability for the expenditure? I ask a similar question when I read on page 4:
The Government has established the Australian best practice demonstration program. . .
It states:
It has allocated $25m to this program.

Again, I would like to see the manner in which it is being expended. If we could achieve a best practice or a best international standard being accepted in the workplace in Australia as what we must and will aspire to, then perhaps that would be a well spent amount of money. But I will be most interested to see the accountability and the accounting for that $25m and the results that flow and are verifiable. I am intrigued by the sentence:

Only those enterprises which can demonstrate that they are prepared to undertake a comprehensive reform and restructuring program within a reasonable timeframe will be eligible to take part in the scheme and share in its rewards.
I am interested to know what sorts of criteria will be used to see that the best practice demonstration program achieves anything at all. Senator Cook then goes on in his statement to say:
Having put the foundations in place, the Government has to consider the structure of the system to be built on them.

I think the foundations are crumbling. I am afraid the Minister's foundations have been built in the sand. As we go on to look at why it might be built on that foundation, I think it does not augur well for the productivity of this nation.

I am tempted to say that almost all the contributions today have contained more substance than this paper itself. It does not mean to say that I agree with all the statements that have been made. Certainly, I would not agree with those that have come from across the chamber; nonetheless even Senator Burns had something of substance to say when he pointed out that we are going to have more than one million people unemployed.

I can only take it that the Minister has decided to bring down this statement as a precursor to a more, shall we say, militant campaign to bring about the things that I said could have been expressed in three paragraphs, that is, his intention to amend section 115 and the way the agreements are registered. The hint to that is given on page 6 where he makes the statement that the IRC should have a role at the entry point of the process of both negotiations and registration of section 115 agreements. He has put out press releases, particularly the one on 2 September which stated that there was a need to have a right to strike. That is obviously buried in this dissembling document, together with his aim of abolishing sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act, which the Government tried to do previously but the Democrats had the good sense not to succumb. I am sure that they will hold to that position, or I sincerely hope they will. Of course, the overall aim is to abolish common law rights, which have introduced some fairness into what has been a very unfair system of industrial relations.

I suppose I should not be surprised at the nature of this statement--after all, Senator Cook was the secretary of the Trades and Labour Council in Western Australia before he was transposed into the Senate. We have had much cause in this chamber to wonder, when he stands and speaks on industrial relations, whether he speaks as a Minister of the Crown with the interests of all Australians at heart or whether he still speaks with the intransigence of a trade union master, because the power of the trade unions has indeed been very strong. It is only now that we have entered into a new phase where we are seeing a deregulation of the centralised wage fixing system and the devolving of functions onto enterprises so that we can indeed begin to see the hope of freedom in negotiations. We hope that after the imposed recession those people who are left in employment and those one million people who are without jobs and who will still be endeavouring to find them will have the opportunity to work in places where they will have a say in the conditions and the employment terms instead of having them imposed upon them. That is something that many thousands of Australians will look forward to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I rise to speak on the paper entitled Reforming the Industrial Relations System. Upon reading it, one cannot but come to the conclusion that about seven and a half of the eight pages are rhetoric and gobbledegook. It is very unfortunate that a paper of this nature--which fails to address the issues and is full of cliches--has been brought down. I have tried to analyse what it says, and I have come to the conclusion that, firstly, it will amend section 115 of the Industrial Relations Act to make it freer than it is currently. One must say that, under the current system, that is an improvement. But, against that, we also find the intention to introduce the right to strike. The paper is strangely silent on common law and sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act, in particular. But, reading between the lines, one can only conclude that they are certainly not off the agenda.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to make a few comments about the right to strike. I do so in the context of our Constitution, which expressly states that the Commonwealth has a responsibility to prevent strikes, yet in this paper we see a statement about the right to strike. I would suggest that in fact that is in conflict with our Constitution. How does the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook) reconcile the right to strike with his constitutional responsibility?

The Minister spent much time on absenteeism and sickness. Nobody denies that they are important and that they are a cost to industry; but they are State matters. The Minister does not address how he intends to deal with these matters in the context of the required negotiations with the State governments. Once again, the paper falls short in this area. The next point I come to in this area--it is very similar to the national wage case--is that we are currently awaiting the decision of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission with regard to the future of wage fixing policy. Why has the Government introduced this at this time? Does the Government intend to pre-empt the decision of its own Industrial Relations Commission? I have often been critical of the Commission in this place but, nonetheless, it is the Government's policy to have an Industrial Relations Commission. Will the Government agree with the recommendations which come from the current inquiry only if they happen to agree with the Government's position? I believe that is a very valid question which should be answered by the Government. Why waste taxpayers' money going through the process of having these inquiries if the decision has been made already?

I now turn to productivity. I have searched this document--albeit not as thoroughly as I would have liked--and I have found the words `productivity' or `production' have been mentioned only three times. Following what Senator Bishop said about Senator Vanstone's question and the answer we received yesterday, it would seem to me that, in reforming the industrial relations policy, it is absolutely essential and imperative that the issue of productivity be addressed.

I have already mentioned sections 45D and 45E of the Trade Practices Act. I think it is now incumbent upon the Minister to make a clear statement as to exactly where the Government stands on this issue. One would have thought, in view of his previous comments, that it would have been addressed this time. In terms of industrial relations policy, it is very important that common law rights apply in all parts--not just selected parts--of society.
I will now touch on a number of points in the paper. I turn to the statement which says:
The Accord between the ACTU and the Government has been enormously beneficial in many ways.

I say, as I have said before, that the accord has promoted mediocrity. What has been produced while the accord has been in place? Let us analyse it. There has been a blow-out in our national debt of some $110 billion net. From a figure of just over $20 billion--which we reached 82 years after Federation--it has reached in the order of $135 billion net in just eight more years. What has the Government done about productivity? That matter has already been touched upon and I will not dwell on it, but it came out very clearly in Senator Vanstone's question yesterday.

What else has the accord produced? A recession we had to have according to the former Treasurer. Yesterday, while overseas, the Treasurer made the statement that this is the worst recession since the Great Depression of the 1930s. We have record unemployment and record bankruptcies. I believe it is totally irresponsible for the Minister to write in a paper:
The accord between the ACTU and the Government has been enormously beneficial in many ways.

Just ask those people who have had to pay record interest rates; ask those people who are unemployed and those people who are bankrupt. Think for a moment of our children and our grandchildren who will have to repay the debt we now have in this country.
We now move to the top of page 3 and find this extraordinary statement:
The 1991 Australian workplace industrial relations survey--the most comprehensive, up-to-date survey available--found that 72 per cent of workplaces had never had any industrial action.

That is a totally predictable statement because 80 per cent of union members are employed by the top 100 companies in this country and only approximately 33 per cent of employees are members of a union.

I must comment on the words `ideological marginalia'. Like honourable senators on the other side of the chamber, I do not understand what it means. We have asked a number of them and they do not understand, and I doubt whether Senator Faulkner knows what it means. The definition in the dictionary is, `marginal notes'. When that definition in used in place of the word `marginalia' it does not make sense.
I refer to page 4 of the statement, which says:

The Government has established the Australian Best Practice Demonstration Program as a catalyst in this process. It has allocated $25 million to this program which is designed to illustrate the productivity gains . . .

I refer to Robe River. In four years it has had a 320 per cent increase in productivity. Why are we not looking at those companies and those operations in Australia that have increased their productivity? Why are we not introducing the reforms that they have made so we can get them across the board? We can then start producing real wealth; we can start producing jobs, because jobs flow from wealth; and we can start producing profits. If we are going to overcome unemployment, we must have profit, we must have incentive and we must have reward in the workplace.

Robe River has been described by the Minister as a vexatious litigant. I remind the Senate that for every appeal that it has made there has been an application lodged first. Robe River has been the catalyst for the reform of the iron ore industry in Western Australia, including such companies as Hamersley Iron Pty Ltd. Robe River Mining overcame the problem of work practices--there were in excess of 250 removed--and the problems of weak management. It now has stability in employment. We have had some debate in this place with respect to the situation of Cape Lambert Services and West Tug. When the Seamen's Union went on strike over that particular issue, not one employee of Robe River supported it.
I refer to Senator Cook's answer to me today. I will put the documentation down when I am ready. I am also giving him the opportunity to correct his mistakes. Page 5 of the document states:
The Confederation of Australian Industry and the Business Council of Australia have both recently put forward reform proposals . . .
That is indeed true. It is also worth noting that they have both rejected the accord. The next paragraph states:
Indeed, accord mark VI committed the Government and the unions in February last year . . .

Since the Government has adopted its position, how many unions have taken the decision of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission, taken the 2.5 per cent, and got on with the job? How much time has been lost as a result of those unions that did not and took industrial action to try to get the provisions of accord mark VI put in place? A classic example of this exists in the meat industry, particularly in Victoria. I will deal with that at a later time in another speech. The document further states:
Workplace agreements should be reached fairly and freely.

Nobody will argue with that. The difference between the policy position of the Opposition and that of the Government is that an individual or a small group of individuals will not have the right to negotiate fairly and freely under the Government's policy. It is a very fundamental difference. They will not have that right under the Government's policy. They will under the Opposition's policy. They can choose for themselves--once again freedom--whether they want to be represented by a union or by an industrial advocate. Similarly, the employer can choose whether he wants to be represented by his employer organisation or represent himself. That is what freedom is all about. Page 7 states:

There should be no industrial action during the life of the agreement over matters that are the subject of the agreement. Equally, the parties should, subject to reasonable conditions, be able to have resort to certain forms of industrial action in periods of negotiating new workplace agreements.

That is where the right to strike proposals come in. Once again, I pose several questions. Is the Government going to legislate for no industrial action during the life of the agreement? Is the Government going to legislate for the right to strike while negotiating new workplace agreements? Is it going to legislate in total to cover all situations? This document is not clear on that.

Page 7 also refers to the ILO Committee of Experts on the Application of Conventions and Recommendations and the ILO Convention No. 87, which allows for freedom of association for individuals or small groups. There is no restriction on numbers. They can be whatever size they want to be. More importantly, the report from the ILO Committee of Experts is subject to employer redress in 1992. In other words, it is an overview. The Minister, in hanging his argument for the necessity of these changes on that, is pre-empting the outcome of that overview. The last page states:
The Government has been consulting widely on this issue for some time, particularly in the National Labour Consultative Council . . .

Who are the members of the Labour Consultative Council? The Confederation of Australian Industry and the ACTU. Those who are not members of the Labour Consultative Council include the Metal Trades Industry Association, the Chamber of Manufactures, the National Farmers Federation, the Australian Federation of Construction Contractors, the Australian Bankers Association and the Australian Road Transport Industry Association, to name but a few. They are very important employer organisations in their own right. I have no doubt that there will be unions which are not members of the ACTU. If there are, where will their input come from?

This paper falls far short of what is required in addressing the various aspects of industrial relations policy in Australia: in productivity; where people are unfortunate enough not to have a job; and where people are on the brink of bankruptcy who could, with proper policies, become strong employers. We have consistently heard from Government senators about exploitation of workers. What absolute nonsense!

I will not deny that in the last century and beyond workers were exploited. However, under our policy, workers still have the option to remain in the centralised system, but they also have total freedom to negotiate as individuals or groups with or without the support of their union or their employer organisation. Surely, that is what voluntary unionism and ILO Convention No. 87 are all about.

This ministerial statement could have been summarised succinctly in one page. Then we would all have been a lot better off and had a much clearer direction of where he is going. I re-emphasise that the statement does not address the problems of absenteeism and sickness in the workplace. The Minister does not spell out how he will tackle this problem with the States. The statement puts in place this determinant of the right to strike. That is in conflict with Australia's Constitution. The Minister should look carefully at what he is doing as a Minister by bringing before this place such a recommendation which is in conflict with the Constitution of this great country of ours.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-This statement by the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook, has brought praise from the Government and some condemnation from the Opposition. That is to be expected because it is on industrial relations, perhaps more than any other issue, that the parties in this place differ. It comes down to a concept of what one makes or does not make of people and what the reality of life is or is not. For example, the presumption that people are always in an equal bargaining position goes against experience and the sorts of provisions that we have in the law. Even the Trade Practices Act contains a provision that talks about unconscionable conduct. Senator Crane said that all the problems in the workplace have now gone and this is no longer the nineteenth century. It is certainly not the nineteenth century, but there are still plenty of problems in the workplace in the twentieth century.

SPEECH.PARA: I quote as evidence for that assertion the actions that used to be brought under section 119 of what was the Conciliation and Arbitration Act, which is now the Industrial Relations Act. My family eats a better quality dinner on Sunday than it otherwise would because we went to the Federal Court and sued for wages owed to people who worked in all sorts of industries. That sort of action was quite common in the courts. It illustrates the difficulties in the workplace and that there are still ongoing problems in the employer-employee relationship. A proper balance has to be established. It is true the employer can be harsh with the employee and the employee can be harsh with the employer, but some sort of system has to be set up--the sort of system that can be examined again and again as a result of changing relationships and new provisions being needed.

In the ministerial statement, the Minister has set out a basis for debate. He has done that successfully; what we have had today is a debate. There are some problems about some concepts that have been put forward today: for example, the question of freedom of bargaining, that people should have the freedom to choose how they go about things and that an employer should be able to negotiate with an employee on equal terms. On some occasions a person might have a rare skill. For example, if that person was a doctor who had a particular knowledge of some sort of pharmaceutical product that a company wanted and needed, the doctor would be in a very strong position to negotiate a good agreement. However, if a person did not have such a skill or had skills that are plentiful, that person would be in a weak bargaining position unless that person proceeded as part of a group or a union.

There is a statement that is worth putting into the debate. It is a statement that small nations used when they were approaching the more powerful nations in the United Nations--`It is just as unjust to treat unequals as equals as it is to treat equals as unequals'. Unfortunately, there is a tendency in this debate to treat unequals as equals. That can have a devastating effect, especially on people who want to offer themselves for work and who cannot find it in today's market and also on people who, if they were alone, would be tempted to accept poor conditions and wages. That does happen; it is happening in the community at the moment. We have inspectors under the Act to ensure adherence to awards. The fact that those inspectors find breaches of awards from time to time is a strong indication of the problem.

I also want to talk about the accord. It has been blamed today for the economic disasters the country is undergoing. Senator Crane said it was the cause of all our bankruptcies and high inflation and unemployment rates. At least we have identified what the Opposition sees as the cause of all our economic problems. I am interested to learn that. I should have thought there might have been other causes such as low world commodity prices; the European community and America throwing their grain on the world markets for next to nothing; the conduct of the financial institutions during the 1980s; and the rate of our imports compared with our exports.

I have been assured by inference that none of those things have caused our problems; that the only cause for the financial disaster of this country is the accord. No doubt Senator Crane did not have time to produce the evidence, but it will be interesting to see how he and his colleagues in the Opposition produce the evidence that the one cause of Australia's economic problems is the accord.

The right to strike has also been mentioned. Whether or not one agrees with that right, Australia, in effectively not allowing the right to strike, stands in isolation. There is a right to strike in England. There is a right to strike even in New Zealand. The fact that there is no such right here ought to be discussed, hopefully with some result.

Sections 45D and 45E have been discussed. I always find it difficult to reconcile those sections being in an Act of Parliament which has everything to do with consumer protection and with the encouragement of competition in the marketplace. It is strange that there should be two sections in the Act--sections 45D and 45E--which are aimed not at protecting competition in the marketplace, and not at consumer protection but at a specific process.

It should be of concern to people in this chamber that we have an Act of Parliament, the Trade Practices Act, which has these sections awkwardly put in. Those two sections are awkward because, as I say, they punish conduct as distinct from the rest of the Act, which does not punish conduct but protects competition and consumers. Why we should disturb the symmetry of the Act by doing that, I am not sure.

Clearly, if the sections are to be in legislation at all they should be in legislation other than the Trade Practices Act. They should be in a comprehensive set of legislation which gives some logical sense to where they are put. Of course, if they are put in a piece of legislation that deals with relationships in the workplace where there is a particular process of carrying them out, that would constitute some offence, although I will be arguing over the next few months--subject, of course, to being convinced otherwise--that they are the sorts of sections that would be better out of the industrial relations field altogether.

Senator Crane also spoke about common law. He spoke of that as something that is sacrosanct. Of course, it is not. The very evidence that it is not sacrosanct is the fact that we, day after day, legislate in here and State parliaments legislate in their respective States to modify it in some way.

TALK.START.PARA: —-They usually muck it up, too.

—-I agree with Senator Durack on that. I think the reason it is mucked up at times is that common law is not fully understood. In this area, in the area where the common law deals with industrial relationships, there are unhappy legacies. I think the reason for that is that the common law was developed--as the Trade Practices Act was--in terms of commercial practice and in terms of protecting trade, and the common law dealing with industrial disputes was grafted on to that in the wrong context.

SPEECH.PARA: It will be interesting to see how this debate ends. I congratulate the Minister for bringing this matter before the Parliament. I hope that after proper debate there will be a more effective industrial relations set-up than there presently is.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I wish to speak very briefly in this debate on the statement on reforming the industrial relations systems by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Senator Cook). I had not intended to, but I am prompted by remarks made by my colleague Senator Cooney. He raised the question of whether people on this side think that the whole problem of Australia's economy is the accord--and that that is the only problem--the implication being that everyone thinks that. I think Senator Cooney has misunderstood the argument that has been put. I would like to put some points to Senator Cooney that he might like to consider.

SPEECH.PARA: The first point is this: the accord is not responsible for everything that is wrong with the Australian economy, but it is responsible for restricting Australian workers and employers in being able to get together and make negotiated agreements amongst themselves that we say would result in greater productivity than can possibly result from the current centralised system. That is why we say that on coming to office we will change the system to allow those people who want to stay in the centralised system to do so and those who want to shift out to do that and, therefore, make much more productive agreements. We say that that is what will happen.

When I was first elected to this chamber the Government said that enterprise bargaining was totally out--it was just not acceptable and it would never move down that track. What I have seen in the 6 1/2 years that I have been here is a slow progression towards the coalition's industrial relations policy. This is just another step in that direction. I have full confidence that it will not be long before our policy is implemented.

I also want to refer to the first page of the Minister's statement and the fourth paragraph, in which he says that one of the problems with the debate in this area is that it focuses attention on the amount of working time lost.

I agree with that. That is not the only aspect one wants to consider. Many people have made contributions in that respect during this debate, pointing out that time lost is not lost only through disputes or bans. An enormous amount of time is lost through industrial accidents. I have a particular interest in that area because of my own interest in drug testing in the workplace, and the problems that legal and illegal drugs contribute towards absenteeism and accidents in the workplace. I understand that.

The Minister goes on to say that paying attention to the working time lost is a mistake if we do not look at how productive the time is that we spend at work. That was exactly the point that I put to the Minister yesterday in a question, and exactly the point that he was incapable of answering. I asked him: why has this Government put wage restraint through the accord on Australian workers yet failed to implement the other policies? It has failed to implement not only a changed industrial relations system but also other policies that would allow productivity to improve.

One needs only to look at the fact that, of the last nine quarters, six have had a negative productivity growth. The average productivity growth under the Hawke Government has been significantly worse than during the Fraser years. If the Minister is interested in how productive the time we spend at work is, he should have something to say about why the system that this Government has implemented has resulted in a fall-off in that sense, because average growth in productivity is not as good.

If one compares us with OECD countries one sees that the situation is not attractive at all. The productivity growth that they have achieved between 1983 and 1990 is almost double the productivity growth that this nation has achieved. If one does not want to compare us with OECD nations, one can compare us with the Asian nations that we trade with, such as the Republic of Korea and Hong Kong. One would see that, while we have been struggling to get up to, say, 4 per cent productivity growth over a limited period, they have been booming ahead with productivity growth at 10 per cent.

That is the question that this Government needs to answer. If it is so wedded to the accord, why has the industrial relations system under the accord not produced greater productivity? One answer is that it is not flexible enough. The other answer is that the Government has steadfastly failed and refused to introduce the other policies that might allow wage restraint under the accord to be turned into productivity growth.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —-In accordance with the provisions of the Audit Act 1901, I present the report of the Auditor-General No. 9 of 1991-92, Project Audits, Department of Veterans' Affairs.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-by leave--I present the report of the Defence Subcommittee of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on a visit by the Subcommittee to Adelaide.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —-by leave--I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.
I seek leave to incorporate the tabling statement in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows--

On behalf of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, I present the report of the Committee entitled Report on the Visit of the Defence Sub-Committee of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade to Adelaide.

In July the Defence Sub-Committee inspected defence facilities in the Adelaide area. These inspections were made in accordance with the tradition of the Defence Sub-Committee of conducting familiarisation visits for its Members.

The Sub-Committee visited RAAF Edinburgh where it was briefed on the surveillance role of the Long Range Maritime Patrol aircraft, the P3C Orions. The visit afforded Members the opportunity to gain first hand knowledge on the Patrol's search and rescue function. Members were able to gain some appreciation of the equipment used in carrying out search and rescue, particularly in light of the attempted rescue of the crew of the yacht Rockin' Robin last year.

Through the discussions with the Commander Maritime Patrol Group Air Commodore Staff James AFC we were also able to obtain a better understanding of the events surrounding the loss of the Orion aircraft in the Cocos Islands.

The visit fulfilled its aim of keeping Members up-to-date with developments in technology in Defence equipment. The Sub-Committee inspected a P3C Orion at RAAF Edinburgh where it was briefed on the aircraft's computer-based sensor system, the Barra Sonobuoy and the AGM-84 Harpoon. This was complemented by a briefing at DSTO on the project for the refurbishment of the Orion.

At RAAF Edinburgh we were also interested to ascertain the percentages of aircraft undergoing maintenance and `on line' at any given time. We gained a clearer understanding of the nature of the maintenance program and of the tests conducted on, for example, the F/A-18 Hornet and the Black Hawk helicopter by the Aircraft Research and Development Unit (ARDU).
During the visit to DSTO we were briefed on the impact of the Force Structure Review on DSTO and the approach adopted by the Organisation to accommodate the changes to their operations.

We also received briefings on a number of major projects in train at DSTO such as DORIC, the KARIWARA Towed Array Project and the support provided by DSTO to Operation DAMASK during the Gulf War. We were also interested in DSTO's task of adapting the RBS 70 for shipboard use, particularly as our visit to Adelaide included an inspection of the RBS 70 at Woodside Barracks.
At Woodside the Sub-Committee appreciated the opportunity to inspect closely both the RBS 70 Missile System and the Rapier Fire Unit which had been set up for the occasion.

Members of the Sub-Committee are concerned that the limited numbers of Rapiers held by 110 Air Defence Battery are insufficient to defend more than one vital asset or one airfield in northern Australia at a given time.
We were also concerned to learn that the numbers of missiles available for use by 110 Battery are inadequate for proving the ability of the equipment to fire.

We were told that 111 Air Defence Battery (Light) also suffers from receiving insufficient numbers of RBS 70 missiles for proving their equipment--the Battery receives an allocation of only 6 missiles per year.

Whilst in Adelaide we inspected the Submarine Project at the Australian Submarine Corporation's plant at Osborne. The inspection complemented another element of the Sub-Committee's program, that is, of receiving briefings on aspects of Defence or Defence support at our regular meetings in Canberra. Earlier this year the Managing Director of the Submarine Corporation had addressed Members on the Submarine Project. We were therefore interested to monitor progress on the construction of the submarine fleet.

Finally, the visit provided Members of the Sub-Committee with opportunities for informal discussions with Defence Force personnel. One such occasion was arranged at Keswick Barracks where discussions with Regular and Reserve personnel from Headquarters 4 Military District, 9 Brigade and 4 Training Group proved most productive.
I commend the report to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Tate) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-At the request of the Chairman of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, Senator Schacht, I present the report of the Committee on Australia's current account deficit and overseas debt, together with the minutes of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —-by leave--I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the report.
I seek leave to incorporate my tabling statement in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows--

On behalf of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, I present the Committee's report entitled Australia's Current Account Deficit and Overseas Debt, together with the minutes of proceedings.

The report contains not only an excellent description and analysis of Australia's position with regard to its current account deficit and overseas debt, but considers issues that go to the heart of the economic policy debate in Australia. Its recommendations are designed to comprehensively address the current account deficit in ways which would also reduce unemployment.

Current account deficits have been a feature of most of Australia's economic history. Over the 1980s, however, there was a marked increase in the relative size of that deficit. At the beginning of the decade, the deficit was less than 4 per cent of Gross Domestic Product (GDP). By the end of the decade, it had risen to around 6 per cent.

There was also a radical change in the nature of the current account deficit over the 1980s. At the beginning of the decade the current account deficit reflected primarily a trade deficit; by the end of the decade the current account deficit was overwhelmingly dominated by our foreign debt servicing obligations.
By international standards, Australia's current account deficit of GDP is amongst the highest of any Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) country.

The current account deficit fell to 4 per cent in 1990-91 and the recent continued decline is heartening. The improvement in Australia's export performance, particularly in relation to the growth in manufacturing exports, is most welcome.

The decline in imports, however, has been marginal and the situation concerning our debt servicing obligations and other income payments overseas has improved to an even smaller degree, despite the severity of the current recession.

So the Committee is concerned that the current account deficit will again return to high levels as Australia comes out of the recession. Unless concerted action is taken to address the underlying causes of Australia's high current account deficit, imports and foreign investment in Australia are likely to return to pre-recession levels.

There is considerable risk that Australia could become complacent about the current account deficit because of the reduction in its size over the past year. It must be remembered, however, that it has taken a very severe recession to halt the growth in imports and further declines in imports cannot be expected once the recession eases.

Australia's overseas debt also grew sharply during the 1980s, increasing more than tenfold to over $145 billion by 1989. It now stands at $165 billion--almost 44 per cent of GDP. While Australia's overseas debt has not yet reached the crisis proportions evident in some countries, it would certainly do so by the end of the l990s, if its debt accumulation were to continue unabated at the rate we have experienced, particularly in the mid-eighties.

In responding to the problems identified in the report, the Committee has rejected the calls made in some quarters for a return to protectionist policies and regulatory controls. In our view, such a course of action would only serve to reduce Australia's ability to adjust to changing global circumstances. Ultimately, a failure to make the necessary adjustments would reduce the living standards of all Australians.

Equally, the Committee has rejected the view that the growing current account deficit and overseas debt is no longer a problem requiring government action, as this debt has been largely incurred by the private sector which is responsible for its repayment.

While those who have incurred the debt are individually responsible for its servicing and repayment, there can be no question that Australia's vulnerability to global economic changes will be greater if debt accumulation continues unabated.
The market has clearly failed to respond to the situation. In the Committee's view, in the interests of efficiency and equity, it is therefore up to government to take the lead.

Against this background, the Committee has recommended a package of proposals designed to comprehensively address Australia's current account and overseas debt problems. The three main thrusts to these proposals are: :

to improve Australia's international trading performance through further reductions in tariff and other universal protectionist measures, while at the same time implementing a comprehensive package of positive measures to assist the development of Australia's export and import replacement industries, particularly those adding value to our exports;
to introduce a range of measures designed to increase domestic savings and reduce Australia's reliance on overseas borrowings to finance investment; and
to put in place a set of appropriate macroeconomic policy settings and necessary microeconomic reforms that are consistent with lowering the current account deficit and the level of overseas debt.
Amongst these are recommendations that real interest rates be reduced so as to encourage investment and a fall in the exchange rate.

I am confident that, if implemented, the Committee's recommendations will create the climate and conditions necessary to bring about substantial and sustained reductions in Australia's current account deficit and the level of our overseas debt. I urge the Government to quickly accept and implement the recommendations.

This inquiry was carried out by the Trade Sub-Committee and I am very grateful to my colleagues on the Sub-Committee for their contribution to this challenging task--particularly the Chairman, Mr Langmore, the Members for Berowra, Reid and New England and Senators Chapman, Beahan and Childs.

I also wish to thank the staff associated with the inquiry--Jane Vincent, the Secretary to the Sub-Committee, our advisers Greg Barrett, Tom Fitzgerald and especially Chris Robinson for his excellent analysis and drafting, Margaret Brown who provided administrative support and Jennifer Blood who took over as Secretary towards the end.
I commend the report to Honourable Senators.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I was intending to speak on the report of the Trade Subcommittee this evening. Before the suspension of the sitting for dinner, we were still discussing the industrial relations statement. We then had to deal with Government papers. I came into the chamber at about three minutes past eight and found that we had already gone past the report of the Trade Subcommittee of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. What is going on in this place?
—-The question was put and passed in relation to this matter. I understand that a motion to adjourn debate on that report was also adopted.

—-by leave--The report of the Trade Subcommittee of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade investigating Australia's current account deficit and overseas debt targets issues which are crucial to our national economic policy. I want to take only a few brief moments this evening on this matter.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, in speaking to the report, I thank all the Committee staff who were involved with us in very lengthy hearings and who contributed to the smooth operation of this inquiry. The inquiry was somewhat drawn out and involved and was conducted over about 18 months. Nevertheless, the proceedings were conducted very professionally. There were wide-ranging submissions--some 72 in total--which had to be considered in reaching the conclusions contained in this report.

There is no doubt that those submissions reflected very real, although broad, community concerns about our hefty overseas debt and the country's massive current account deficit. The conclusions and recommendations of the report do not have the full support of the Opposition members of the Trade Subcommittee or, indeed, of the full Joint Committee. As a consequence, we have produced our own minority report, which appears between pages 141 and 153 of the Committee's report.

Of the 25 main recommendations adopted by the Committee and contained in this report, only recommendations Nos. 1 and 8 have the support of the Opposition members. Recommendation No. 1 deals with the explicit taking account of the objective of reducing the current account deficit and the level of overseas debt and recommendation No. 8 relates to the introduction of an anti-dumping and countervailing duty system to ensure that Australian industries are fully protected from unfair import competition.

However, we do not believe that the remaining recommendations in this report are at all a suitable response to the issues that were under reference. In the view of the Opposition members, Australia urgently needs a comprehensive and complete program of policy reform to effect fundamental change to boost national production, productivity, savings and exports. This report does not sufficiently emphasise those issues and those requirements. As Deputy Chairman of the Trade Subcommittee, I want to reinforce the fact that our minority report, although it is brief, does include an extract from the current Treasury Budget Paper No. 1. We say of this in the report:

. . . examines developments in the 1980s and puts the case for relating economic policy more to the medium term and spells out a comprehensive package of policy and reform, notably labour market and micro economic reform--to which we would add tax reform--to achieve sustained low inflation, economic and employment growth, rising living standards and--
I stress this--
a reducing current account deficit, as specified in the terms of reference. It stresses the importance of making significant progress simultaneously on all these policy concerns.

We have two key difficulties in supporting this document in toto. They relate first to its inadequate underlying analytical framework. We believe that there is an excess of specific information on specific areas, such as merchandise trade, but a lack of information on other areas such as productivity. Secondly, there is difficulty in regard to the general questions that are often asked by people concerned about foreign debt which we believe were not effectively or efficiently addressed in the inquiry. I refer to questions such as, `What actually brought about the large and rapid increase in the nation's indebtedness over the past eight to 10 years?' and `It is said that because a large proportion of the debt is private rather than public that overseas debt is not a problem. Is this a proper view?'.

Such questions are commonly asked by people in the community about our foreign debt, yet they were not adequately addressed in this report. That is why we do not fully endorse its contents. Too much is left unanswered and unaddressed in the conclusions and recommendations. There is insufficient attention to detail with regard to the medium to longer term. We believe that this can best be addressed by specific reform agendas.

As we say in our minority report, Australia urgently needs an across the board program of reform to effect fundamental change. We need growth in gross domestic product of 3 1/4 per cent to 3 1/2 per cent in the medium term to take up some of the existing unemployment in Australia. With imports increasing at much the same rate, there is a need for a sustained increase in exports of the order of $4 billion each year for five to six years in order to effect the necessary transfer of resources to net exports and thus reduce the deficit to the more normal level of 2 1/2 per cent of GDP. We require that to happen if we are to stabilise the debt; that is, our net foreign liabilities to the ratio of gross domestic product. That will not allow us to reduce the foreign debt; it will simply allow us to stabilise it at about its present level.

We need to recognise that Australia has never before in its history achieved such a sustained transfer of gross domestic product and net growth into exports. That is an indication of massive challenge that this country faces if we are to do anything about the problem of foreign debt.

I want to reinforce the message, which is worth repeating and is emphasised in our minority report, that we need across the board programs of fundamental reform and changes if Australia's economy is to emerge in a healthy state in the coming decades. A reform that is required most importantly is that of the labour market. The pace of reform on the waterfront still remains inadequate. Reform is also required in land transport and in the tax system, which the coalition is committed to reform with its proposal for a goods and services tax and substantial income tax reductions--and so the list goes on.

We need a government that will not place obstacles to manufacturing or trade in our path. We must look much harder at the medium to longer term, not just to the short term, in terms of policy decisions. Each time a government interferes in our economy or in business activity it creates obstacles which make it increasingly difficult for growth and change.

In the past few years we have all been reminded of the great difficulties that macro-economic policy faces when economic events are unusually difficult to predict, where economic trends are not easily discernible and where policy responses operate with substantial and uncertain lags. Those circumstances will always confront in varying degree an internationally open economy such as Australia. This points to the advantages of relating policy more to the medium term and assigning policy instruments to their area of greater effectiveness. Such a framework would entail a close consideration of all aspects of monetary policy, fiscal policy and wages policy.

If we are to overcome the problems that are effectively detailed in this report we do not need the sort of interventionist approach that is recommended in the majority report. We need an approach which will remove impediments and obstacles to business and economic activity and which will enable this economy to produce efficiently and productively, as it will be capable of doing if those obstacles are removed, so that we can stabilise the debt which has developed to great proportions over the time that this Government has been in office.
I commend the report to the Senate with the reservations that I have highlighted. In particular, I commend the minority report and hope that it will bring about a wider understanding of these issues.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-by leave--I shall not detain the Senate for long because most of the topics that I intended to mention have already been eloquently dealt with by Senator Chapman. I was one of the dissenting signatories to the report. I commend the secretariat for its work on this subject, which is fundamental to the well-being of all Australians in terms of our current account deficit--or credit, as it could be--and our foreign debt. Those two issues are intertwined with each other and will hang around our necks unless we get the matter right.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I conclude my remarks by supporting what was said by Senator Chapman to the effect that we should seek to remove Government obstacles and restrictions to growth which affect our economy and the whole of our community. The position will not be fixed just by intervention and by creating yet another administrative group or bringing in another restriction. I firmly support the minority report. PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 10 October, on motion by Senator Sowada:
That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sowada Sen K.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I rise to say a few brief words on the Australian Research Council Awards report 1991. In this report are detailed grants made to tertiary education institutions by the Australian Research Council largely under the aegis of the Higher Education Funding Act 1988. Its charter ensures that funds are spread adequately through the higher education sector across disciplines to establish, in the words of the Council, `a broad research base in Australia'.

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Democrats fully support this concept. Whilst it is clear that the innovations, technological advantages and scientific breakthroughs going on at our universities are an important element of helping to improve our international competitiveness and agricultural productivity, it is essential that a diverse research program be pursued in tandem with seeking to meet so-called national goals and priorities established by government policy. Research projects should not be rejected on the grounds that they fail some long or short term financial criteria or that there is no perceived economic benefit to Australia as a whole. Science, technology and development research is all very well but should not be pursued at the expense of the humanities and social sciences, which help improve the quality of life and add valuable insights into the history, function and nature of human relationships.

Secondly, I highlight the relatively small growth in the size of budgetary allocations for Australian postgraduate research awards outlined in the report. An amount of $38.2m was expended in 1990 and has increased to $42.7m in 1991, representing a 12 per cent increase in funding. I note that the Government offered 1,000 new awards this year, an increase of 100 on 1990, which is to be commended.

However, this in no way meets the demand for these scholarships. Nearly 4,000 of our best and brightest undergraduates applied for postgraduate scholarships this year, an increase of nearly 25 per cent on 1990 applications. The selection criteria is extremely high and narrow. Many students with very good grades simply do not bother applying because they know that they will not get a place. If we are going to foster university research and become in some measure the clever country, the Government must consider increasing the Budget allocations for postgraduate scholarships in real terms next year.

It is tremendously encouraging and a great tribute to our higher education institutions to read of the enormous diversity of research currently in progress across the country. This report contains a staggering wealth of information about these projects and details of how each program will add to the body of knowledge at the local and international levels. It is worth noting that in some research fields, such as the biological sciences, Australia is a world leader. These efforts and talents should be fostered and encouraged by government.

In particular, I draw the Senate's attention to a number of archaeological projects which have received ARC grants this year. In addition to projects conducted in Australia, universities send archaeological missions to Italy, Turkey, Syria, Greece, Cyprus, Egypt and Jordan. Australia has a long and distinguished history of active archaeological activity in many of these places, research which has helped add significantly to the body of knowledge of the ancient world. Significantly, the presence of local teams overseas has helped to foster bilateral relations between Australia and these countries. Indeed, this has been recognised by the Government with the awarding of the Order of Australia to Professor Alexander Cambitoglou and Professor Basil Hennessy, of the University of Sydney, for services to archaeology and international relations.

Thanks to an ARC grant, Professor Hennessy is once again about to lead a team to the site of Pella in Jordan after an hiatus of work caused by the Gulf war. This site is recognised as one of the richest and most important sites in all of Jordan, with habitation material in its environs dating to 12,000 BC and beyond.

This report is at the cutting edge of the clever country. The Democrats take the view that all learning is of value and not just that which can be quantified in financial and economic terms. It is to be hoped that those who criticise humanities and liberal arts education and who condemned a number of these research grants as a waste of money will not gain undue influence over research funding which would undoubtedly see quality of life issues sacrificed at the altar of economic rationalism. I commend the report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: TAFE in the 1990s: Developing Australia's Skills

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 10 October, on motion by Senator Sowada:
That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sowada Sen K.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Australian Democrats support the broad thrust of the discussion paper entitled TAFE in the 1990s: Developing Australia's Skills produced by the Employment and Skills Formation Council of the National Board of Employment, Education and Training. It is imperative for Australia's economic future that the proportion of young people attending post-secondary education in Australia should increase, as has been the case in the world's most successful export economies.

SPEECH.PARA: Sadly, the report acknowledges that `at the present time participation by the 15 to 64 age group in TAFE is declining'. This is unacceptable.

The paper goes on to indicate some reasons for this unacceptable situation. It states that `governments' attitudes to resourcing TAFE are anomalous and unsatisfactory'. I can only agree with this statement as it is in my home State of New South Wales that some of the most unsatisfactory anomalies are present. For example, the New South Wales Government has mismanaged TAFE funding to the extent that last year's budget has blown out by $60m, with no benefit whatsoever to staff or students and no increase in enrolments.

TALK.START.PARA: —-It is a Liberal government too, isn't it?

—-It is indeed a Liberal government. Even worse is the prospect that this year's budget will be reduced as a consequence of last year's overspending, with a resulting decline in student numbers. This has come about because of the New South Wales Government's ideological commitment to overpaid, top heavy bureaucracies, which has found expression in its restructuring of TAFE organisations in that State. The unbudgeted $60m was spent almost entirely on increases in salaries for middle and top level managers under the Greiner Government's wasteful Special Executive Service scheme, with the effect that expensive new hierarchies of administrators have grown and prospered.

SPEECH.PARA: No benefits have trickled down to the teachers and students who are supposedly the reason for TAFECOM's existence. The inevitable cutbacks will hurt enrolments and courses while leaving the bureaucratic empires created under the then State Minister, Mr Fahey, unscathed. Such are the problems facing TAFE as it enters the 1990s under State administration. The discussion paper also notes:

. . . while women constitute 67 per cent of total TAFE enrolments, they form only 41 per cent of enrolments in. . . vocational streams. . . This compounds the disadvantage many women face in labour market participation or progression.

However, it is heartening to read that this problem is being confronted in the National Plan of Action for Women in TAFE, which seeks to `provide a more nationally consistent approach to equal opportunity for women in TAFE'. The report also recognises `an urgent need to increase women's participation in engineering, building, rural and horticultural study areas'.

The under-representation of Aboriginal people in TAFE courses is also addressed in this paper. This deficiency in the system will be addressed by the use of Aboriginal access courses that teach life skills as well as focus on English and mathematics leading to TAFE diploma or higher education study.

Overall, the discussion paper seeks to create greater coordination between industry and industrial education in the context of greater participation by school leavers and mature students in the further education system. As we move towards a century which is likely to be dominated by a fiercely competitive transnational information economy, the quality of technical and further education available to Australians will be an essential factor in assuring our continued prosperity and security. It is to be hoped that the discussion paper now before this chamber will act as a catalyst for the necessary changes.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: National Board of Employment, Education and Training--Toward A National Education and Training Strategy for Rural Australians

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 10 October, on motion by Senator Tierney:
That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Senate is considering the report of the National Board of Employment, Education and Training on a national strategy for rural Australians. The Board was given a reference to identify achievement and gaps in rural education and training and to propose possible initiatives. The overall conclusion by the Board is far from reassuring. In the report it says:

SPEECH.PARA: The provision of post-compulsory education and training in and for non-metropolitan Australians remains uneven and inadequate.

Therefore, the report identifies more gaps than achievements and the Board is deeply concerned that, if Australia is to have an education and training led economic recovery and is to become a truly clever country, it can ill afford to permit discrimination against one-third of the nation's labour force in terms of access to education and training.

The report identifies three major gaps: participation by rural young people in senior secondary schooling, particularly those living in remote areas; participation by the 15- to 29-year-old age group in higher education and TAFE apprenticeship and trainee training; and participation by the adult rural work force in skills training and reskilling. A number of reasons are included in the report. One is that non-metropolitan Australia has proportionally higher concentrations of demographic groupings which are under-represented generally in education and training. For example, three-quarters of the number of Aborigines live in non-metropolitan areas; unemployment figures are higher; there are more early school leavers and more low income earners; and there are more limited employment opportunities. This suggests that there is a high proportion of doubly disadvantaged people in rural areas. However, the Board has decided that the single most significant factor in the lower participation rates is the obvious one--lack of access to facilities.

The Board recognises that there have been major attempts in the past to increase the participation rates of rural Australians in education and training, but they have proved to be only marginally effective overall. There is a high degree of agreement that the central issue of rural participation in education and training requires a coordinated national approach. Therefore, the Board makes certain recommendations as an initial step towards a coordinated national response to addressing the situation which can be summarised as follows: that a national rural education and training coordinating committee be established to develop a national strategy for rural education and training; that new guidelines be developed for Austudy assistance schemes for rural students; and that the levels and types of skills training and accreditation required for the rural work force be studied.

Unfortunately, these recommendations are really calling for yet another committee and for more proposals rather than for specific action. However, the report is valuable for the information it provides on the causes and the extent of the problem. I commend the report to all honourable senators since all have some responsibility for rural areas in their own States.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 10 October, on motion by Senator Faulkner:
That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-First of all, I should thank this Parliament, the National Party and all my colleagues for giving me the opportunity to represent the Australian Parliament at the United Nations. I can assure honourable senators that it was an experience I will never forget. I only wish that more members of parliament from this august body could have the opportunity to go to the United Nations. It has definitely broadened my horizons. I also thank Ambassador Wilenski, the Australian Ambassador to the United Nations, and Ambassador Cook, the Australian Ambassador to the United States, for the help and support they gave both Senator Jones and me.

SPEECH.PARA: I was hoping that Senator Jones would speak first tonight because he was our leader at the mission. I am sure he will be speaking in a little while, or when this matter comes back on the Notice Paper. He was a wonderful travelling companion and a great help, and somebody whom this Parliament could feel proud it had sent to the United Nations.

Living and working in New York was an experience. Work would start at about 8.30 every morning and would not finish until quite late into the night. We would read the cables and have our chance to make a big input to the mission. Sometimes our ideas were taken on board by the permanent members and sometimes we were told that we needed a little more experience in foreign affairs. When Senator Evans was there, we had some quite interesting exchanges around the table.

Some outstanding events were taking place when we were at the United Nations. One of them was the children's summit, when 70 heads of state, for the first time ever, congregated in the one place to discuss the plight of children around the world and to make sure that they put forward their point of view. In our joint report we point out that Margaret Thatcher made a very good speech and stressed the importance of the family unit. This, she suggested, could be used as the basis for solving children's problems around the world. We both concurred in that.

We had an opportunity to speak at the United Nations on numerous occasions. I think Senator Jones spoke four or five times and I spoke four or five times. We spoke on a variety of subjects, from world debt through to the Decade of the Disabled, human rights issues and the like. Another highlight was when the Security Council moved resolution 678, which was only the fourth time in history that foreign Ministers from member nations of the Security Council came to give their nations' views around the table. Shevardnadze put forward the position for the USSR, and it is sad that he is not still at the forefront of Soviet politics. What a change there has been over the past year or so in the UN and the job it has had to do. On World Food Day, the theme was that space has been conquered but poverty has still not been conquered. That was also quite a big event.

Our report states our points of view very clearly. We have some suggestions at the end of the report which I will leave Senator Jones to expand on when he speaks. I commend the report to the Senate and seek leave to continue my remarks later.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Australian Education Council Review Committee--Young People's Participation in Post-Compulsory Education and Training

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 10 October, on motion by Senator Tambling:
That the Senate take note of the documents.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sowada Sen K.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I rise to discuss the report of the Australian Education Council Review Committee entitled Young People's Participation in Post-Compulsory Education and Training, otherwise known as the Finn review. This report is far-reaching and deserves more discussion than the brief comments I am able to make. The changes proposed have enormous implications for school and post-secondary education and deserve serious debate, both in the wider community and in this place.

SPEECH.PARA: The current recession has brought home to Australians the need for better education while at school and vocational training afterwards, so that our young work force is skilled and therefore employable. The dreadful spectre of thousands of our most valuable assets as a nation, our young people, unemployed and in many cases unemployable must focus our minds on the steps we need to take to give them improved prospects.

The most important aspect of this review of young people's participation in post-secondary education and training is the attempt by the Commonwealth to introduce national policies on training and education and to encourage the adoption of standard national criteria in curriculum, qualifications, standards, assessment and funding. I shall return to the funding question later.

The Australian Democrats welcome many aspects of the report, in particular the establishment of national targets for post-secondary education. The review suggests that, by the year 2001, 95 per cent of 19-year-olds should have either completed year 12 or an initial post-school qualification or be in formally recognised education or training. This is a laudable and very desirable goal. The report says this would be achieved by the introduction of, amongst other things, a post-compulsory education and training guarantee, and states:

. . . all young people would be guaranteed a place in school or TAFE after year 10 for two years of full-time education or training or its equivalent part time for up to three years. The Guarantee should apply for all those who are under 20 at the first of January each year.

In addition, recommendation 5.4 suggests that the introduction of uniform compulsory school education to year 10 should be given serious consideration by the States and Territories. A national assessment policy outlined in recommendation 4.7 would go a long way towards assisting students in achieving a high level of portability in education qualifications between the States and would also help employers gauge more realistically the relative on-paper suitability of job applicants. These are but a selection of very positive suggestions raised by the Finn Review.

In addition, I note that the Committee recommends the development of major proposals which will substantially improve the participation of disadvantaged groups in post compulsory educational training, in particular the needs of women; students from non-English speaking backgrounds; the homeless; young people with disabilities; and Aboriginal students, who often face enormous hurdles even at the secondary school level.

For many years I have been of the view that one of the greatest barriers to serious micro-economic reform and the development of national goals and strategies is our Federal system of national and State governments. This complex and sometimes difficult relationship is clearly illustrated in this report. None of this will work without the cooperation and compliance of the States. I note already that several State Ministers have responded angrily to the proposals contained in the Finn Review. Quite clearly, the review recommendations, and the Minister's support for Commonwealth control of TAFE education in particular, fly in the face of the Prime Minister's new federalism.

The Federal Government cannot and must not simply bludgeon the States into accepting this new direction. The process must be orderly and debated fully. For these strategies to work, the Commonwealth must take into account the State-based diversity which already exists in the system. National reform of post-secondary education should not result in the development of institutions which become bland sausage factories of students pouring forth the same product. Regional differences, educational diversity and choice must not be forsaken.

The Democrats will look closely at funding proposals to ensure that the financial situation of students is not a barrier to participation. The Government must take care that, in shovelling students into higher education, adequate resources are provided to ensure the current overcrowding situation at universities is not replicated at TAFE and in other training courses. This report, whilst making many recommendations for the improvement of post compulsory education and training, leaves many questions unanswered. These include the issue of funding, the agreement and compliance of the States, and the existing diversity and choice offered by post secondary institutions. In addition, the question of jobs--that is, what these students will be doing once they leave these institutions--is one that the Government must urgently address in the current economic situation. The document is a stimulating starting point for debate. I commend it to the Senate. (Time expired)
