DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: National Board of Employment, Education and Training and its Higher Education Council--Overenrolments and Overcrowding in Higher Education Institutions

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 10 October, on motion by Senator Tierney:
That the Senate take note of the document.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tierney Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Senate is considering another extremely short report from the National Board of Employment, Education and Training to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins). These reports usually contain vague generalities and no useful information or useful data. This report, entitled Overenrolments and Overcrowding in Higher Education Institutions, informs the Minister that the Higher Education Council has been conscious this year of difficulties facing students and staff at some higher education campuses because of overcrowding.

SPEECH.PARA: In the view of the Council, the high level of enrolments across the system has increased pressure on facilities that have not expanded quickly enough to keep pace with the strong growth in this sector over the last few years. The report also states that the Council is reluctant to make judgments about the individual factors involved in producing the overcrowding until confirmed data is available. Yet the Council admits to having known that there has been a strong growth in student enrolments for the last few years. Why have records not been kept until now about the effect of increased student enrolments on higher education institutions? Why does the Council not have the relevant data by now?

I looked at the second part of this report, which consists of a letter from Mr Ian Chubb of the Higher Education Council to the Board, for answers to these questions, but the letter simply states that the Council can make judgments about causes and means of avoiding similar problems when it has better information. The first half of this very short paper has revealed only that there is a problem with overcrowding in higher education institutions, but the exact causes are unknown. Therefore it is not possible to determine how to prevent similar problems in the future.
However, the second half of the report does provide some tentative comments by the Higher Education Council. For instance, it offers some suggestions for the causes of overcrowding. Firstly:

Overcrowding is rather caused by the large growth that the system has experienced in recent years and the inability to construct facilities to parallel the growth; overenrolment naturally exacerbates the problems.
Secondly:
The clever country agenda, significantly increased school retention rates . . .

If this is true, it has happened remarkably quickly since the first Hawke statement on the clever country was delivered last year. The figures that do exist are based on 1989 figures. Thirdly, the report states `widespread youth unemployment has created unprecedented levels of demand for higher education'.

Next, the Council apportions blame for overenrolment and the subsequent overcrowding. Honourable senators will not be surprised to learn that it is not the Government which is at fault but the institutions themselves, according to this Government report, which says that `some of the responsibility rests with institutional management' within certain universities. The Council justifies this statement because it claims that regular overenrolment occurs in only a few instutions. It says that institutions did not adjust well eugh to wt was a predictable high demand for places. Once again under this Government we have a conflict between it and the universities. On its own admission, it is too late to adjust student numbers or resource levels for 1991, with the result that there will be overcrowding and cutbacks in tutorials, lectures and laboratory classes and there will be less personal involvement with the students by staff.

The Council has made a number of recommendations for action by the National Board of Employment, Education and Training: explore the renovation of existing but poor quality teaching space; explore the practicability of bringing forward the 1992 capital program; allot to each institution a total load target, a commencing load target that may be adjusted by negotiation; and give a commitment that performance in relation to targets will be averaged over a triennium before any funding adjustments are made. These recommendations are too late to alleviate the situation in 1991. The Opposition will be anxious to see whether these recommendations are implemented and urgent action taken as a result to head off overcrowding in 1992. At least this report is a thought in the right direction.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sowada Sen K.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The present crisis of excessive numbers squeezed into inadequate facilities is one of the greatest problems faced by our vital tertiary institutions in their entire history. It is this crisis which the report entitled Overenrolments and Overcrowding in Higher Education Institutions details. An increase in the number of students seeking higher education is a good thing in itself, but when they cannot be accommodated this boon becomes a problem. Having students who need tickets to attend lectures, waiting lists at libraries and photocopiers and overcrowded lecture theatres cannot be allowed to become the norm at our tertiary institutions in Australia if Australia is to have any hope of maintaining its competitiveness into the next century.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the structural sources of the overcrowding crisis in our tertiary institutions has been strangely neglected in this report. As Senator Tierney outlined, the report largely places the blame at the door of the institutions themselves and of poor management practices conducted by them. The Australian Democrats reject this. A great deal of the overcrowding problem has been caused by the practice of determining the number of students for the purpose of funding allocations during the second semester each year.

This method of funding allocation has led to students being locked out of lecture theatres at Macquarie University, and has forced Adelaide University to issue tickets to first year students before they are allowed to attend their lectures. Under this system of funding, each university or college receives an allocation partly based on the number of students attending courses during the second semester each year. However, an attrition rate of 10 to 20 per cent of new enrolments in the first semester reduces the funding to which the tertiary institution is entitled. This means that administrators make strenuous efforts to deliberately over-enrol students during the first semester in order to maximise their funding, based on those who are left in the second semester. A vicious cycle is the result, with appallingly overcrowded positions leading to more students dropping out during the first semester, which in turn drives university administrators to seek even greater numbers of new students.

The Australian Democrats support reform of this funding regime so that allocations can be determined on a more realistic basis. A first step would be to put a lid on funding-driven over-enrolment by assessing the maximum number of students who could be adequately educated at each institution. This number would be used to set an upper limit for funding, thus removing the incentive for administrators to overload courses in search of extra money. Student numbers would be assessed in the first semester, with adjustments made for likely attrition.

Another factor which has contributed to overcrowding is the Government's retrograde policy of charging fees for higher education and its failure to provide adequate financial support for students. This forces students to enrol for the maximum possible number of courses in order to complete their degrees as quickly as possible and so minimise their financial problems. I suggest to the Government that the introduction of the higher education contribution scheme has actually in itself resulted in this problem, and the Government has failed to take adequate notice that students telescoping their courses would result in overcrowding at institutions.

The Government's failure to anticipate this consequence of its short term mercenary policies is now reflected in the inadequate conditions at universities on which our economic future depends. The vital tertiary education sector has been squeezed for finances at the same time as it has been required to take on even more students. Such starvation of educational institutions is intolerable while wealthy individuals and huge corporations are allowed to evade tax through overseas havens.

The Australian Democrats fully supported yesterday's national day of action on overcrowding at universities. An educated population and work force is an essential resource which must not be sacrificed to the altar of economic rationalism. I commend the report to the Senate and ask that it take note of its recommendations.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I seek leave to have the report of the Australian delegation to the forty-fifth session of the United Nations General Assembly recommitted.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —-It's a bit late.

—-I heard the interjection from Senator Tate that I am a bit late, and I apologise to the Senate. I will be brief in my comments on the report. As one of the parliamentary advisers to the forty-fifth session of the United Nations, and on behalf of myself and my co-delegate, I would like to express my gratitude to the Parliament of Australia and to my Party for allowing me to attend the United Nations. At this stage, I would have to say that this was probably one of the best experiences that I, as a parliamentarian, have ever undertaken. I also say that my co-delegate Senator Brownhill and I worked very well together. I congratulate Senator Brownhill on the way in which he participated in his role as an adviser to the United Nations. I thank him for the personal way in which we were associated when the United Nations was not sitting. I will not say too much more because I do not want to affect his endorsement. Thank you, Senator Brownhill.

SPEECH.PARA: We presented a written report as part of the Australian delegation to the forty-fifth session of the United Nations. It is not my intention at this stage to cover in detail all the points included in our section of the report covered under annex D. I believe it is worth mentioning the headings which outline the structure of our report and cover those matters dealing with different sections in the report.

One of the first items that the report covered--and one of the first things that the United Nations covered--was the Middle East. I believe that the Middle East crisis was the single most important item on the agenda for the 1990 session. The Middle East crisis, of course, overshadowed everything else that was undertaken at the United Nations.

Another heading in the report was `Changing world'. In this section we dealt with the changing role of Europe. Of course, when one looks at the forty-fifth session of the UN Assembly, one looks at the changing role within Europe, German unification, the changing attitude in Russia and, of course, the end of the Cold War which brought about great changes not only at the United Nations but also in a lot of countries throughout the world.

One of the other headings which had a marked influence was `Statements by key-note speakers'. When one goes through the list of keynote speakers, one of the ones that come to mind is the People's Republic of Bulgaria. A few years ago, one would not consider that Bulgaria was the greatest democratic country of all times. But on this occasion, the speech made by the speaker from Bulgaria certainly showed that changes were taking place. I think about two or three days ago in the newspaper, I noticed that there were democratic elections taking place in Bulgaria itself. Other keynote speakers who outlined changes were from the Federal Republic of Germany, the United States and, of course, the USSR. The keynote speaker from the USSR was Eduard Shevardnadze, the then Foreign Minister.

One of the other headings was `New attitudes give strength to UN action'. I believe that this strength was shown by the support for the Security Council's positive action in the Middle East. Another heading was `World under discussion'. Many changes took place, and one that comes to mind more than anything else is the changes in Africa. Of course, one can see the continuing path towards the ending of apartheid.

As delegates, we also attended the Inter-Parliamentary Union conference. It was attended by both advisers--Senator Brownhill and me. There was a discussion on Cambodia. I think the other discussion was on literacy. I was lucky enough to be appointed chairman of one of the sessions of the conference.

I think one piece of advice that I could give to other parliamentary advisers that go to the United Nations is that they not be quite as conscientious, enjoy the visit a bit more and not spend quite as much time at the United Nations as we did. However, as advisers, we participated in the debate on the report of the Economic and Social Council. We also participated in the debate on the global fight against acquired immune deficiency syndrome--AIDS; the international decade for natural disaster reduction; the restructuring of the economic and social sector in the UN; the human rights issue; and the drug control program. I think there were other areas that we also participated in, but we actually participated within the Assembly and within the committees discussing those items on behalf of Australia and putting the point of view of the Australian delegation forward. (Extension of time granted)

There was also a briefing of countries prior to the committee meetings, and I think these briefings showed more clearly than anything else the extremely high regard in which the Australian delegation was held. The way in which Ambassador Wilenski and his team acted and the discussions they had with the other countries certainly assisted Australia and the world in relation to the matters discussed.

Australia also participated in the World Summit for Children. The delegation was led by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Senator Gareth Evans, and we were proud that Australia was a signatory to the declaration and plan of action. I am cutting my speech fairly short; I probably should go a little further.

The only other point I would like to make concerns the summary and conclusion that we made within our report. As the report came from the parliamentary delegates, we decided to put forward a number of points which we believe should be taken up. The first thing we recommended was that the United Nations be asked to form an elected body or representative assembly with a member or members from the governments of individual states. This group could provide some form of accountability through the elected representatives who would report back to their own governments. When one considers the changes that are taking place in the world, it is quite obvious that the United Nations needs to change in some way. I believe that we ought to look at the charter of the United Nations and that there should be some discussion about bringing some form of elected assembly into the United Nations.

We also made a number of other recommendations. One, which was prompted by Eduard Shevardnadze, involved the re-establishment of the military committee. If the military committee for the United Nations had been re-established, after the Iraqi affair we might not have had the problems we experienced in Kuwait and in those other countries because we would have had the advice of the military staff committee, which could have advised the United Nations.

I would like to make one more very quick point. When one attends the United Nations it is fairly difficult to look at all of the addresses, but when I looked through the papers I received I again looked at the address by Eduard Shevardnadze. I think it is fairly important to quote a couple of points that were made in his statement. I will quote them fairly quickly.

DEBATE.TITLE: INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT (VALUELESS SHARES) AMENDMENT BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —-We are dealing here with the Income Tax Assessment (Valueless Shares) Amendment Bill 1991, which is a private member's Bill introduced by Senator Watson. As has been the case with similar initiatives by Senator Watson in the past, I would acknowledge--not for the first time, but perhaps for the first time in this chamber, because it is the first time I have been called upon to discuss it--that the issue dealt with by this Bill is a real problem. It is not the sort of problem that is central to the whole structure of the tax system, and it is not fundamental to the principles of equity, efficiency and simplicity in legislation. But for the people affected it is a real problem, nevertheless, and one that needs to be addressed properly by the Government and the Parliament. I want to put that on the record right from the start.

SPEECH.PARA: In summing up the Government's response to the proposed Bill, one would say that Senator Watson has asked the right question, although we are not convinced he has the right answer at this stage. But that is not to say that this is not a proper matter to come before us. It is an issue well worthy of consideration and an issue on which action needs to be taken. There has been some consideration of this issue within the Government already and some advice has been forthcoming. It is a matter which, as I will indicate at the conclusion of what I hope will be a relatively brief contribution to this debate, I will be referring to the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) upon his return from overseas.

Broadly put, the issue concerns the problem that arises for shareholders who have shares in a company which is in liquidation and who are unable to trade in those shares. They are unable to realise what would otherwise be a capital loss and offset it against capital gains otherwise earned and, therefore, would pay a higher tax bill than they would pay otherwise. That is not in conflict with the fundamental principles of capital gains tax, which is that gains and losses are realised at the point of disposal of the asset-- and these assets have not been disposed of. So, in principle, one can see the underlying premise of the legislation as it stands, but the human cost to the individuals is real and needs to be addressed.

Having dealt with that as a broad principle very briefly, but I think adequately for the circumstances, I would now like to deal with some of the problems we see with this particular formulation as a solution to the problem before coming back to indicate the direction in which I think action might be taken in order to deal with the problem before us.

One of the problems we see with the legislation as proposed is that it is considering that, subject to various prerequisites set down in the legislation, the disposal will be deemed to have taken place. We do not think that is the trigger mechanism which most effectively meets the common objective of dealing with the objectives of the taxpayers involved. At the moment, on the basis of our consideration, which is not concluded--it is an issue which requires further study and consultation; that is why as yet we have not taken action on this matter--it would seem that it would be more appropriate that the disposal be triggered by action of the liquidator: the person who is likely to be in the best position to assess the value of assets and the extent of liabilities.

It is probably more appropriate that the disposal be triggered by a written declaration by the liquidator rather than by the Commissioner of Taxation. We would expect that that declaration would indicate that there was no likelihood that the shareholders would receive any distributions on those shares. The liquidator is the person who is, in effect, looking after the interests of the shareholders as well as those of the creditors. It is our view that this would be a neater, cleaner, more appropriate and more direct formulation. It has a second benefit also with regard to timing, which I will perhaps come to at a slightly later stage. But I think the liquidator's triggering mechanism would give us a cleaner and easier timing device for the realisation of the loss.

In the drafting of the legislation before us, it is unclear--according to advice that I have received--exactly which shares would be covered or to which years the amendment would apply. I understand quite clearly from the legislation--it is set out there quite clearly--that the provision would commence upon royal assent. It deems a disposal of a share in certain circumstances where, at the end of the year, it is worthless. This legislation, as it stands, does not have any further clarification, and without that further clarification it is not clear whether the measure is intended to apply to shares that were worthless at the end of previous years--that is, shares that were worthless in 1986, 1987 and 1988 and which are still worthless--or whether it applies only to future years.

With the current trend of the Government's thinking, I suggest that the most likely course of action would be--this has not been finally considered by the Government; it is a matter I will be making representations to the Treasurer about on his return--that the provision would apply to any declaration made by a liquidator after a certain date. That is the second leg of the argument. That is why we think that a declaration by the liquidator being the trigger mechanism is the more appropriate formulation. It has the second benefit with regard to timing. This has the benefit of giving the taxpayers some certainty at the time, rather than having to wait until the end of the year. That is what the provision is properly designed to do. It would, I think, enable people more quickly to take advantage of the proposal.

There is a second and related timing question. The Bill as it is before us deems the share to have been disposed of at the end of the year, even though it has actually become worthless some time during the financial year. Closely related to the point I made before--and Senator Watson and others who have taken an interest in these issues would understand this--in general, the capital gains provisions provide that where an asset expires or is destroyed the loss comes into effect at the time the asset expires, is destroyed or, in this instance, loses its value. I would have thought that the preferred approach would be to deem a disposal when the liquidator declares there is no likelihood of distribution or there is no value in the shares. I think that timing matter has benefit in it.

There was also some uncertainty as to whether the value should be nil or negligible and whether we should deal with it as though the value in the circumstances is nil. I understand that there is some international precedent for the negligible aspect. I am aware of that point. There is no unanimity of view at this stage from advisers and from people whose opinions have been brought forward as to what is the best solution to that matter. Unlike the other three points I have made, where quite clearly there is a better alternative formulation to solve the problem than that which is in the Bill, I would not go so far with regard to the fourth point. It is a matter for subsequent discussion and determination. The Government does not have a final view about it.

It is likely that the Government will want to clarify how the provision applies to different classes of shares. I expect that it will be more likely to look at a formulation that dealt with shareholders--that is, taxpayers--rather than shares. The Government may well need to look at a drafting provision that clarifies how the provision applies to different classes of shares. In a sense, once this provision applies to them, all shares are equal; they are all of nil value. It may be that this is a lesser problem than it appears on the surface. At the end of the day, they will all be deemed to be of the same value. That is an issue which we are seeking to address.

For the sake of completeness, although there is not a matter of debate between us, there is one aspect of the drafting which I certainly share with Senator Watson; that is, the view reflected in the Bill that there ought to be a choice for shareholders as to whether they wish to take advantage of this provision to crystallise their losses earlier than existing legislation would require. I think that is pretty uncontroversial. I do not suggest anyone would think otherwise. I do not want honourable senators opposite to think I have ignored that provision, and I indicate that that is my thinking. I am fairly confident that that will be reflected in any final action that the Government takes with regard to this matter.

I do not want to extend the discussion of this Bill. I conclude essentially as I began. I wish to indicate what it is that I will be doing about this matter so that it does not become just an interesting debate in the chamber which disappears into the ether and Hansard but is not of any practical value to the people who have a real human and financial problem. To recapitulate, while the issue that has been dealt with in this private member's Bill is not one of the central and determining tax issues that will determine the nature of, the equity of, the efficiency of or the simplicity of our tax system over the coming months and years, it is for those individuals affected a very real and substantial problem. It is agreed that we need to address it.

I indicate once again that the Government will not be supporting the Bill. It is not satisfied that the mechanism in the Bill adequately meets the problems that we agree exist. I certainly give an undertaking to Senator Watson directly, and to the chamber as a whole, that I will raise this issue and ensure that briefs from the Treasury and the Tax Office are available consistent with that on the Treasurer's return. I will seek prompt action, if possible, for legislation that might be introduced in the course of this session of the Parliament but, if not, in the next session. For those reasons, while I have clearly indicated sympathy for the objectives of the legislation, the Government will not at this stage be supporting the Bill. It will seek to take action with a similar objective but with a slightly different style to achieve what is, if not exactly a common objective, a similar objective shared, I suspect, by the whole Senate, but certainly by the Government and the Opposition. I will do that promptly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Kemp Sen R.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I rise in support of Senator Watson's private member's Bill, known as the Income Tax Assessment (Valueless Shares) Amendment Bill. I believe that Senator Watson has the respect of all sides in this chamber because of the expertise he shows on tax matters. Senator McMullan made a similar point. Senator Watson has a well-deserved reputation for mastering complex tax matters. This Bill is yet another contribution of Senator Watson to achieve a greater sense and equity in our taxation law.

SPEECH.PARA: I think it is correct to say that Senator McMullan gave some comfort to Senator Watson and his colleagues who are concerned about this issue--probably not quite enough comfort. We were pleased to hear Senator McMullan say that he viewed this as a very real problem. While he felt that he was not able to support the legislation as it stands, he gave assurances to the chamber that he would be pursuing this matter with some vigour with the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) on his return from overseas. Senator McMullan said he believed that Senator Watson had asked the right questions, but was not altogether sure that he had provided the right answer with this Bill. I think Senator Watson has provided the right answers in this Bill.

Considering the present climate and the large number of private investors who have been affected by share losses, this Bill could not have come at a better time. The purpose of this Bill is to allow losses on valueless shares to be claimed as a capital loss and thus be available for netting off against any capital gains accruing in current or in future years in circumstances where the company, the subject of the investment, is in liquidation.

There is an urgent need for a Bill of this kind, and I think that point was conceded by Senator McMullan. The current capital gains provisions do not allow for capital losses arising from investments in shares in circumstances where the corporation is in liquidation and where a valid and effective transfer of ownership cannot be effected. Further, the liquidator rarely directs funds for maintaining a share register. This is a very real problem. Therefore, private investors and their advisers have been worried about how to claim losses on worthless shares.

Private investors holding listed shares which have become worthless cannot easily dispose of them once the company goes into liquidation. This means that, even though investors have made the same losses on the shares as anyone else, they cannot deduct the loss from any capital gains unless they find another way of disposal and/or rely on tax rulings.

In July of this year income tax ruling 2643 set out some ground rules for `wash sales', though it left many areas still vague. This followed an earlier ruling by the Australian Taxation Office that for private investors--those not classified as traders or investing via company structures--suspension or delisting of the stock did not, in its eyes, constitute disposal. Although the Australian Taxation Office in income tax ruling 2643 stated that under certain conditions part IVA would not typically apply to wash sales, there is still a probability that the share sale arrangements between related parties, including family members, could be caught by the anti-avoidance part IVA mechanisms as the facts of each case need to be determined.

According to the Tax Office rulings, it is not possible to give an assurance that part IVA would not apply to wash sales generally. Further, my colleague Senator Watson and a number of eminent experts within the industry believe ruling 2643 to be wrong in law. One accounting firm has stated:
The ruling appears to substitute some form of arm's length test for the true test contained in part IVA.

The Income Tax Assessment (Valueless Shares) Amendment Bill is thus being brought before this chamber to overcome the apparent vagaries of income tax rulings. The Bill would allow for a statutory mechanism or technique to crystallise the losses. I urge all members of the chamber to support this Bill, as it brings the Australian taxation system into line with that of the USA and the UK.

The British Inland Revenue Office publishes from time to time shares listed as having negligible value, while in the USA the Internal Revenue Code section 165(g) allows a deduction for worthless security. Therefore I think we can say that there is an international precedent in favour of putting all investors on the same footing when it comes to claiming legitimate investment losses. In fact, the various clauses of the Bill before us are based largely on section 22 of the British capital gains tax legislation, which allows notional disposal where there is an entire loss on an asset.

In this Bill, the valueless shares are defined as having negligible or nil value, as in the UK legislation. The negligible value is not quantified in the UK legislation, although the UK Inland Revenue considers negligible value to be less than or equal to 5 per cent of the par value of the share. For our purposes, such a determination could be assisted by an appropriate income tax ruling.

To complement the legislation, the Australian Taxation Office could publish from time to time details or lists of shares where such claims would be accepted. We are fortunate in Australia to have a large number of organisations through which this information could be disseminated. The circulation could be via organisations such as the Taxation Institute of Australia, Butterworths and CCH tax services, the Australian Taxpayers Association, the Australian Securities Commission and the Australian Stock Exchange.

Most importantly, this Bill allows for restitution of taxpayers' rights. The present capital gains provisions, by not recognising the loss on shares in the circumstances I have described, restrict the taxpayer and put him or her in an unfair position. Overall, I think the Government should note that the financial impact of this Bill is not expected to be significant. It is a Bill directly concerned with the justice and the protection of taxpayers' legitimate rights.
Senator McMullan raised a number of issues of a more technical nature. I think it would be wiser if I left those for Senator Watson to tackle. I commend the Bill to the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bourne Sen V.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Income Tax Assessment (Valueless Shares) Amendment Bill is another piece of specific legislation brought forward by Senator Watson in the very complex area of income taxation. At the outset, the Australian Democrats would like to compliment Senator Watson for his consistent and persistent endeavours to ensure that taxation law is refined and improved and that anomalies are speedily dealt with by this chamber, thereby ensuring that the Government addresses them. A recent example was his Bill which sought to correct the injustice in the substantiation provisions, which was highlighted by the Evangelist case. The Democrats supported that Bill and we will also be voting for this Bill tonight.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill proposes to address the technical problem which arises because of inconsistent legal requirements between the taxation law and company law. Realised capital losses may be offset against capital gains derived during the current year, or they may be carried forward to be offset against capital gains which are derived in future years.

For a capital gain or loss to be realised, the legislation requires that the taxpayer must dispose of the relevant asset. In the case of the shares in a company to which a liquidator has been appointed, sections 468 and 493 of the corporations law prevent the transfer of the absolute control and ownership of those shares. This means that an investor whose shares have become worthless or virtually worthless is legally unable to realise the capital loss which he or she has sustained. The Commissioner of Taxation has recognised that there is a problem in this regard in taxation ruling No. 2643. However, I think Senator Watson is correct in his interpretation that the ruling is not correct at law and that an amendment to the legislation is necessary.

The Bill proposes that investors whose shares have become worthless or virtually worthless will be able to make an election when a company is in the process of liquidation which will deem that they have disposed of the shares, thereby allowing the loss to crystallise. There are other ways to achieve this aim. Indeed, Senator McMullan has informed us that the Government is examining alternative approaches. We are certainly not solely endorsing the method proposed by Senator Watson. However, the Australian Democrats believe that this Bill will solve the problem whilst not allowing an avoidance opportunity, therefore we are supporting it. However, we are willing to consider the merits of any other approach that may come before the chamber.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —-in reply--I would like to thank all honourable senators who participated in the debate on the Income Tax Assessment (Valueless Shares) Amendment Bill. Naturally, I am disappointed that the Government has not chosen to follow the approach that I have adopted. I would like to pay a special thanks to those people who have supported the Bill, enabling it to reach the second reading stage. I thank the Australian Democrats for their support. They will naturally share in the success of this Bill and in the promise of what is to come, in the manner in which the Government wishes to take this up. I also thank my colleague Senator Kemp for his kind remarks.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bill is essentially a question of restoration of taxpayers' rights and, as Senator Kemp said, a question of justice. That is what it is all about. I acknowledge that there are a number of approaches and that each approach has its own limitations. Rather than giving the discretion to the liquidator, I have chosen the option of an election, which is essentially a very simple and straightforward approach. Of the three or four approaches that we had the choice of pursuing, we chose this one for reasons of simplicity and certainty as far as the shareholders were concerned.

The Government believed that there should be another way of producing the trigger mechanism to produce the particular loss. The trigger mechanism in our case, of course, was the election by the shareholder. The shareholder need not make the election this year or next year. It is a question of shareholder choice. We believe this to be fundamental, rather than a decree or fiat from a particular liquidator.

The choice the Government may take of giving a choice to the liquidator, of course, places a great responsibility upon the liquidator. That approach will require much more voluminous legislation because safeguards will have to be built in to allow for circumstances in which there is an excess on final realisation. This could happen. For example, the mine could suddenly find a pot of gold right at the end. The trigger mechanism of an election provides that degree of flexibility not only for the current situation but also for a future situation where, for example, additional revenue may be found and it is discovered that there is not a nil value after all.

I believe that the approach that we have followed is a sound one. I have to defend the integrity of the approach that I have used. I acknowledge that there are choices. If the Government chooses to follow another approach, obviously, providing it is based on sound criteria, we will endorse that. I thank the Minister for the fact that he is going to raise this with the Treasurer (Mr Kerin) on his return and seek a prompt response. I certainly look forward to seeing similar legislation in the nature of an amendment coming before this Parliament, hopefully before it rises at Christmas.

I believe that with my approach there would not be problems with different classes of shares. This would be a decision that would be confirmed, of course, by the Taxation Office. It would not readily agree to listings if there was a lot of doubt about them. My Bill is a question of timing. Obviously, once the shares have been struck off the register the loss could be crystallised but, in many cases, this might take a dozen or so years. It is not an expedient remedy.

Of course, what shareholders are looking for is a means of crystallising that loss so that it could be offset, not against income but against any current gains or future gains. Therefore, I support the mechanism that I have used, that is, the mechanism of an election followed by certain rulings that could be made by the Australian Taxation Office. I thank the Senate for its support for the Bill.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate--
(a) condemns the Government for its failure to provide direction and support to Australia's depressed rural sector, especially during the present devastating drought; and
(b) calls on the Government:

(i) to adopt policies to remove the obstacles which are preventing rural producers from operating effectively and efficiently, including a reduction in real interest rates, an efficient waterfront and transport system and a competitive tax structure, and
(ii) to pursue all opportunities to liberalise international trade to minimise the barriers confronting Australian primary industry.

This time last week, when the Senate was debating a similar motion condemning the Government on its ineptitude in getting mineral resources off the ground, I mentioned that the mining industry would have to lift Australia out of despair because the primary industries are not able to do so at this stage. The Government was soundly condemned on that day because the Senate carried the motion. In fact, the Government condemned itself by its silence. However, I presume that even the Government is entitled not to incriminate itself any further.

While Australia's eyes are firmly fixed on the mineral sector, it does not mean that primary industry does not have a future. Primary industry will come good again as it has in the past, time and time again. Farmers just cannot be kept down for too long--that is, if the Government gives them any sort of encouragement.

TALK.START.PARA: —-What about the market?

—-If Senator Cook will be patient, we will come to the market. If the Government were simply to remove the obstacles put in the way of Australian agriculture, deliberately or by default, it would thrive again and--pending getting top money in the market again--regain its rightful place, the place it had in the past when it was Australia's biggest exporter.

SPEECH.PARA: To show exactly how much Australia's agricultural income has dropped I will refer to the latest figures available to me which show the downturn. I will take wheat first. In 1988-89 Australia's exports were valued at $2.107 billion; in 1989-90, they went down to $2.56 billion; and by the year 1990-91 they had dropped right down to $1.782 billion, which is a decrease of 15.4 per cent. I turn to wool, which went through a big fiasco last year and the year before. In 1988-89, Australia exported $5.54 billion worth of wool; in 1989-90 it had dropped to $4.078; and for 1990-91 it was down to $2.725 billion, in other words, exactly half, working out at 50.8 per cent.

If we look at the figures on a per farm basis, we see that the net farm cash incomes for the last five years have decreased dramatically. In 1987-88, for a single farm the figure was $6,948; 1988-89, $6,685; 1989-90, $6,397; 1990-91, $4,150; and the estimate for 1991 is $3,157. At the same time, total farm costs have risen, which tells a very sorry tale. In 1987-88, costs were $16,678; 1988-89, $18,651; 1989-90, $19,983; 1990-91, $20,100; and, hopefully, on provisional figures there may be a slight drop in 1991, but there has still been a vast increase since 1987.

Income is going down while costs are continually going up, although the increases may have slowed in the past 12 months. What encouragement is the Government giving to help turn around this trend? Australian farms are still 93 per cent family worked and owned. That figure is equal to or higher than in any other country in the world. It is imperative that we keep it that way.

When we were in Eastern Europe a little earlier in the year we were told that various countries are hoping to get their economies going by getting back into rural production. Given the situation that has existed for the past 45 years, all that two of the three countries could talk of was returning farms to private enterprise and getting them going. They have quite a bit to learn from Australia, which is one of the most efficient primary producers in the world. They would do well to follow our methods.

As I asked before, what has the Government done? In this year of record unemployment, with one million people already out of work caused by this recession we had to have, one would have thought that this Government would bring down a Budget to try to relieve the situation. I cannot find anything whatsoever in the Budget to help the rural sector, except a small attempt to provide some social security benefits to the farming community. This may be of minimal help to those in extreme circumstances, but it does nothing to help the whole industry.

We cannot let the industry sink to the lowest point, otherwise it will never recover. If the Government had at least retained the income equalisation deposit scheme that was instigated by the Fraser Government, it would have prepared farmers, who would have had ready cash from the better times, for this downturn. After all, the farmers enjoyed four or five reasonable years. But the Government altered the scheme over and over again until it was absolutely useless and the farmers did not use it. Of course, they now pay tax.

The Government has failed to provide an efficient system through which we can compete with the rest of the world. The Government has failed to provide an efficient and competitive transport industry. As I see it, the road transport industry in Australia continues to be taxed out of existence. Instead of rationalising the rail system by cutting expenditure, the Government tries to keep the rail system moving and get it back into a competitive situation by flogging the road industry system out of existence.

The Government has also failed to provide an internationally competitive waterfront. We are told that we have to restructure the waterfront. I know that restructuring is taking place, but it is not moving anywhere near fast enough. The use of the waterfront for trade has dropped by between 30 per cent and 33 per cent in the past two years, yet the number of people employed on the waterfront has been reduced by only 13 per cent, which amounts to between 600 and 700 people. They have to be paid by somebody. Eventually, of course, those costs are picked up by whoever pays the freight costs.

This Government did manage to provide Australia with the Western world's highest interest rate, which put our farmers and small businesses in a very dangerous position when world commodity prices were at such high levels that they were prevented from consolidating. Had we been in a position to make the best of those commodity prices, Australian farmers would have been in a far better position. This Government has failed farmers at every turn.

The Government has now put the farmers into a peasant class. Based on the figures for the average farm income, which will provide a provisional profit of $3,157 this year, that cannot be denied. The Government has abandoned them altogether. Perhaps that is where the Government wants them. The wheat industry in particular had its cushion taken away after 47 years of the old marketing system. In 1986 the Government took away the guaranteed minimum price when it paid out $385m. That is a small figure compared with the amount that the wheat industry has put into the kitty of all governments since 1947.

Of course, this downturn has had the effect of reducing the number of hectares planted for this year's crop. We have now reached the situation where we cannot supply traditional markets, albeit at the current low prices. In Western Australia, to the credit of the Premier--I do not normally sing her praises--a one-off guaranteed minimum price of $150 for one year has been provided. At least in Western Australia the planting was kept up. That is just as well because, I believe, the seven million tonnes of wheat that will be produced this year to satisfy our traditional customers will all come from Western Australia.

If measures similar to those that have been put in place by Premier Lawrence were repeated in the rest of Australia, it would give farmers some incentive--above all, an incentive to remain on their farms. We have farmers leaving the countryside and going into the cities, which only puts pressure on housing and jobs in the city and leaves country homes and country towns empty. Once the farmers leave, it has been my experience that they very seldom return, especially the younger ones.

Measures such as the isolated children's assistance under the means test must be addressed again. The isolated children's assistance should be totally divorced from Austudy. It only causes confusion. Those measures were separated for a certain time, but a heap of confusion was caused when they were amalgamated. I believe, and I always will, that all children, no matter where they live in Australia, should have the basic right of access to education. If anyone denies that, that person should tell me. Therefore, the isolated children's assistance should be available to all students who find it impossible to go to school. When I say `impossible', I mean impossible. I do not mean children that may be within 40 or 50 kilometres of a school; I mean those who find it totally impossible to get to school every day and have to go to boarding school. That should be the basic right of all those children. Senator West might agree that the isolated children's assistance should be available to them. The figure of about $1,500 per year, payable by way of assistance, does not cover anywhere near the minimum fees of a student boarding at a government hostel, which in Western Australia costs at least $5,000. Fifteen hundred dollars does not go anywhere near meeting that bill.

If the farm has a cash flow the children have a chance of getting an education, but if there is no cash flow whatsoever those children will suffer and their education will end. I suppose that they could take correspondence lessons, but anyone who has had experience with that method of education will know that it is fairly hard. If this allowance were adequate, these children would be able to remain in the system and take part in this clever country that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and others always talk about.

In 1988 Mr Kerin, as Minister for Primary Industries, decried the fact that young people in rural and remote areas lacked education. But what did he and the Government do about it? They did nothing. Mr Crean this year in a communication to a backbencher, after sympathising with the fact that more money was not available for the education of isolated children, said, `I realise that no increases in allowances were sought for AIC'--Assistance for Isolated Children. One would have thought that the Government, having considered the matter, would have put in submissions to the Expenditure Review Committee so that money could have been allocated out of the Budget for this purpose. But that did not happen, and that is what this Government really thinks about children in isolated areas.

If Australian agriculture is to revive, the Government must adopt policies to enable it to compete internationally. A little earlier Senator Cook asked, `Where are the markets?'. If we can get our costs down, we will compete. I know that operating in international markets is hard at present, but even with the dumping and the subsidised prices that now exist in the world I believe we have an opportunity to get into certain markets. Certainly our beef industry is not doing a bad job in competing internationally.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I had wool and wheat in mind.

—-Well, wool is different. If we cannot sell our wool now with the present price structure, we never will, but wool will revive. If we are provided with measures to get costs down, we can start gradually to get our market share back. These measures include a reduction in real interest rates. I know that there has been a reduction in interest rates over the past six months, but what is the farmer paying? Even somebody on top security at the top line of a bank still has to pay 13.5 per cent; that rate applies even if one is the best risk in the land. Certainly the average farmer who has to borrow must pay around 20 per cent interest. What can a farmer do in the face of such a rate?

SPEECH.PARA: Government policy must include the attainment of efficiency on the waterfront. I know that workers have been removed from the waterfront and have been paid redundancy money, but this is not happening nearly fast enough. There are still 600 or 700 people on the waterfront who are not producing, and something must be done.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Would you put the troops in?

—-No, I would not put the troops in just for this situation; we do not need troops there at present. There may be a day when the troops will be needed, just as this Government put the troops in during the airline dispute. The day may come when the coalition government might have to do what the Labor Government did then, but at present there would not be a need. That does not mean that in time a coalition government might not have to do the same on the wharf. That is my position on it. As I have said, there are 600 to 700 people on the waterfront who are still being paid, whereas trade has dropped off at a great rate. Therefore, the sooner that something is done the better.

SPEECH.PARA: We must have an efficient transport system. I know that the Government has made a start in reorganising that system, but things are happening far too slowly. I know that in Western Australia rail freight rates are rising rather than falling. Where are the Government's rationalisation measures in this regard?

Government policy on agriculture must include a tax system that is internationally competitive. I could launch into what a goods and services tax would do for this country, but I believe there will be enough debate on that topic in future, and indeed there has been quite a lot of debate in the past. Senator Cook will hear about it if he is patient and waits a little longer. All will be revealed. We certainly need to become internationally competitive.

TALK.START.PARA: —-It just increases the prices of what you sell.

—-Well, we will sell nothing with the costs that are operating at present. If we can get costs down, we can start to move again. The Government must pursue all opportunities to liberalise international trade to minimise barriers confronting Australian primary industry. This must include a tougher stand with the United States. Australia has given total commitment to the United States, no doubt for favours in the past. We have got involved in everything the Americans have got themselves into in the last 50 years. The latest was the Gulf war, the result of which was a certain loss to wheat growers. Not all those losses were recouped. I know that there was compensation at around 80 per cent, but wheat farmers lost a certain amount of money.

SPEECH.PARA: Furthermore, Australian motorists paid through higher fuel prices as a result of the Gulf war, as did farmers with diesel fuel and as did the mining sector. But when it suits those in the United States, they take no notice of Australian protests and sell wheat at subsidised prices. I hope that the forthcoming visit by President Bush will not be only a back-slapping, `My mate George' exercise. I hope that there will be some solid negotiations about United States dumping of subsidised products on world markets. The discussions can include almost anything, including the future of American bases on our soil.

The stand must also include the European Community and the `more than 100 per cent cost of production' subsidy to its wheat farmers. I know that the American cost of production subsidy is only 65 to 70 per cent, but in Europe the figure is over 100 per cent, and ranges up to 150 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Twenty per cent of the farmers get 80 per cent of the subsidies.
—-Order! It would be helpful if debate were conducted through the Chair. Senator West will have an opportunity to put her point of view, if she wishes, at another time.

—-I will take your direction, Madam Acting Deputy President. Certainly the EC does nothing for us. Delegations such as that headed by Dr Blewett this year should be made every six months. I believe some good came out of Dr Blewett's delegation to the EC not so long ago. The point is that it is useless going to Europe or to the United States just once and then forgetting about it. I believe that the delegations should be made, in good times and in bad times, at least every six months. Let us keep those countries on notice that we mean what we say.

SPEECH.PARA: The stand should also include the definition of `Third World countries'. There are some countries which have `developing' status and which use labour at very low wages, and those goods appear on the Australian market. I believe that more use should be made of anti-dumping and countervailing measures, and even a period of 50 days in respect of these provisions is not enough.

The `developing country' status includes eastern European nations. Some of those eastern European countries are highly productive and have just emerged out of communism. Those countries are seeking `developing' status markets, but are all applying to join the Common Market. As soon as those countries get into the EC, we will be left lamenting.

The Government has relied on primary industry export income in the better times because of that assured income. But while that income was there it let the Green lobby take over the environmental debate. I said last week in the other debate that this Government had let the Greens set the pace on the environment, and while they were setting that pace they prevented new resource development. At the same time, the Government was putting nothing back into agriculture.

The Government stands condemned for what it has not done for agriculture in the past eight years. Only when a coalition government returns to power will the agriculture industry have any hope of receiving help to get it back to its previous position. If the Democrats have any feeling for the people in Australian agriculture, we will get their help on this motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Again we are debating the condemnation by Opposition senators of our policies and actions in relation to the rural sector and primary producers. No other group in the rural sector has been mentioned in their condemnation. I do not know what makes the Opposition feel that it is the only group in this Parliament that has any concern for primary producers or people living in rural areas. It is an absolute falsehood for Opposition senators to come up with that proposition. We have also heard tonight about where they think we have gone wrong. Not only have we not heard any concrete proposals from them; we have also heard nothing about the costing of what they are suggesting we might do. We should do some things more quickly and maybe we should do some things differently, Opposition senators say, but those things have not been spelt out. If the Opposition wishes to be the alternative government, it has to start off by costing its proposals and telling us clearly what they are.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government is aware of the hardship the drought is causing and the hardship that is being suffered by primary producers, particularly with the fall in their incomes, caused mainly, I might add, by factors external to this country. However, that seems to be forgotten. It is even more unfortunate that the present weather conditions are compounding the problems caused by the drop in commodity prices and the trade war being fought by the USA and the EC.

One way in which this Government has responded to the needs of the rural community has been through the rural adjustment scheme and the rural counselling programs. Funding for RAS has been substantially increased this year. The Government has also embarked on a comprehensive program of infrastructure reform which directly benefits primary producers. Historic progress has been made in the area of the waterfront and negotiations are proceeding with the States on the reform of the road and rail transport systems. Again, the conservative parties are totally devoid of any understanding of the reform processes. They are devoid of any constructive ideas on these issues, except to want to make things happen faster.

We had an example recently of what the current Liberals think of previous Liberal governments when the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson) expressed concern about the achievements of the conservatives under Malcolm Fraser. He was certainly less than complimentary in his assessments, which makes one wonder precisely what they will do. However, they have yet to spell out their plans. Have the Liberals learnt anything from that period in government? I am not sure, for the only serious policy proposal we have heard tonight has been for troops on the waterfront.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Troops on the waterfront! Who said that?

—-Senator Panizza said it; I have made copious notes. What sort of solution is this? The Government has always believed that any program of reform of our domestic economy must be accompanied by a corresponding reform in the international sphere. Of central concern to that belief has been the Uruguay Round of the multilateral trade negotiations which commenced in 1986, otherwise known as the GATT. Since opening the round, Australia has taken a leading role in the negotiations and has ensured that agriculture has remained at the top of the agenda. Australia has played a pivotal role in the formation of the Cairns Group of free trading nations, all of which have a common dependence on agricultural exports and share a desire for a more open, international agricultural market. The formation and continued effectiveness of the Cairns Group is a triumph for Australian trade diplomacy and a tribute to those Ministers who have had responsibility for that portfolio.

SPEECH.PARA: The Cairns Group now represents an effective third force in the current round of negotiations, which means that agricultural reform cannot be ignored. Today, no trade negotiator doubts that a successful conclusion to the Uruguay Round can be achieved without substantial liberalisation of agricultural trade. I defy anybody in this place to disagree with those points. It is important for us that we win the Uruguay Round of GATT, not just for Australia's primary producers but for the whole Australian economy.

We have also had groups of bipartisan members of parliament, including members of farming organisations, travelling to both the USA and the EC. These have had some benefit and have allowed our members to understand the thinking of the people in those countries and allowed those people to understand our thinking.

I know that I am repeating myself, but I made the point in the debate on the Appropriation Bills, and I will continue to make it, that many members of parliament, whenever they get an opportunity, badger and attempt to make visiting members of the US and EC parliaments explain why they have policies that provide massive subsidies for their primary produce to the detriment of all other nations in the world which are trying to compete with them. It is vitally important that this Government be assisted by all those who can do so to continue to apply this pressure. It is pointless moving motions of condemnation and then not putting up concrete proposals. All we have heard is that some things need to be--

TALK.START.PARA: —-Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. Under the Hawke Labor Government total farm debt has gone from $5.5 billion to $12 billion and total farm costs have gone from $11.4 billion to $20 billion. Yet Senator West is saying that we have no case to put. We do have a case to put.
—-Senator Brownhill, that is not a point of order, and I very strongly suspect that you know it. Unless someone wants to put an alternative view, I rule that there is no point of order.

—-I hasten to add that we have not heard addressed tonight any of the problems caused by the States. I need look only at my own home State and at how the policies of the Liberal Government there are impacting upon the people who live in primary producing areas. The grain handling charges that are levied by the New South Wales Liberal Government are about twice as high as those of the other States. That is an example of Liberal policies in action.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Calvert Sen P.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I was not going to say anything about Senator West's speech, but I have to make one point. I am sure she did not really mean it when she criticised Senator Panizza for not putting forward any proposals and then said that the proposals had not been costed. I find that rather hard to believe. I know that Senator West does have the interests of rural areas at heart. I am pleased that she has joined our newly formed Senate Standing Committee on Rural and Regional Affairs. I am looking forward to hearing her views on the problems facing rural Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I certainly support Senator Panizza's motion. Regardless of what Senator West has said about a lack of policies being put forward from this side, if Senator West reads the motion Senator Panizza has framed she will see in the second part that he has pointed out the sorts of things that need to be addressed to help the rural community.

TALK.START.PARA: —-But you haven't outlined the cost of them.
—- We only have a few minutes tonight.
—-You have half an hour.

—-There are other speakers too. I was not intending to get into the nitty gritty detail; I just wanted to point out to you, Madam Acting Deputy President, and to those opposite that, if they thought that mainland Australia was the only place in Australia that was having problems, I can assure them that things are no different in Tasmania. I read the papers today, and I cannot remember in my lifetime seeing the rural areas in such a disgraceful situation. Even the former Minister for Primary Industries and Energy, Mr Kerin, has said that this is the worst recession in 60 years. I do not think it is really at the stage depicted in some of those old movies I have seen where the American farmers were forced off the land into the cities, but it is fast approaching that sort of situation.

SPEECH.PARA: I know farmers whose families have been on the land in Tasmania for four generations. Their forefathers came out and settled there and carved their farms out of the wilderness four generations ago. I see them in a situation, through no fault of their own, where they are having to sell up their farms. They are moving from wool growing, because of wool prices, into vegetable growing areas. I cannot see the sense in that. I believe they are putting another noose around their neck. When people like Slim Dusty compose songs about the farmers' plight, that really points out just what a mess the rural areas are in.

TALK.START.PARA: —-What did you think when he composed The Pub with No Beer?

—-It could not have been any worse. The situation in the rural areas now is that not only do the pubs not have any beer but also the cattle do not have any water. In 1960, when there was a downturn in the wool market, we had a brief glimpse of what can happen to Australia. On this side of the Senate we know, and I am sure that Senator Cook would agree, that the drop in wool prices has not been the fault of the Government to any great extent. But we know the effect that the downturn in 1960 had on the economy in general. I know what effect it had on me when I first started out. In 1980 to 1982 we had a horrendous drought. We came out of the drought when Mr Hawke was elected Prime Minister and I think he even tried to take credit for ending it.

SPEECH.PARA: We are now back in the situation we were in in 1982. We have a very severe drought. It has been put down to the El Nino effect again. The drought has exacerbated the situation of rural producers. In good times, they tend to dodge along; in better times, they tend to forget. As long as they have a dollar in their pocket, they do not seem to mind and the Government does not mind taxing them more and more. We get used to all the taxes--provisional tax, et cetera.

I was interested to hear Senator West praise the Government for its very adequate rural adjustment scheme. In some cases, that scheme is really only extending the agony of some people, but it does hold out some hope. I will give credit to the Government for its initiatives in the area of rural counselling. But farmers certainly need more than rural counselling and rural adjustment schemes. They need fundamental changes in the rural areas. Senator Panizza points out in his motion some of the areas that are causing concern: interest rates, for one. Interest rates have been one of the biggest killers for farmers, particularly the farmers who have to get off their farms. The situation has now been exacerbated by the drought, but it was started by the high interest rate regime inflicted upon this country by the former Treasurer who engineered this recession.

Senator Collins has been telling us how he is going to make the waterfront more efficient. I believe that he has tried very hard in this regard. But we only have to read a report that was tabled in the Senate this week by the Australian Meat and Livestock Corporation. It pointed out that one of the biggest bugbears in exporting meat to overseas markets was the inefficiencies on the waterfront. As Senator Panizza said, some of the reforms that the Government is attempting may be coming into place, but they are too little, too late, and they have been far too slow. Also in his motion, Senator Panizza mentions a competitive tax structure, but he said it was not worth going into the detail of that tonight.

I am looking forward to attending the Royal Hobart Show next week because I will be able to get at first hand some other anecdotes and thoughts and perhaps some ideas from farmers around Tasmania. I have been getting many phone calls and many letters from not just the wool growers or the cattle growers but also the vegetable growers in Tasmania who have a big problem. They are finding it very hard to compete. We used to be the biggest producers of export potatoes for the manufacturing industry in Australia. McCain set up in Tasmania, and Edgells has been there for many years. They are concerned now. McCain imports some raw materials--potatoes--from Canada and New Zealand.

TALK.START.PARA: —-Are they forcing down grower prices?

—-They are forcing down farmers' prices. These potatoes are coming in from Canada and from New Zealand and I do not know whether they are being dumped. The point is that the New Zealanders have an advantage with their relatively low dollar compared with our high dollar. The inflated value of our Australian dollar is another thing that is affecting the rural industries severely. We have potatoes from New Zealand competing with a local product. They have been forcing the price down to about $32 a tonne. That is the last figure I heard. So where are our vegetable producers in Tasmania going to go? I will tell honourable senators: they are going to go broke. The last I heard was that Edgells is very seriously thinking about closing. It is of great concern to me and it should be of concern to the Minister because once Edgells goes out, there will be one producer--McCain--and it will be screwing the vegetable growers even further.

SPEECH.PARA: Rural adjustment schemes--rural reconstruction, as it used to be called--are all very well, but often they do not help when people are at the end of their tether. I was most disturbed to hear Senator Brownhill saying last night that, as a result of the drought and the rural recession in western New South Wales, there had been an increase in the number of people walking off their farms and, most importantly, an increase in the rate of suicide. That really does sum up the grief and despair of people in our rural areas. It is a huge problem to tackle but I am sure that, if adopted, the matters raised in Senator Panizza's motion would help to resolve it.

Another matter Senator Panizza raised in his motion is the transport system. A national road transport system is going to be set up. From what I can understand from people who have contacted me--and I had discussions with the Minister's advisers the other day--whilst I admit it is in the early stages, a lot of problems seem to be arising with this proposed transport system. By the time this matter sorts itself out, it will probably be too late for a lot of the truck owners who cart our cattle and stock around the country.

Today I just picked up a few papers to have a look at how things are going. I noticed this article--thank heavens--entitled `Slight price lift hopeful' concerning the Launceston wool sales. I must declare an interest there because I did have a few bales there. Further down, the article says that, despite a terrible autumn and a dry spring, the wool on offer was generally sound but overall production was down about 10 per cent and the return to growers was 50 per cent lower than at this time last year. How the dickens are those wool growers in Tasmania going to survive when they get a wool cheque 50 per cent less than last year and at the same time have all the extra costs and interest rates around their neck this year? It is no wonder that they are walking off their farms.

Another little area of concern in Tasmania is highlighted in another article that I picked out where it says that Gunns Kilndried Timber Industries is feeling the pinch because it has been a very depressed year with sales revenue down 14 to 15 per cent. The company has stood down 40 workers, which is a sign of the depressed logging industry in Tasmania. Other articles are headed `Cattle industry at four-year low' and `Industry looks for optimism'. The latter article states:
Two weeks ago, the price of Australian wool hit its 10-year low, closing even lower last week on 438c/kg clean.
That is a far cry from the 870c and 900c which we saw 12 to 15 months ago. I have not painted a very bright picture for the rural industry but that is the fact of the matter.

I am very pleased to see that my colleague from Western Australia, Senator Panizza, has brought this matter forward because it is of great importance. One has to get out there, talk to the people and actually see for oneself just how bad the situation really is. I just hope that the Democrats support us on this particular motion and that the Government will take some notice of what we are trying to say.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The time remaining for discussion does not allow proper consideration of the full extent of the motion. The Australian Democrats would certainly be tempted to support much of what the motion says. I hoped that we would have the opportunity to move an amendment whereby we would omit in paragraph (b) (ii) the words `to liberalise international trade' but, as the debate will not be concluded tonight, I do not see the opportunity to do so.
—-Order! Senator Bell, am I to take it that you are simply informing us that, if there were time, you would move an amendment but now you are not going to?

—-That is correct. In the time remaining I will just look at some aspects of the motion. In the first sentence the Government stands accused of a failure to provide direction and to support the rural sector. In this context we could define `direction' as perhaps indicating, without any ambiguity, the most satisfactory means to reach a goal, to provide signals or indicators which would guide the rural sector along the path to a goal for the nation's benefit; or perhaps we could say that `direction' means to discourage deviations from a path which would be in the nation's interest. There should be considerable discussion about it but, according to those definitions, I would say that the Government has failed to provide direction to the rural sector.

SPEECH.PARA: Perhaps the best indicator would be to ask the question: has this Government demonstrated its concern for, and faith in, the future of Australian farming and the communities which support Australian farmers? The answer to that question would have to be no. The evidence is that financial hardship has been visited upon Australian farmers but that those same farmers cannot be held responsible for the financial problems in which they find themselves. In other words, they are in financial difficulty, but whose fault is it?

I contend that the blame lies squarely at the feet of all those who have been duped by the economic rationalists, by the bank deregulators, by the tariff reducers, by those who choose to allow interest rates to remain high and the foreign exchange rate to float, and by those who choose to fight inflation with engineered recession. We have heard the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, indicate here in answer to a question from Senator Coulter that he does not understand the meaning of interventionist policies. He would wash his hands and deny any capacity or any need for the Government to intervene in the economy; that is, to provide any meaningful signals or alterations which could ameliorate some of the excesses which are suffered by the rural sector which supports this nation.

This economy shows as much evidence of being well managed as a boy on a bike careering off down the hill shouting, `Look, Mum, no hands'. We all know that the next line is: `Look Mum, no teeth'. Well, that is what is happening here: the Government's responsibility to steer this economy has been abandoned. It has lost its teeth; it has lost its capacity to have any effect on the economy; it has lost its capacity to do anything but munch its gums at the problems which surround rural Australia. Because of that, I am very tempted to suggest that we would be supporting this motion.

But the trouble is that in many cases we have been encouraged to allow this managed chaos of the so-called free market forces to prevail. The people who have encouraged us to allow that managed chaos of the free market forces have been the coalition itself. We have before us a partnership of Government and coalition which has quite blithely sat by and allowed the mismanagement of this economy to occur to such an extent that our rural sector is now reduced to something which is going to be very difficult to resurrect.

I share the optimism of one of the previous speakers, who said that the rural economy will prevail because we have people out there who have faced all sorts of adversities in the past. But I would not like to be in their shoes now and be facing this particular adversity. Apart from interventions such as fixing interest rates, fixing exchange rates, investing in infrastructure to support efficient transport systems and further removing any remaining inefficient work practices which might prevail at transport nodes such as railway stations, airports or on the waterfront, there are many other interventions which the Government should make on behalf of the entire community.

I say the entire community because there is another aspect to this whole debate, which I have raised before in this chamber, and that is associated with the concept of user pays. So often in this place we pass Bills for the application of various levies and funds to various branches of our rural industries. These levies cover the whole range from the honey levy to the cattle transaction levy and pig levies, et cetera. I do not think any of us could possibly keep track of the incredible number of inspection levies, research levies, administrative levies and the like.
