These are all collected from the rural sector's producers with the assumption that the producers benefit most from the improved or cleaner products. I suggest that that assumption is false--the whole community benefits and the Government has responsibility to meet those costs on behalf of the community.

Similarly, the community--through its successive governments--has established a series of award wages, local government charges, sickness benefits, holiday pay, superannuation benefits, inspection charges, packaging standards and the various other standards which Australian consumers have come to expect and appreciate. The community has established these standards and is willing to pay for them when purchasing Australian produce, and logically it should expect a responsible government to protect those standards. Quite simply, if the Government allows free entry of overseas products which do not need to meet these standards, the Government has not properly accepted its responsibilities. Senator Boswell has so often espoused such a move. The Democrats would support him and thank him for his efforts to bring about such a change.
Debate interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —-Order! It being 10.30 p.m., I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BOSWELL
TALKER.ROLE: -Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —-There have been a number of articles recently in the Aviation Press which imply that the tender released by the RAAF for flight screening and basic flying training is biased towards a foreign owned company, Hawker de Havilland. The tender calls for pilot training and flight screening for the RAAF and Army for a period of three years, plus two by one options. This is in replacement of current training conducted by RAAF at Point Cook in Victoria. There would be approximately 88 students requiring training per year. The current aircraft is a CT/A and B Airtrainer. The tender calls for aircraft which offer identical specification to the CT/4, including aerobatic ability, as well as a new requirement for a side by side seating, aerobatic, tailwheel aeroplane.

SPEECH.PARA: Would the Parliamentary Secretary to the Treasurer (Senator McMullan) contact the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray) and ask him whether he would give an assurance that the substance of the press articles is not correct and that tenders will be evaluated fully on merit and not with any bias, particularly towards a company which is substantially foreign owned? In other words, will the Minister ensure that there has been no undue benefit given to any single responding company? I seek leave to table relevant documents.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —-I want to talk about security issues this evening and put somewhat of a different complexion on the usual definition of security. There has been a great deal of community debate about certain areas of Australian Budget expenditure, such as superannuation and the lack of adequate provision for the unemployed.

SPEECH.PARA: One area that got by unscathed was defence, which took up 9.3 per cent of total Budget expenditure. The coalition offered some comments on the subject, but only to complain that the Department of Defence was buying the wrong equipment. This surprised me as I thought it would grasp the opportunity to slash Budget expenditure in this area, in line with all its other proposals to cut every other area as savagely as possible. Predictably, the Australian Defence Association said that Australia should be spending more on the military and referred to 22 possible threats that needed to be countered in the next 15 years.

Given the hard rethink that is going on in strategic defence circles and the end of the Cold War, it is sad that no-one has addressed the advantages offered to us by these profound changes. It seems as though the peace dividend is back on the agenda in many other countries post-Gulf War. It never really got on the agenda in Australia and is still not on our agenda. I think it is high time for a reassessment of our defence expenditure in relation to our foreign affairs budget, in light of the dramatic changes that are taking place globally. Instead, we have a ludicrous spectacle of the military admitting that the Soviet threat has, indeed, dissipated but desperately trying to drum up new threats in enemy images to justify a continued level of military expenditure.

In Europe, NATO has noted the disappearance of the Warsaw Pact. Yet, while trying to justify its continued existence, it has proved completely impotent when it comes to maintaining the peace in Yugoslavia. It is the European Community which has sought to set up a ceasefire to monitor that very sad situation. It is not doing too well either, but at least it is making the attempt. It seems to be completely beyond the capacity of NATO to try to do anything about it.

In Australia, the Royal United Services Institute had a conference in Canberra at the end of September on realignment of the world order--implications for Asia-Pacific security. The new Indonesian Ambassador to Australia, Mr Sabam Siagian, was far more perceptive than most of the men in uniform who still seemed locked in the past. While Senator Ray said that Australia accepted a continued strategic role in regional security, Mr Siagian pointed out that the US military presence in South East Asia has not suppressed regional conflicts. This implied that ASEAN countries had done more to reduce tension in the region than the United States because they had carefully avoided any suggestion that ASEAN would become a military bloc.

General Gration was prepared to look ahead as well, but reverted to drumming up the usual invisible threat scenarios, though conceding that the military would need to concentrate on both military and non-military situations. It is not prepared to accept that the end of the Cold War and the need to address new concepts of security meant that there also had to be a fundamental rethinking about the role of the military and its current capital equipment programs.

To consider that, we need to note the words of Gwyn Prins, Director of the Global Security Program at Cambridge University and a fellow of Emmanual College at that university. He was in Canberra in September this year to speak about new options in defence strategies, personnel and equipment, presented as a result of the end of the Cold War. There is obviously some reassessment going on in New Zealand on this issue of equipment, in particular, with a certain amount of discussion on possible threat scenarios in the future.

General Gration, who was speaking at the RUSI conference, criticised what he called the popular myth that Australia faced no military threat for 10 years. He said that it had never reflected present military thinking. Rather, the debate seems to focus on whether Australia faces a major threat or just minor threats. There does appear to be agreement that minor threats, such as terrorist attacks, are likely to arise far more quickly.

The question I want to raise here is the relevance of proceeding with the Anzac class frigates program as well as the Collins class submarines. Low level or minor threats are things like piracy, drug running, illegal fishing and abuse of and pollution of enclosed waters. If there is to be a regional effort to deal with these problems, say, a regional maritime safety and surveillance organisation which has been voted in ASEAN circles this year, then the Anzac class frigates are not really the kinds of surface ships that we should be tying ourselves to for the next 20 or 30 years. It would cost us money to cancel the existing orders, of course. But military plans are legendary for their ability to be changed at the last moment and it would cost us far more in the long run to build the frigates when we do not need them and at the expense of building the kinds of ship that we do need.

We really need more ships in the water--smaller ships, technically simpler, vessels with long endurance and, of course, a much lower weapons density. Instead, we are locked into a capital equipment program reflecting the days when our submarines were used by the United States Navy to run around checking on Soviet nuclear submarines in the North Pacific and when the enemy was the Soviet Pacific fleet. This refusal to take up the challenges of the twenty-first century, which will be global security rather than national security and making sure that we do not let the East-West confrontation be replaced by a North-South one, is reflected in Europe where NATO is desperately floundering around trying to justify its continued existence. It is totally incapable of suggesting any positive role in the one major conflict now raging in the Balkans.

We have precisely the same situation in this part of the world. Just as NATO is set up to counter the perceived threat of Soviet domination in Europe, so the ANZUS alliance was brought into existence as part of the US strategy of containment in the Asia-Pacific region. Now the threat no longer exists the military is desperately trying to justify its continued role in acquisition of capital equipment, so that we get Admiral Jeremiah, Vice-Chairman of the US Joint Chiefs of Staff, saying in Canberra on 27 September that the United States would need to retain powerful military forces because the world is an unstable place. He asserted that as many as 20 nations could develop nuclear weapons in the next 20 years without saying anything about how they would acquire them or why his own country should have them while others could not.

He then warned that the world would have a population of 10 billion by the year 2025 and that a quarter of these people would be hungry. Why then did he not suggest that instead of spending billions of dollars on Trident submarines and missiles, the B2 bomber and Star Wars--or Brilliant Pebbles as they are now called in the toned down version--the United States transfer its resources to combating the courses of this insecurity, hunger, poverty and disease? These are the real risks to our security.

Certainly there are conflicts in the Asia-Pacific region but, just as NATO does not know what to do in Yugoslavia, the military has no real long term solutions to offer with regard to the conflicts in Kashmir, Sri Lanka, Burma, the Philippines, East Timor, West Papua, the two Chinas, the two Koreas, Bougainville or anywhere else. The implication of Admiral Jeremiah's speech was that the military would be used to maintain the injustice of the status quo in the name of the new world order--in essence, replacing the enemy images of the East-West confrontation with enemy images based on a war against the South.

In a time of shifting alliances and unstable governments, this can backfire very easily, as yesterday's friend becomes tomorrow's enemy, armed with the weapons that we equipped and supplied. We need to look only at Panama, Iran, Iraq and Syria for proof of this boomerang syndrome with weapons transfers. What we really need, of course, is a new definition of security.

Two hundred years ago the founding fathers of the United States of America in the Declaration of Independence had a list of three principles: life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness. The problem today is that many people in industrialised societies have confused the priorities and have come to see their rights to the pursuit of happiness as more important than other people's rights to life or liberty. We then end up with a definition of security that is exclusive. We do not see our security as being bound up with other very different definitions of security. National security has come to be seen as the same thing as the security of the individual living within that particular state. So the individual's security becomes part of maintaining the territorial integrity of the state, or the maintenance of the ideological supremacy of a set of ideas which that state is said to represent.

As the appetite for raw materials and also for markets in these very wealthy states grew during the twentieth century, so did these same states' concept of what constituted their minimum security. It came to involve not only their right to territorial integrity, but also access to raw materials that came from other parts of the world at fixed and stable prices. Indeed, we have reached the point that John Kenneth Galbraith warned us about when he argued that, once an individual, a company or a country has reached a certain point of wealth, its economic rationale comes to be less and less driven by the pursuit of profit and more and more by the pursuit of predictability and control of its environment.

Once security was a concept defined at the national and international scale above all, but now we add both the small scale, that is, the personal security, and the large scale, environmental security. The fact of the close coupling of these two--the very small and the very large--is one of the distinguishing characteristics of global security. The introduction of the environmental dimension into the concept of security could not have come at a more timely moment, for the inherited concept of security from the last generation has reached a time of crisis.

The dropping of nuclear weapons on Hiroshima and Nagasaki confronted us with the question of how strategic thinking and international relations could accommodate this monstrous increase in the destructiveness of war. Then the Cold War arrived. To deal with this new threat, the United States devised a doctrine of containment, armed with its new lethal weapons. The psychology of the nuclear age demanded the dehumanising and demonising of the potential enemy as a necessary prerequisite for people who wish to retain their sanity, while at the same time planning the nuclear incineration of millions of other people. Suddenly, with the end of the Cold War, the pattern of more than 40 years has begun to disintegrate rapidly.

Our leaders cast about desperately for new enemy images, and in the last couple of years we have been presented with a number of unpleasant Third World dictators: Colonel Gaddafi, Manuel Noriega, Saddam Hussein, and possibly someone like Kim Il Sung as the next bad guy. These enemies are terrorists who blow aircraft out of the sky; they are drug runners, fundamentalists and religious fanatics, or anybody who seems likely to pose a threat to the normality of life in the rich nations of the North--a term which, for this purpose, includes Australia.

Curiously, it is Time magazine that has pointed out that the cuts announced by President Bush in the area of tactical nuclear weapons do not save money and still leave the US with a strategic advantage--whatever that means in today's world. It is precisely the continuation of forced modernisation, the continued deployment of the Trident submarine and ongoing research on the B2 bomber and Star Wars that constitutes the kind of skewed thinking I am talking about.

I fear that it is also reflected in the other nuclear weapons states, as the French continue to test in the South Pacific, the British continue to build Trident submarines while there are riots in their cities, the Soviet Navy goes on building its new aircraft carrier and new surface combatants and submarines while its people cry out for consumer goods, and the Chinese go on with the development of their blue water nuclear navy while they ignore calls for democracy within China and the call for self-determination by Tibet.

Needless to say, seen from the perspectives of the poor South, the range of threats to security is very different from the perceptions of the North. For them, war, famine and pestilence ride together. Virtually all of the armed conflicts since 1945 have been in the South--a significant change from the pre-war era. Yet we have military leaders such as Admiral Jeremiah arguing that the US has to retain powerful military forces because other countries can now obtain nuclear, chemical and biological arsenals; because a quarter of the world's people are hungry; and because the United States was a Pacific power and would remain militarily involved, even if it is now making other nations, such as Japan, foot the bill for its continuing global presence. The contradictions are ludicrous.

The North is to keep nuclear weapons to safeguard against other countries that might acquire them. We are to perpetuate world hunger because we refuse to transfer dollars and research expertise from Trident missiles and submarines to feeding the hungry and dealing with the root cause of much of their insecurity; topping it off by arming the regimes that maintain this oppression in the name of national security and the right to national defence.

In Australia, we are told that we cannot reap the peace dividend because there is a lot of conflict in the Asia-Pacific region. Yet, as in Europe, the military is equipped with totally inappropriate tools and is useless in helping to resolve these longstanding conflicts. None of the conflicts in the region pose a threat to Australia, but they cry out for third party diplomacy, non-military forms of conflict resolution, the strengthening of international institutions that can assist, and new diplomatic initiatives that will devise a response to the second wave of self-determination now that the colonial era is virtually over.

One exception to this generally bleak picture I am painting of Australia's role at the moment is the case of Cambodia. The Government certainly deserves to be congratulated for its efforts there. It is indeed a tragedy that the kind of new thinking we require is more or less absent from current Government policy--with that major exception--and certainly within military circles, with the exception of a few other United Nations initiatives.

I mentioned earlier the introduction of the environmental dimension into the concept of global security. Many analysts are redefining the term `security' to take account of the fact that the most serious and immediate threats to most of the world's population are posed by environmental degradation. We saw this year how abuse of the environment can be used as a weapon, with both deliberate and consequential oil spills and the burning of hundreds of oil wells. There were also threats to divert or withhold vital fresh water supplies-- water being the only resource other than oil that has been suggested as a possible catalyst for a resource war in the Middle East. The environment has been a major casualty of other wars too. The intense use of defoliants in Vietnam and their continuing effects should not be forgotten.

There is a much wider sense in which our security is intrinsically linked to the health of our environment. Consideration of the major environmental degradation occurring today--global climate change, depletion of the ozone layer, deforestation and desertification at rates never before seen on the planet, and pollution of air and water--makes it difficult to ignore the fact that these are the real threats to global security. On this issue, one scientist-analyst has said:

Viewed with traditional concepts, any force that had the power to inflict such harm upon a state--kill some of its citizens and displace others, reduce its agricultural output, threaten its water supply, and destabilise its ecological balance--would be received with considerable attention. Today, therefore, just because these particular challenges are not being issued and controlled by a national leader does not mean that they should be ignored. Indeed, the fact that they are beyond such control makes them all the more threatening and ominous.

Since the nature of the threats to global security has changed radically, it is vitally important that we develop responses that recognise the changes. For a start, we need to acknowledge the global dimensions of the problems and the need for international cooperative responses.

I am pleased that Australia played such a leading role in one global approach which recently gave heart to environmentalists around the world. The agreement to ban mining in Antarctica for the next 50 years and to give priority to nature conservation and appropriate scientific research there will, I hope, be the forerunner of future global decisions that will put humanity's common aspirations ahead of the economic demands of those who already exploit more than their share of the earth's resources.

Indeed, there have been attempts to deal with other issues on a global scale, but we have not reached the stage of being able to set aside national and sectional interests even when they clearly conflict with global and, hence, our own long term interests.

While there has been considerable progress towards the reduction of ozone depleting substances globally, the difficulties which were encountered in negotiating the Montreal Protocol, and the difficulties in ensuring not just compliance with the protocol but continuous reappraisal by all countries of the adequacy of their response, are unfortunately being experienced again in relation to a global response to climate change, and are even greater when we start to talk about possible responses to loss of biodiversity or global deforestation.

In the case of ozone depletion, we saw years of stalling by the main producers of ozone depleting CFCs because of inadequate information and scientific uncertainties. The major producers argued vigorously that there should be no obligation for them to do anything unilaterally and that they should not have to contribute to the cost of alternative strategies to dissuade developing countries from taking the same destructive path. It was only when the evidence for ozone depletion became overwhelming, and in fact the depletion was shown to be far more severe than had been detected a few years previously, that the industrialised countries which produced and used most of the world's CFCs finally agreed to act.

We are seeing exactly the same sort of delaying tactics again in the negotiation of an agreement on reduction of greenhouse gas emissions. The first predictions of global climate change as a consequence of the increase in carbon dioxide concentrations came in the nineteenth century. Despite some attempts to play down the consequences of greenhouse warming, no-one has yet disproved those initial estimates of either the nature or the possible magnitude of the changes we are forcing on the global climate through the emission of greenhouse gases.

The international community has at least accepted that it is a real problem and, with such a time lag between actions and consequences, we cannot wait for all the studies to be completed before we think about a response. Accordingly, the inter-governmental negotiating committee was convened to draft a framework climate convention which would hopefully be ready for signing at the United Nations Conference on Environment and Development in Brazil next June. We have already seen the patterns of the ozone debate re-emerging: the industrialised nations are refusing to accept their responsibility for the problem, pointing at the potential for the developing countries to increase their emissions as somehow absolving us from action. The developing countries are quite understandably saying that global warming should not become an excuse for maintaining the existing inequities in resource use between the developed North and the developing South.

This is what I was referring to earlier when I said that there was a danger of East-West confrontation being replaced by North-South confrontation. On the one hand, the North wants to address individual environmental issues without any consideration of restructuring of international economic relations. On the other hand, the South sees that this involves threats to its sovereignty over natural resources and future development, and that the North is not willing to face the systemic courses of the threats to environmental security; that is, the gross inequities in financial resources between North and South.

In 1989 we saw a net transfer of $44 billion from the poorer nations to the richer nations, despite all aid and private sector investments. In addition, there is a large transfer of natural resources from the South to the North because the South is forced to trade its way out of its massive and crippling debt at the cost of its own people's requirements.

At the same time, more than $2 billion is spent in the world each day on armaments. In the past two decades, the world has spent 70 per cent more on arms than it has on health and at least 15 per cent more on arms than on education. While this is going on, we are bogged down in negotiating a climate change convention--we have not got anywhere on a biodiversity convention--because of the fear of the developed nations that they may have to contribute financially to implementation of those conventions. It is almost unbelievable that disarmament and the redirection of resources from military to life-developing purposes such as the provision of water, food, health, housing and alternative energy sources are not even on the agenda for next year's UN conference on environment and development.

The developed nations have contributed most to the global warming by being the biggest users of fossil fuels. They are the nations which have for the most part largely destroyed their own forests and woodlands. Australia's record of forest removal is a classic example. It is the developed nations which have the resources and the technology--if not the willpower--to make the biggest changes in their economic systems and their lifestyles to reduce dramatically their output of greenhouse gases and to start restoring some of the planet's carbon sinks through reafforestation.

Unfortunately, however, it is the developing countries which are likely to be most severely affected by changes in the sea level, increased climatic uncertainty and the consequent incidence of storms, floods and droughts. The countries which are already marginal, and already locked into the cycle of poverty and environmental degradation, will be the hardest hit and the least able to cope.

No wonder then that there is some scepticism from the developing world at what it sees as our hypocritical concern over global warming. It sees us refusing to accept that, because we contribute more to the causes of climate change through our high per capita use of fossil fuels, we should therefore accept a commensurate responsibility for decreasing the release of greenhouse gases into the atmosphere. Instead, what Australia and most of the industrialised world are saying is that, because this is a global problem, everyone has to share the responsibility--even though they did not get to share in any of the benefits of industrialisation. Furthermore, the developed nations are not going to countenance any action that may disadvantage their economies in the short term.

When the Protocol on the Reduction of Ozone Destroying Substances was being negotiated, the developing countries saw the same thing happening. The North decided that the South could not be allowed to proceed in the same way as it had because of the harm that would be done to the environment if everyone used resources at such rates. This led to the astute observation that the South was being coerced into forgoing the development that the North had already undertaken so that white northern skins could be saved from melanomas.

It is equally hard to see why the South should resign itself to its current level of development so that the North can continue to use a disproportionate level of the earth's resources while pretending to be so concerned about the planet's state of health. If a forum such as UNCED is to have any real effect on ensuring our environmental security, we will have to learn to be less selective about what we are willing to share and more aware of the interconnectedness of poverty, environmental degradation and individual security.

The new world order will keep looking like the old world order unless we can both recognise those connections and start to address them. To do that, we need to examine our own priorities in Australia and to introduce some of these broader concepts of security to our political and economic systems. For a start, though, we would need to shed the old concept of security as territory and security as maintenance of the status quo, especially through military regimes. The status quo has not been working too well for the unemployed, the young homeless, most of our Aboriginal population or the environment at large.

Unfortunately, a common reaction to the prospect of change--and the magnitude and nature of the changes are unprecedented--is to cling myopically to what we think we know best. In Australia, and most of the developed world, we cling to a system in which any development is good development and the best is that which is biggest. While other nations are talking about environmental security in terms of being able to feed and house their own populations and the growing

number of environmental refugees, we corrupt the term to talk about resource security by guaranteeing diminishing native forest resources to multimillion dollar pulp mills--which will be established through more overseas borrowing--to employ a fraction of the people who would be employed in small scale, high quality saw logging operations.

While we are paying lip service to the concept of global responsibility to reduce greenhouse warming, we are building new coal-fired power stations instead of introducing some effective energy demand systems which could reduce both our environmental and economic costs. We are directing 9.3 per cent of the Budget into defence against invisible threats and a paltry 0.37 per cent into overseas aid against the all too visible threat of poverty and environmental degradation.

SPEECH.PARA: cant achievements by Australia on the international front this year with regard to Antarctica and Cambodia.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General upon notice, on 14 August 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: What legislation or regulation is required by Commonwealth law to de-list from world heritage status, areas which had previously been listed.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —-The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The process of listing properties on the World Heritage List is a matter of international law which does not of itself require domestic legislation. For the same reason a domestic law, such as a Commonwealth Act or regulation, could not operate to remove an area from the World Heritage List.

The World Heritage List is established under Article 11 of the Convention for the Protection of the World Cultural and Natural Heritage. Australia is a Party to that Convention. Although the Convention itself does not provide for removal of a property from the World Heritage List, the Operational Guidelines issued under the Convention do. Under those guidelines there are two circumstances which may give rise to removal. The first is where the property has deteriorated to the extent that it has lost those characteristics which led to its inclusion on the World Heritage List. The second is where the property was under threat at the time of its nomination to the List and the necessary corrective measures to remove the threat have not been taken within the time allowed. A removal can only take place if approved by a majority of two thirds of the World Heritage Committee.
